admirabilitas: <entryFree id="n884" type="main" key="admi_ra_bi^li^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admīrābĭlĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>admirabilis</etym>, <sense id="n884.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the quality that produces admiration</hi> or <pb n="40" /> <cb n="ADMI" /> <hi rend="ital">wonder</hi>, <hi rend="ital">admirableness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wonderfulness</hi> (vis, quae admirationem excitat): <cit><quote lang="la">quanta sit admirabilitas caelestium rerum atque terrestrium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:36" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum admirabilitate maxima,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec animi despicientia admirabilitatem magnam facit,</quote> <trans><tr>excites great admiration of the possessor of this virtue</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:11" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 11</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
admirabiliter: <entryFree id="n885" type="main" key="admi_ra_bi^li^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admīrābĭlĭter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. admirabilis.</entryFree>
admirandus: <entryFree id="n886" type="main" key="admi_randus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admīrandus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. admiror <sense id="n886.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
admiratio: <entryFree id="n887" type="main" key="admi_ra_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admīrātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>admiror</etym>. <sense id="n887.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An admiring</hi>, <hi rend="ital">admiration.—Absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tua divina virtus admirationis plus habet quam gloriae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,032:chapter=26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Marcell. 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui (plausus) non numquam ipsa admiratione compressus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:chapter=34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">perspicua admiratione declaratur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,026:chapter=2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Balb. 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:10:36" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 10, 36</bibl>.— More freq. with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> of object: <cit><quote lang="la">copiose sapienterque dicentis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:14" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quid fuit in isto studio admirationis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admiratione afficiuntur ii,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admiratio nonnulla in bestiis aquatilibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:48:124 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 48, 124 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cuivis inicere admirationem sui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,011:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Iph. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hominis admiratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:chapter=4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Arch. 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admiratio viri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 9, 8</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 7, 34</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:52 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 52 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in magna admiratione esse,</quote> <trans><tr>to be greatly admired</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 5, 10, § 32</bibl></cit>.—In <number>plur.</number>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec sunt, quae admirationes in bonis oratoribus efficiunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 33</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:84:290" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 84, 290</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:7:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 7, 13</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n887.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Wonder</hi>, <hi rend="ital">surprise</hi>, <hi rend="ital">astonishment</hi> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">admiror, admirabilis): hoc mihi maximam admirationem movet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:10:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 10, 2</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">habere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:12:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 5, 12, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">divitiarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 62</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:3 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 3 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">admiratio ancipitis sententiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non sine admiratione,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:19" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 19</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 12, 10, § 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:107" default="NO" valid="yes">16, 26, 44, § 107</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut admirationem faciam populo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:29:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Isa. 29, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">miratus sum illam admiratione magna,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:17:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Apoc. 17, 6</bibl></cit>.—Also with <hi rend="ital">quod</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">(Decium) admiratio incessit, quod nec pugnam inirent, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:34:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 34, 12</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
admirator: <entryFree id="n888" type="main" key="admi_ra_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admīrātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n888.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an admirer</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">alicujus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:4:21:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 4, 21, 21</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 94:70" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 94, 70</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mundi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Cons. ad Helv. 8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Cons. ad Helv. 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">antiquitatis nimius admirator,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:5:21 al" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 5, 21 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
admiror: <entryFree id="n889" type="main" key="admi_ror"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-mīror</orth>, <itype>ātus, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos>, <sense id="n889.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to wonder at</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be astonished at</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to regard with admiration</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to admire</hi>, to be in a state of mind in which something pleases us by its extraordinary greatness, its sublimity, or perfection; while <hi rend="ital">mirari</hi> signifies to be surprised at, to have the feeling of the new, singular, unusual. </sense><sense id="n889.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">quorum ego copiam non modo non contemno, sed etiam vehementer admiror,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ingenium tuum, Crasse, vehementer admirans,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 20</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">res gestas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:94:323" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 94, 323</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quem et admiror et diligo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 36</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,029:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Scaur. 1, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">magnitudinem animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Dion. 2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dion. 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Alcib. 11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Alcib. 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">illum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:215" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 215</bibl></cit> (cf. mirari in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:14:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 14, 43</bibl>, and the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">qauma/zein</foreign>, Eurip. Med. 1144).—</sense><sense id="n889.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n889.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To gaze at passionately</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to strive after a thing from admiration of it</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to desire to obtain it</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil hominem nisi quod honestum decorumque sit, aut admirari aut optare aut expetere oportere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 20</bibl></cit>: nil admirari prope res est una, Numici, Solaque quae possit facere et servare beatum, <hi rend="ital">not to be brought by any thing into an impassioned state of mind</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">into a state of desire</hi> or <hi rend="ital">longing</hi> (as in the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">mh\ qauma/zein</foreign>; <cit><quote lang="la">acc. to Pythagoras the limit of all philos. effort),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 6, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n889.4" n="B" level="2"> More freq., <hi rend="ital">to fall into a state of wonder</hi> or <hi rend="ital">astonishment at a thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to wonder at</hi>, <hi rend="ital">be astonished at.</hi>—Constr. with <case>acc.</case>, <case>acc.</case> with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">de</hi>, <hi rend="ital">super</hi> aliquam rem, with a <hi rend="ital">relat. clause</hi>, <hi rend="ital">quod</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cur</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">quid admirati estis?</quote> <trans><tr>why are you so surprised?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. prol. 99</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admiratus sum brevitatem epistulae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc maxime admiratus sum, mentionem te hereditatum ausum esse facere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 16 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Alcib. 1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Alcib. 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Epam. 6:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Epam. 6, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">de diplomate admiraris, quasi, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:10:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 10, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de Dionysio sum admiratus, qui, etc.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 12</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">super quae admiratus pater,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Tob. 5, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:13:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 13, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cave quidquam admiratus sis, quā causā id fiat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:6:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 6, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admirantium, unde hoc studium exstitisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admiratur quidnam Vettius dicturus sit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:167" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 3, 167</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admiror, quo pacto, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:4:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 4, 99</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admiratus sum, quod, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne quis sit admiratus, cur, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:10:35" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 10, 35</bibl></cit>. <cb n="ADMI" />!*? <hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi>: Propter venustatem vestimentorum admirari, <hi rend="ital">to be admired</hi>, Canutius ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 792</bibl> P.—<hi rend="ital">Part. fut. pass.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">admīrandus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">to be admired; admirable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wonderful</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">suspicienda et admiranda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:72:148" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 72, 148</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo magis pravitas eorum admiranda est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 2, 4</bibl></cit>. —Hence also <pos>adj.</pos>, = admirabilis: <cit><quote lang="la">patiens admirandum in modum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,015:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ep. 3</bibl></cit>: exposuit quae in Italia viderentur admiranda, id. Cat. <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">admiranda spectacula,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vir subtilis et in plurimis admirandus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:3:11:22" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 3, 11, 22</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi> and <pos>adv.</pos> not used.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi> is found in <bibl default="NO"><author>Salv.</author> Ep. 8</bibl>: admirandissimi juvenes; cf. Barth, Adv. 35, 9.</sense></entryFree>
admisceo: <entryFree id="n890" type="main" key="admisce^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-miscĕo</orth>, <itype>scui, xtum</itype> (better than -stum), <itype>2</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n890.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to add to by mingling</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to mix with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mingle with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to admix</hi> (in <hi rend="ital">admiscere</hi> there is a ref. to a principal constituent, to which something is added; in <hi rend="ital">immiscere</hi>, to the intimate union of the ingredients; in <hi rend="ital">permiscere</hi>, to the removal of their distinct characteristics). </sense><sense id="n890.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, constr. with the <case>abl.</case> of that with which any thing is mingled: <cit><quote lang="la">aër multo calore admixtus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:10:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 10, 27</bibl></cit> (cf. on the contr. ib. § 26: aquae admixtum calorem; <cit><quote lang="la">and soon after: admixtum calorem): genus radicis admixtum lacte,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 48</bibl></cit>.— With <hi rend="ital">in</hi> with <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">admixtis in heminam seminis resinae coclearibus duobus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 10, 66, § 104</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">cum</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">admiscent torrefacta sesama cum aniso,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:15" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 15</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n890.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n890.3" n="A" level="2"> Of things, <hi rend="ital">to mingle in</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to mix with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to add to</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">nec tamen admiscent in eorum corpus inane,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:745" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 745</bibl></cit>: deus bonis omnibus mundum implevit; <cit><quote lang="la">mali nihil admiscuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Univ. 3</bibl></cit>: se admiscere atque implicare hominum vitiis, id. Fragm. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:de Trin. 14:19" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> de Trin. 14, 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sed hoc cum iis rationibus admisceri nolo,</quote> <trans><tr>be mixed up</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Att. 7:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Att. 7, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admiscere huic generi orationis illud alterum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:de Or. 2:49" default="NO"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">versus admiscere orationi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Tusc. 2:11:26" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 11, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admiscenda venus est timori,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:609" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 3, 609</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non admixtus fidei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,019:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Heb. 4, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,034:23:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Eccli. 23, 10</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n890.4" n="B" level="2"> Of persons. </sense><sense id="n890.5" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To mix up with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to add</hi> or <hi rend="ital">join to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">his Antonianos milites admiscuerat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3</bibl></cit>. 4: <cit><quote lang="la">expeditos antesignanos admiscuit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 75</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad id consilium admisceor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:12:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 12, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admiscerenturne plebeii,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>whether the plebeians should be admitted to the number of the decemvirs</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:32:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 32, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admixti funditoribus sagittarii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:3:9" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 3, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:579" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 579</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n890.6" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To involve</hi> or <hi rend="ital">entangle in a thing</hi>: se, <hi rend="ital">to interfere</hi> or <hi rend="ital">meddle with</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ita tu istaec tua misceto, ne me admisceas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:5:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 5, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne te admisce: nemo accusat, Syre, te,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 2, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad id consilium admiscear?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:12:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 12, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Trebatium vero meum, quod isto admisceas nihil est,</quote> <trans><tr>implicate</tr>, <tr>involve in</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 1, 3</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">admixtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">that is mingled with something</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mixed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not simple</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">simplex animi natura est, nec habet in se quidquam admixtum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Sen. 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil est animis admixtum, nihil concretum, nihil copulatum, nihil coagmentatum, nihil duplex,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:29" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 29</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi>, and <pos>adv.</pos> not used.</sense></entryFree>
admissarius: <entryFree id="n891" type="main" key="admissa_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admissārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>admitto</etym>, sc. equus, asinus, etc., <sense id="n891.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a horse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ass</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">that is used for breeding</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a stallion</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">equus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:7" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">asinus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:ib. 2:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 8</bibl></cit>.—Hence, metaph. <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, </sense><sense id="n891.1" n="II" level="1"> Of a sensual, lewd man: <cit><quote lang="la">scitus admissarius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:3:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 3, 19</bibl></cit>: admissarius iste, sic ad illius orationem adhinniit, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:28:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 28, 69</bibl> (cf. adhinnio); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 1:16" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 1, 16</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
admissio: <entryFree id="n892" type="main" key="admissi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admissĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>. <sense id="n892.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An admitting of the male to the female</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:1:18" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 1, 18</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n892.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Admission to a prince</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an audience</hi> (post-Aug.): <cit><quote lang="la">quibus admissionis liberae jus dedissent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 3, 12, § 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admissionum tuarum felicitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:47" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">primae et secundae admissiones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 6:33" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 6, 33</bibl></cit>; cf. Lipsius ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 9</bibl>. (Special officers of reception were appointed, whose charge was called officium admissionis, <hi rend="ital">the office of chamberlain</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:14" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vesp. 14</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and the superintendent of them was called maagister admissionum,</quote> <trans><tr>chief marshal</tr>, <tr>lord chamberlain</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 15, 5</bibl></cit>.)—</sense><sense id="n892.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The entrance upon an inheritance</hi>, Cod. 6, 15, 5.</sense></entryFree>
admissionalis: <entryFree id="n893" type="main" key="admissi^o_na_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admissĭōnālis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>admissio</etym>, <sense id="n893.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who introduced those who came to an audience</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an usher of the privy chamber</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a seneschal</hi><cb n="ADMI" />  (late Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Alex. Sev. 4</bibl>; Cod. Th. 6, 35, 7 al.</sense></entryFree>
admissivae: <entryFree id="n894" type="gloss" key="admissi_vae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admissīvae</orth>, <itype>aves</itype>, <sense id="n894.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the birds which permitted</hi> (admittebant) <hi rend="ital">to do that in reference to which they were consulted</hi>, acc. to Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=21" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 21</bibl> Müll.; cf. admitto, II. B.</sense></entryFree>
admissor: <entryFree id="n895" type="main" key="admissor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admissor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>admitto</etym>, <sense id="n895.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one that allows himself to do a thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a perpetrator</hi> (late Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> Epit. 63</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:Cic. Div. 7:3" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> Cic. Div. 7, 3</bibl>; cf. admitto, II. C.</sense></entryFree>
admissum: <entryFree id="n896" type="main" key="admissum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admissum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n896.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a wrong done</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a trespass</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fault</hi>, <hi rend="ital">crime</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">judicia, quae etiam nullo admisso consequi possent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,038:chapter=35" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Part. Or. 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tale admissum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de admissis Poppeae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 4</bibl></cit>; cf. admitto, II. C.</sense></entryFree>
admissura: <entryFree id="n897" type="main" key="admissu_ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admissūra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n897.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the admitting of a male to a female</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 1 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:ib. 2:4:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 4, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:24:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 24, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:164" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 42, 66, § 164</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:5:2:24" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 5, 2, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:30:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 30, 42</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
admissus: <entryFree id="n898" type="main" key="admissus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admissus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of admitto.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n899" type="main" key="admissus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admissus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>admitto</etym>. <sense id="n899.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A letting in</hi> or <hi rend="ital">admission</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">solis admissu,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 4, 9, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">6, 2, 2</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n899.1" n="II" level="1"> = admissura, <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> Veg. 4, 7, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
admistio: <entryFree id="n900" type="main" key="admisti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admistĭo</orth> (better <orth extent="full" lang="la">admixt-</orth>, q. v.), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>admisceo</etym>, <sense id="n900.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mixture</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">olei admistione conspersus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:7:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Lev. 7, 12</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
admistus: <entryFree id="n901" type="main" key="admistus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admistus</orth>, v. admixtus.</entryFree>
admitto: <entryFree id="n902" type="main" key="admitto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-mitto</orth>, <itype>mīsi, missum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (admĭsse <sense id="n902.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sync.</hi> for admisisse, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 7, 4</bibl>: admittier <hi rend="ital">arch.</hi> for admitti, as <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:231" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 231</bibl>), orig. <hi rend="ital">to send to;</hi> hence with the access. idea of leave, permission (cf.: aditus, accessus), <hi rend="ital">to suffer to come</hi> or <hi rend="ital">go to</hi> a place, <hi rend="ital">to admit.</hi>—Constr. with <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <case>acc.</case> (<hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <case>abl.</case> is rare and doubtful), <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, or <case>dat.</case> (class.). </sense><sense id="n902.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n902.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">ad eam non admissa sum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:2:1:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 2, 1, 41</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so Eun. 2, 2, 50: quam multis custodibus opus erit, si te semel ad meas capsas admisero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,004:chapter=16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Div. in Caecil. 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in cubiculum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:8:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 8, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lucem in thalamos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:807" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 3, 807</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">domum ad se filium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Tim. 1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Tim. 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plebem ad campestres exercitationes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:10" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem per fenestram,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> Sat. 79</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:605" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 3, 605</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">admissis intra moenia hostibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1:1" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 1, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n902.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n902.4" n="1" level="3"> Of those who admitted one on account of some business; and under the emperors, for the purpose of salutation, <hi rend="ital">to allow one admittance</hi> or <hi rend="ital">access</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to grant an audience</hi> (the t. t. for this; v. admissio, admissionalis; <cit><quote lang="la">opp. excludere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 4, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:48" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 48</bibl>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Schwarz ad h. 1. 47, 3): nec quemquam admisit,</quote> <trans><tr>admitted no one to his presence</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">domus clari hominis, in quam admittenda hominum cujusque modi multitudo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:39" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 39</bibl></cit>: Casino salutatum veniebant; <cit><quote lang="la">admissus est nemo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:41:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 41, 105</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,009:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Con. 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Dat. 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:79" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 79</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">spectatum admissi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admittier orant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:231" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 231</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">turpius eicitur quam non admittitur hospes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:6:13" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 6, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vetuit ad eum quemquam admitti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:1:25" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 1, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">promiscuis salutationibus admittebat et plebem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:52" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 52</bibl></cit>.—Metaph.: <cit><quote lang="la">ante fores stantem dubitas admittere Famam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:1:25" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 1, 25</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n902.5" n="2" level="3"> Of a harlot: <cit><quote lang="la">ne quemquam interea alium admittat prorsus quam me ad se virum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:3:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 1, 3, 83</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:20:7" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 20, 7</bibl>.—Also of the breeding of animals, <hi rend="ital">to put the male to the female</hi> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">admissarius, admissura, admissus),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:9:22" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 9, 22</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:3:10:3" default="NO">3, 10, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:43:68 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 43, 68 al.</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:63:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 10, 63, 83</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:10" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 1, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:37" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 37</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:7:2" default="NO">7, 2</bibl>.—Also used of the female of animals, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:7" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 7</bibl>, and <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 69, 85</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n902.6" n="3" level="3"> Admittere aliquem ad consilium, <hi rend="ital">to admit one to counsel</hi> or <hi rend="ital">consultation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec ad consilium casus admittitur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Marc. 2, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">horum in numerum nemo admittebatur nisi qui, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,006:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Lys. 1</bibl></cit> Halm.—Hence: <cit><quote lang="la">admittere aliquem ad honores, ad officium,</quote> <trans><tr>to admit him to</tr>, <tr>to confer on</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:41" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:34:16" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 34, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Herc. Oet. 335" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Herc. Oet. 335</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n902.7" n="4" level="3"> Of a horse, <hi rend="ital">to let go</hi> or <hi rend="ital">run</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to give loose reins to</hi> (cf.: remittere, immittere, less emphatic than <hi rend="ital">concitare;</hi> usu. in the <hi rend="ital">part. perf.</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">admisso equo in mediam aciem irruere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:19:61" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 19, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">equites admissis equis ad suos refugerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Considius equo admisso ad eum accurrit,</quote> <trans><tr>came at full speed</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. G. 1, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in Postumium equum infestus admisit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 19</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:1:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 1, 36</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:237" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 6, 237</bibl>.—Hence of the hair, <hi rend="ital">to let it flow loosely</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">admissae jubae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:2:16:50 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 2, 16, 50 al.</bibl></cit> <pb n="41" /> <cb n="ADMO" /></sense><sense id="n902.8" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n902.9" n="A" level="2"> Of words, entreaties, etc., <hi rend="ital">to permit a thing to come</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to give access</hi> or <hi rend="ital">grant admittance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to receive</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pacis mentionem admittere auribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 49</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so 30, 3: nihil quod salutare esset, ad aurĭs admittebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 25, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo facilius aures judicum, quae post dicturi erimus, admittant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:3:10" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 4, 3, 10</bibl></cit>.—Hence also <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">admittere precationem,</quote> <trans><tr>to hear</tr>, <tr>to grant</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 5</bibl></cit> Gron.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:4:698" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 4, 698</bibl>: tunc admitte jocos, <hi rend="ital">give admittance to jesting</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">allow it</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:4:8" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 4, 8</bibl>.—So also: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid ad animum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cogitationem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> 6, 13, 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n902.10" n="B" level="2"> Of an act, event, etc., <hi rend="ital">to let it be done</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to allow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">permit</hi> (“fieri pati,” Don. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:6:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 6, 23</bibl>).—With <case>acc.</case> of thing: <cit><quote lang="la">sed tu quod cavere possis stultum admittere est, Ter. l. c.: quod semel admissum coërceri non potest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:1:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non admittere litem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=116" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 116</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aspicere ecquid jam mare admitteret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:6:16:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 6, 16, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non admittere illicita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,024:6:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Macc. 6, 20</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">subj. clause</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hosti non admissuro, quo minus aggrederetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 40</bibl></cit>.—With <case>acc.</case> and <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">non admisit quemquam se sequi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,002:5:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Marc. 5, 37</bibl></cit>; so <case>acc.</case> of person alone: <cit><quote lang="la">non admisit eum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 5, 19</bibl></cit>.—Hence, in the language of soothsayers, t. t. of birds which give a favorable omen, = addīco, <hi rend="ital">to be propitious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to favor</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">inpetritum, inauguratum'st, quovis admittunt aves,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 1, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi aves non admisissent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:36:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 36, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:18 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 18 al.</bibl> (hence: ADMISSIVAE: aves, in Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=21" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 21</bibl>. Müll.).—</sense><sense id="n902.11" n="C" level="2"> Of an unlawful act, design, etc., <hi rend="ital">to grant admittance to one's self;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">become guiliy of</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to perpetrate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to commit</hi> (it thus expresses rather the moral liability incurred freely; while <hi rend="ital">committere</hi> designates the overt act, punishable by civil law, Herz. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 9</bibl>; freq. and class.), often with a reflexive pron., in me, etc. (<case>acc.</case>): <cit><quote lang="la">me hoc delictum admisisse in me, vehementer dolet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:5:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 5, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ea in te admisisti quae, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:19:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 19, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tu nihil admittes in te formidine poenae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 16, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admittere in se culpam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 61</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:1:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 2, 1, 40</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">scelera, quae in se admiserit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,001:27:5" default="NO"><author>Lucil.</author> 27, 5</bibl></cit> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">quid umquam Habitus in se admisit, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:60:167" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 60, 167</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quantum in se facinus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 9</bibl></cit>.—And without such reflexive pron.: <cit><quote lang="la">cum multos multa admĭsse acceperim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 7, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid ego tantum sceleris admisi miser?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:2:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 5, 2, 83</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">si Milo admisisset aliquid, quod, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 23 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dedecus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 1, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">commissum facinus et admissum dedecus confitebor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:10:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 10, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tantum dedecus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quod facinus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">flagitium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 128</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fraudem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rab. 126</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">maleficium,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sext. Rosc. 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">scelus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,015:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ep. 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facinus miserabile,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 53:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 53, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pessimum facinus pejore exemplo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:72:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 72, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tantum dedccoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 2</bibl></cit>; so 2, 37; 3, 59 al.</sense></entryFree>
admixtio: <entryFree id="n903" type="main" key="admixti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admixtĭo</orth> (better than <orth extent="full" lang="la">admist-</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>admisceo</etym>, <sense id="n903.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mingling;</hi> in concreto, <hi rend="ital">an admixture</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">animus omni admixtione corporis liberatus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Sen. 22, 79</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">terreni,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 1, 5, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ardor nulla admixtione concretus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:45:117" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 45, 117</bibl></cit>.—In <number>plur.</number>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:9:2 al" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 9, 2 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
admixtus: <entryFree id="n904" type="main" key="admixtus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admixtus</orth> (better than <orth extent="full" lang="la">admist-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, from admisceo.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n905" type="hapax" key="admixtus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admixtus</orth> (better than <orth extent="full" lang="la">admist-</orth>), <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>admisceo</etym>, = admixtio, <sense id="n905.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mingling;</hi> in concreto, <hi rend="ital">an admixture</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nullo admixtu voluptatis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 2, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
admoderate: <entryFree id="n906" type="main" key="admo^de^ra_te_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admŏdĕrātē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. admoderor.</entryFree>
admoderor: <entryFree id="n907" type="hapax" key="admo^de^ror"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-mŏdĕror</orth>, <itype>āri, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos>, <sense id="n907.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to keep to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">within due limits</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to moderate</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nequeo hercle equidem risu admoderarier,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:4:2:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 4, 2, 81</bibl></cit>.—Hence, * <orth extent="full" lang="la">admŏdĕrātē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">fitly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">suitably</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">humanis rationibus admoderate tempora mutare annorum,</quote> <trans><tr>in conformity with the ways of men</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:169" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 169</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
admodulor: <entryFree id="n908" type="hapax" key="admo^du^lor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-mŏdŭlor</orth>, <itype>āri, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos>, in music, <sense id="n908.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to accord</hi> or <hi rend="ital">harmonize with</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Padus electriferis admoduletur alnis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Nupt. Hon. 11</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
admodum: <entryFree id="n909" type="main" key="admo^dum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-mŏdum</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>modus</etym>, prop., <sense id="n909.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to the measure</hi> or <hi rend="ital">limit</hi> (scarcely found in the poets, except the comic poets); <cit><quote lang="la">as, postea ubi occipiet fervere, paulisper demittito, usque admodum dum quinquies quinque numeres,</quote> <trans><tr>quite to the limit till you count</tr>, <tr>until you count</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 156, 2</bibl></cit> (like fere and omnino, freq. put after its word).— <cb n="ADMO" /> Hence, </sense><sense id="n909.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To a</hi> (great) <hi rend="ital">measure</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in a high degree</hi>, <hi rend="ital">much</hi>, <hi rend="ital">very.</hi>—With <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">P. adj.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vbs.</hi>, and <pos>adv.</pos> </sense><sense id="n909.2" n="(a)" level="5"> With <pos>adj.</pos>: <cit><quote lang="la">admodum causam gravem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,001:29:19" default="NO"><author>Lucil.</author> 29, 19</bibl></cit> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">admodum antiqui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:5:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 5, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admodum amplum et excelsum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 4, 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">utrique nostrum gratum admodum feceris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:4:16" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 4, 16</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec admodum in virum honorificum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:34:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 34, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in quo multum admodum fortunae datur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:5:12" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 5, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque admodum sunt multi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,021:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Reg. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admodum magnis itineribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admodum pauci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:3:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 3, 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">14, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:69" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 3, 69</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pauci admodum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">iter angustum admodum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 92</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admodum nimia ubertas,</quote> <trans><tr>very excessive</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:21" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 4, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admodum dives,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:1" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">brevis admodum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 56</bibl></cit>.—And strengthened by <hi rend="ital">quam</hi>, q. v. (only before and after the class. per.): <cit><quote lang="la">hic admodum quam saevus est,</quote> <trans><tr>very cruel indeed</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:3:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 3, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">voce admodum quam suavi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:9" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 9</bibl></cit> (on this use of quam, cf. Rudd. II. p. 307, <gen>n.</gen> 15).— </sense><sense id="n909.3" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">part. adj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">admodum iratum senem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:3:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 3, 1, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">iratum admodum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:3:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 3, 3, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">natio admodum dedita religionibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">prorae admodum erectae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admodum mitigati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">munitus admodum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 80</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admodum fuit militum virtus laudanda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 8</bibl></cit>.—Esp. is it joined (like <foreign lang="greek">komidh=|</foreign> in Dem.) with words denoting age; as, puer, adulescens, juvenis, senex, to enhance the idea (for which in some cases the <lbl>dim.</lbl> or the prefix <hi rend="ital">per-</hi> is used; <cit><quote lang="la">as, puellus, adulescentulus, peradulescentulus): Catulus admodum tum adulescens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,012:7:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. Perd. 7, 21</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:13:47" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 13, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">puer admodum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Brev. Vit. 7:3" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Brev. Vit. 7, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:6:1" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 6, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">admodum infans,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">juvenis admodum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 4, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fratres admodum juvenes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:2:12" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 7, 2, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admodum senex,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Eutr.</author> 8, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admodum parvulus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:17:3" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 17, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non admodum grandem natu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:4:10" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 4, 10</bibl></cit>.— Also with <hi rend="ital">dim.</hi>: neque admodum adulescentulus est, Naev. ap. Sergium ad Don. Keil, Gr. Lat. IV. p. 559 (R<bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Com. Fragm. p. 11</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">hic admodum adulescentulus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:2:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 2, 90</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,022:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ham. 1, 1</bibl> (cf. peradulescentulus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eum. 1, 4</bibl>), and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 44</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n909.4" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">verbs</hi> (in earlier Latin, mostly with delectare, diligere, placere): haec anus admodum frigultit, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Fulg.</author> p. 175</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">irridere ne videare et gestire admodum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:2:125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 3, 2, 125</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque admodum a pueris abscessit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0112,001:Rib. Com. Fragm. p. 11" default="NO"><author>Naev.</author> Rib. Com. Fragm. p. 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">me superiores litterae tuae admodum delectaverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 7, 24</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ejus familiarissimos, qui me admodum diligunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 4, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">stomacho admodum prodest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 3, 7, § 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bucinum pelagio admodum adligatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:134" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 9, 38, 62, § 134</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(familia) ipsa admodum floruit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:3" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Marius auctis admodum copiis ... vicit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1:36:13" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 1, 36, 13</bibl></cit> Halm.— </sense><sense id="n909.5" n="(d)" level="5"> With <pos>adv.</pos>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec inter nos nuper notitia admodum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: si quando demersimus, aut nihil superum aut obscure admodum cernimus, Cic. Ac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 7, 57</bibl>: acipenser, qui admodum raro capitur, id. de Fato ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 2, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">raro admodum admonitu amicorum ... uti solebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:13:25" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 13, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi satis admodum suorum animos est expertus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:13:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 13, 4</bibl></cit> Weissenb. (Hertz cancels <hi rend="ital">satis</hi>): quae maxime admodum oratori accommodata est, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 12, 17</bibl> (Oudendorp regarded this as a mere pleonasm, and Hand seems to agree with him; Klotz and B. and K. adopt after Goerenz the reading <hi rend="ital">maxime ad modum oratoris</hi>, but Hand condemned this form).—</sense><sense id="n909.6" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To a</hi> (full) <hi rend="ital">measure</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fully</hi>, <hi rend="ital">completely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wholly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">quite</hi>, <hi rend="ital">absolutely.</hi> </sense><sense id="n909.7" n="A" level="2"> Of number (not used in this way by Cic., Tac., or Suet.): noctu turres admodum CXX. excitantur, <hi rend="ital">full</hi> 120, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 40</bibl>: sex milia hostium caesa; <cit><quote lang="la">quinque admodum Romanorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 24</bibl></cit>. 14; 42, 65, 3; <cit><quote lang="la">44, 43, 8: mille admodum hostium utràque pugnā occidit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:30:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 27, 30, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in laevo cornu Bactriani ibant equites, mille admodum,</quote> <trans><tr>a round thousand</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:12:3" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 12, 3</bibl></cit>: mille admodum equites praemiserat, quorum paucitate Alexander, etc., <hi rend="ital">a thousand</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but not more</hi> (as the context requires), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:9:24" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 4, 9, 24</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">congregati admodum quingenti sponsos hostes consectantur, trucidatisque admodum novem milibus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:24:1" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 24, 1</bibl></cit>. <cb n="ADMO" />!*? The meaning, circiter, fere, <hi rend="ital">about</hi>, <hi rend="ital">near</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">nearly</hi>, which used to be assigned to this head, as by Graevius ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:24:26" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 24, 26</bibl>, Gronovius ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:30:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 30, 2</bibl>, is rejected by recent scholars, as Hand, Turs. I. p. 175 sq., and by Corradini, Lex. Lat. s. h. v.</sense><sense id="n909.8" n="B" level="2"> Of time: <cit><quote lang="la">legati ex Macedonia exacto admodum mense Februario redierunt,</quote> <trans><tr>when February was fully ended</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:43:11:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 43, 11, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Alexandri filius, rex Syriae, decem annos admodum habens,</quote> <trans><tr>just ten years</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Epit. 55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> Epit. 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">post menses admodum septem occiditur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:17:2:3" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 17, 2, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n909.9" n="C" level="2"> With negatives, <hi rend="ital">just</hi>, <hi rend="ital">at all</hi>, <hi rend="ital">absolutely</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">equestris pugna nulla admodum fuit,</quote> <trans><tr>no engagement with the cavalry at all</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:29:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 23, 29, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">armorum magnam vim transtulit, nullam pecuniam admodum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:59:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 40, 59, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">horunc illa nibilum quidquam facere poterit admodum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:3:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 2, 3, 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Curio litterarum admodum nihil sciebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:58:210" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 58, 210</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oratorem plane quidem perfectum et cui nihil admodum desit, Demosthenem facile dixeris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 9, 35</bibl></cit>: alter non multum, alter nihil admodum scripti reliquit (by the latter is meant Antonius, who indeed, acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Brut.</author> 44, 163</bibl>, left a treatise <hi rend="ital">de ratione dicendi</hi>, but <hi rend="ital">no written oration at all</hi>, by which his eloquence could be judged), <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 38, 132</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Clu. 50, 140</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 2, 2, 8</bibl>; <foreign lang="greek">eirwneia</foreign> a tropo genere ipso nihil admodum distat, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:2:44" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 2, 44</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">quia nihil admodum super vite aut arbore colenda sciret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:12" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 12</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n909.10" n="D" level="2"> In emphatic affirmative or corroborative answers, = maxime (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">pa/nu ge</foreign>), <hi rend="ital">exactly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">just so</hi>, <hi rend="ital">quite so</hi>, <hi rend="ital">certainly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">yes</hi> (freq. in Plaut., only twice in Ter.); cf. the remark of Cic.: scis solere, frater, in hujusmodi sermone, ut transiri alio possit, dici <hi rend="ital">Admodum</hi> aut <hi rend="ital">Prorsus ita est</hi>, Leg. 3, 11, 26: nempe tu hanc dicis, quam esse aiebas dudum popularem meam. <hi rend="ital">Tr.</hi> Admodum, <hi rend="ital">Certainly</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:4:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 4, 4, 36</bibl>: num quidnam ad filium haec aegritudo attinet? <hi rend="ital">Ni.</hi> Admodum, <hi rend="ital">It does</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 5, 1, 24</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 1, 40</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:1:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 1, 5, 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 2, 55</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 6, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:7:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 4, 7, 54</bibl>: Advenis modo? <hi rend="ital">Pa.</hi> Admodum, <hi rend="ital">Yes</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:5:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 5, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 2, 2, 1</bibl>.!*? Admodum with an <pos>adj.</pos> may have the same force as in II., in: <cit><quote lang="la">quandam formam ingenii, sed admodum impolitam et plane rudem,</quote> <trans><tr>absolutely without polish and altogether rude</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:85:294" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 85, 294</bibl></cit>, compared with: <cit><quote lang="la">(oratorem) plane perfectum et cui nihil admodum desit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 35</bibl></cit>, where the same adverbs occur.</sense></entryFree>
admoenio: <entryFree id="n910" type="hapax" key="admoeni^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-moenĭo</orth>, <itype>īre, 4</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n910.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to draw near the walls</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to besiege</hi>, <hi rend="ital">invest</hi>: oppidum. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:3:150" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 3, 150</bibl> (but not <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1, 11</bibl>; cf. Ritschl ad h. l.; and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:2:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cist. 2, 2, 5</bibl>, for admoenivi, <hi rend="ital">admovi</hi> is a more correct reading; v. admoveo).</sense></entryFree>
admolior: <entryFree id="n911" type="main" key="admo_li^or"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-mōlĭor</orth>, <itype>ītus, 4</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos>, <sense id="n911.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to move</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bring</hi> one thing <hi rend="ital">to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">upon</hi> another (not in Cic.). </sense><sense id="n911.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi sacro manus sis admolitus,</quote> <trans><tr>put the hand to</tr>, <tr>lay hands on</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:2:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 3, 2, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">manus moli,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 6, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dejerantes sese neque ei manus admolituros, i. e. vim illaturos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Flor. 1, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">velut de industria rupes praealtas admolita natura est,</quote> <trans><tr>has piled up</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:10:24" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 10, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">imagini regis manus admolitus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Flor. p. 344, 14</bibl></cit> Elm.—</sense><sense id="n911.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. as a mid. voice, <hi rend="ital">to exert one's self to reach</hi> a place, <hi rend="ital">to strive</hi> or <hi rend="ital">struggle toward</hi> a place: <cit><quote lang="la">ad hirundinum nidum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:3:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 3, 1, 6</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
admonefacio: <entryFree id="n912" type="main" key="admo^ne^fa^ci^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admŏnĕ-făcĭo</orth>, <itype>ĕre, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>admoneo</etym>, <sense id="n912.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to admonish</hi>, dub. in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:34:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 34, 85</bibl>, where B. and K. read <hi rend="ital">admoneo;</hi> cf. also Wunder ad h. l.: in the Gloss. Gr. Lat. it also occurs as a transl. of <foreign lang="greek">u(pomnhmati/zw</foreign>.</sense></entryFree>
admoneo: <entryFree id="n913" type="main" key="admo^ne^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-mŏnĕo</orth>, <itype>ui, ĭtum, 2</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n913.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to bring up to one's mind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to put one in mind of</hi> (<hi rend="ital">in a friendly manner</hi>), <hi rend="ital">to remind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">suggest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">advise</hi>, <hi rend="ital">warn</hi>, <hi rend="ital">admonish</hi> (by influencing more directly the reason and judgment; while in <hi rend="ital">adhortor</hi> the admonition is addressed immediately to the will, Doed. Syn. 1, 164: “Moneo, et admoneo hoc differunt, quod <hi rend="ital">monemus</hi> futura, <hi rend="ital">admonemus</hi> praeterita; illa ut caveamus et discamus, haec ut recordemur,” <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Popma, p. 29</bibl>; cf. Ellendt ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:3:11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 3, 11</bibl>: “in monente benevolentia, in admonente memoria,” Ernest. <hi rend="ital">no.</hi> 1663). </sense><sense id="n913.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen., constr. <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> and with <hi rend="ital">aliquem alicujus rei</hi> or <hi rend="ital">de aliqua re</hi>, <hi rend="ital">aliquam rem</hi> (Sallust employs them all); with <hi rend="ital">ut</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ne.</hi> when an action follows; with <case>acc.</case> and <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> or a <hi rend="ital">rel. clause</hi>, when merely an historical<pb n="42" /> <cb n="ADMO" />  fact is brought to view, Zumpt, § 439 and 615. </sense><sense id="n913.2" n="(a)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui admonent amice, docendi sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amicissime admonere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 7, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si sitis admoneret, profluente aquā vitam tolerat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 45 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admonitus in somnis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 2, 22</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n913.3" n="(b)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Aliquem alicujus rei</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">admonebat alium egestatis, alium cupiditatis suae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quoniam nos tanti viri res admonuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> J. 95</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admonere aliquem foederis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:51" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 51</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">judices legum et religionis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:33" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admonitus hujus aeris alieni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:1:5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aetatis et condicionis admoneri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:2" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Dom. 2</bibl></cit>; cf. Drak. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:36:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 36, 6</bibl>.—And with <case>acc.</case> of person omitted: <cit><quote lang="la">adversae res admonuerunt religionum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 51</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:46:6" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 46, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">veterum recentiumque admonens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 24</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n913.4" n="(g)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Aliquem de aliqua re</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">de aede Telluris et de porticu Catuli me admones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut aliquid aliquando de doctrinae studiis admoneamur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 1, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">de moribus civitatis tempus admonuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admonuit eos de auxiliis Dei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,024:8:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Macc. 8, 19</bibl></cit>.—Sometimes in passing from a subject already discussed to a new one, = docere, dicere, <hi rend="ital">to treat of</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to speak of</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">de multitudine (verborum) quoniam quod satis esset admonui, de obscuritate pauca dicam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=40" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 40</bibl></cit> Müll.—</sense><sense id="n913.5" n="(d)" level="5"> With two <case>acc.</case> (in gen., only with illud, istuc, quod, multa, res, etc.): <cit><quote lang="la">ridiculum est te istuc me admonere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 112</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illud te esse admonitum volo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cael. 3, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam illud non sunt admonendi, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:19:68" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 19, 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illud me praeclare admones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 9, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sin quippiam essem admonitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 5, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multa praeterea ostentis, multa extis admonemur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:66" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 66</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eam rem nos locus admonuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 79</bibl></cit>.— (<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With <case>acc.</case> and <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">admonuisti etiam dictum aliquod in petitionem tuam dici potuisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:34:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 34, 85</bibl></cit> B. and K.: <cit><quote lang="la">et meminerant et admonebant alii alios, supplicium ex se, non victoriam peti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 19</bibl></cit>: nostri detrimento admonentur diligentius stationes disponere, Auct. B. G. 8, 12.—（<foreign lang="greek">z</foreign>) With a <hi rend="ital">rel. clause</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">meus me sensus, quanta vis fraterni sit amoris, admonet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 2</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">h</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">ut</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ne</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">admonebat me res, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:19:67" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 19, 67</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Caninius noster me tuis verbis admonuit, ut scriberem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ea res admonet, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 25</bibl></cit>;
