so, <cit><quote lang="la">corresp. with moneo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 24:16" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 24, 16</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">q</foreign>) With the simple <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi> (in the historians): <cit><quote lang="la">simulque admonerent liberis suis prospiceret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Ph. 1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ph. 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nisi Seneca admonuisset venienti matri occurreret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admonuit negotiis abstineret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:50" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illud me admones, cum illum videro, ne nimis indulgenter, et cum gravitate potius loquar,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:9:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 9, 2</bibl></cit> (where <hi rend="ital">ut</hi> is to be supplied from the preceding <hi rend="ital">ne</hi>).—（<foreign lang="greek">i</foreign>) With a simple <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi> (so most freq. after the Aug. per., but also in Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">ut mos erat istius atque ut eum suae libidines facere admonebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:24:section=63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 24, § 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">easdem decedere campis admonuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:186" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 186</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">Matrem Admonuit ratibus sacris depellere taedas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:109" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 9, 109</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sol acrior ire lavatum admonuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:6:125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 6, 125</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:601" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 601</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">6, 150</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil agere quod non prosit, fabella admonet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:3:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 3, 17</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 67</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">regrediendum (sc. esse sibi),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 25</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">k</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> and the <hi rend="ital">gerund.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad thesaurum reperiendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:65:134" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 65, 134</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">l</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">abl. of means</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cause</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">de quibus (discordiis) ipsis his prodigiis a dis immortalibus admonemur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,021:21:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Har. Resp. 21, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">proximi diei casu admoniti omnia ad defensionem paraverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">divinā admonitus plagā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,024:9:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Macc. 9, 11</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n913.6" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n913.7" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To recall a thing to memory</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to bring to remembrance</hi> (without any accessory notion of admonition); with <case>acc.</case> or <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum memor anteactos semper dolor admonet annos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:4:1:189" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 4, 1, 189</bibl></cit> Müll. (some read here <hi rend="ital">admovet</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">admonuit dominae deseruitque Venus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:5:40" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 1, 5, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nomen, quod possit equorum Admonuisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:543" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 543</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n913.8" n="B" level="2"> Of a creditor, <hi rend="ital">to remind</hi> a debtor of his debt, <hi rend="ital">to ask payment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to dun</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum tibi cotidie potestas hominis fuisset admonendi, verbum nullum facis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 12</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:chapter=1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Top. 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>—</sense><sense id="n913.9" n="C" level="2"> In the poets and in later Lat., <hi rend="ital">to urge</hi> or <hi rend="ital">incite to action</hi> (cf. admonitor): <cit><quote lang="la">telo admonuit bijugos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:586" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 586</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>Spart.</author> Sever. 11 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">liberos verberibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Clem. 1:14" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Clem. 1, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Const. Sap. 12" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Const. Sap. 12 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl> <cb n="ADMO" /></sense></entryFree>
admonitio: <entryFree id="n914" type="main" key="admo^ni^ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admŏnĭtĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>admoneo</etym>. <sense id="n914.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A reminding</hi>, <hi rend="ital">recalling to mind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">suggestion</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">illud ne indignuin quidem admonitione, ingens in epilogis verti discrimen,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 6, 1, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tanta vis admonitionis inest in locis, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 5, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qua admonitione succurrit quod Varro tradit, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 1, 2, § 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">unius admonitione verbi in memoriam reponuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:2:19" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 2, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">unius admonitione verbi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:1:37" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 1, 37</bibl></cit>.—Hence, transf.: admonitio morbi, or doloris, <hi rend="ital">the returning sensations of a former sickness</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si qua admonitio doloris supersit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:88" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 8, 49, § 88</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admonitionem morbi sentire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:158" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 24, 17, 101, § 158</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n914.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A friendly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mild admonition</hi> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 83</bibl>: admonitio, quasi lenior objurgatio; <cit><quote lang="la">v. admoneo, 1.): admonitio et praeceptum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 40 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 70</bibl>: si aliter sentirem certe admonitio tua me reprimere aut si dubitarem, hortatio impellere posset, Planc. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 4</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n914.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Correction</hi>, <hi rend="ital">chastise ment</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">plures admonitione notavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:39" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admonitio fustium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:48:19:7" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 48, 19, 7</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
admonitor: <entryFree id="n915" type="main" key="admo^ni^tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admŏnĭtor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>. <sense id="n915.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">He that reminds</hi> or <hi rend="ital">admonishes</hi> one of something, <hi rend="ital">a monitor</hi>: misi ad te quattuor admonitores non nimis verecundos. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 8</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:chapter=1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Top. 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>—</sense><sense id="n915.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">One that urges to action</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an admonisher</hi> (cf. admoneo, II. C.): <cit><quote lang="la">admonitorque operum caelo clarissimus alto Luclfer ortus erat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:664" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 664</bibl></cit>: admonitor praecepti, Cod. Th. 8, 8, 7.</sense></entryFree>
admonitorium: <entryFree id="n916" type="hapax" key="admo^ni^to_ri^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admŏnĭtōrĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n916.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an admonition</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a reminding</hi>, Dig. Ep. ad Trib, 12.</sense></entryFree>
admonitrix: <entryFree id="n917" type="hapax" key="admo^ni^trix"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admŏnĭtrix</orth>, <itype>īcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n917.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">she that reminds</hi> or <hi rend="ital">admonishes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a female monitor</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid adhuc egeo tui, malum, admonitricis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:6:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 6, 20</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
admonitum: <entryFree id="n918" type="hapax" key="admo^ni^tum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admŏnĭtum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n918.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a reminding</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an admonition</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cohortationes, consolationes, praecepta, admonita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:15:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 15, 64</bibl></cit> B. and K; where others read <hi rend="ital">monita.</hi></sense></entryFree>
admonitus: <entryFree id="n919" type="main" key="admo^ni^tus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admŏnĭtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of admoneo.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n920" type="main" key="admo^ni^tus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admŏnĭtus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>admoneo</etym>, used only in the <case>abl.</case> <sense id="n920.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A reminding</hi>, <hi rend="ital">suggestion</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">acrius de claris viris locorum admonitu cogitamus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:2" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> R. A. 729</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">admonitu Allobrogum praetorem misi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:3:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 3, 3, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:612" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 3, 612</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 92</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 48</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:13:25" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 13, 25</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 81</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n920.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Instance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">request</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">admonitu tuo perfeci libros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut Attici admonitu eam reficiendam curaret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 48</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n920.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Reproof</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">acrior admonitu est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:564" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 564</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
admordeo: <entryFree id="n921" type="main" key="admorde^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-mordĕo</orth>, <itype>rsum, 2</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (<sense id="n921.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">perf.</hi> admemordi, Plaut. Aul. Fragm. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:6:9:6" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 6, 9, 6</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">to bite at</hi> or <hi rend="ital">gnaw</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to bite into</hi> (cf. accīdo, to cut into). </sense><sense id="n921.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">admorso signata in stirpe cicatrix,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:379" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 379</bibl></cit>.—So of Cleopatra: <cit><quote lang="la">bracchia admorsa colubris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:10:53" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 10, 53</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n921.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig., of a miser, <hi rend="ital">to bite</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">get possession of some of</hi> one's property, to fleece him: <cit><quote lang="la">lepidum est, triparcos, vetulos bene admordere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:2:3:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 2, 3, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam admordere hunc mihi lubet, i. e. aggredi et ab eo aliquid corradere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:7:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 4, 7, 24</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
admorsus: <entryFree id="n922" type="main" key="admorsus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admorsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of admordeo.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n923" type="hapax" key="admorsus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admorsus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>admordeo</etym>, <sense id="n923.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a biting at</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a gnawing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a bite;</hi> trop.: <cit><quote lang="la">vereor ne libellus iste admorsu duri dentis uratur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Ep. 1:15" default="NO"><author>Symm.</author> Ep. 1, 15</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
admotio: <entryFree id="n924" type="main" key="admo_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admōtĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>admoveo</etym>, <sense id="n924.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a putting</hi>, <hi rend="ital">moving</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">bringing to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an applying;</hi> in music: digitorum, <hi rend="ital">the application of the fingers</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">itaque ad pingendum, ad scalpendum, ad nervorum eliciendos sonos apta manus est admotione digitorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:60:150" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 60, 150</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">animis judicum admovere orationem tamquam fidibus manum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:54:200" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 54, 200</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spongiarum cum aqua frigida expressarum admotio gutturi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2305,001:Tard. 2:6" default="NO"><author>Cael. Aur.</author> Tard. 2, 6</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
admotus: <entryFree id="n925" type="main" key="admo_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admōtus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of admoveo.</entryFree>
admoveo: <entryFree id="n926" type="main" key="admo^ve^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-mŏvĕo</orth>, <itype>mōvi, mōtum, 2</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (admōram, admōrim, etc., sync. for admoveram, admoverim, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:367" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 367</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:3:7:36" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 3, 7, 36</bibl>), <sense id="n926.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to move</hi> a person or thing; <hi rend="ital">to bring</hi>, <hi rend="ital">conduct</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lead</hi>, <hi rend="ital">carry</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">toward</hi> a place (syn.: adduco, adicio, adhibeo, appello). </sense><sense id="n926.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n926.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen., constr. with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> or with <case>dat.</case> (in the histt., of an army, implements for besieging, etc.; class. at all periods): dum ne exercitum propius urbem<cb n="ADMU" />  Romam CC milia admoveret, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:6:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 6, 3, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">copias in locum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">signa Achradinae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 25, 24</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">ext.;</hi> so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1:24:3:23" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 1, 24, 3, 23</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">castra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:1:296" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 1, 296</bibl></cit>.—Hence, also, sometimes <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to draw near</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to approach</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to bring near</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam admovebat rex,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:9:4" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 9, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam opera admoventi deditio est facta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 32, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">scalas moenibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 39</bibl></cit>. —<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">quot admovi illi fabricas! quot fallacias!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:2:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 2, 2, 5</bibl></cit> (where formerly <hi rend="ital">admoenivi</hi> was erroneously read): <cit><quote lang="la">tamquam aliquā machinā admotā, capere Asinii adulescentiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 13</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so also: ignes ardentesque laminae ceterique cruciatus admovebantur (sc. civi Romano),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dolorum faces,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:10:37" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 10, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cumque quasi faces ei doloris admoverentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:25:61" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 25, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fasciculum ad nares,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 18</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecus flagrantibus aris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:171" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 171</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admotae hostiae (sc. aris),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 69</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:32" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:7:165" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 7, 165</bibl>: Hannibalem admotum, i. e. adductum altaribus, <hi rend="ital">led</hi> or <hi rend="ital">conducted to</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">labra poculis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:3:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 3, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignes templis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:3:5:11" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 3, 5, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exercitum Ariminum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vultum ad auditores,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 3, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animam admotis fugientem sustinet herbis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:188" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 188</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(opes) Stygiis admoverat umbris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:1:139" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 139</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">manus operi,</quote> <trans><tr>to apply</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:10:254" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 254</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">capiti diadema,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:79" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">digitum scripturae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:80" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Aug. 80</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oscula,</quote> <trans><tr>to give a kiss</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:644" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 644</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem ad munera publica,</quote> <trans><tr>to promote</tr>, <tr>advance</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:10" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">infantes papillae,</quote> <trans><tr>to put to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:44 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tib. 44 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gressum,</quote> <trans><tr>to approach nearer</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:11:560" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 11, 560</bibl></cit> (cf.: addere gressum).—</sense><sense id="n926.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n926.4" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To bring one thing near to another</hi>, and in the <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi> <usg type="style">poet.</usg> of places, <hi rend="ital">to lie</hi> or <hi rend="ital">be situated near</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nocturna ad lumina linum nuper ubi extinctum admoveas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:901" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 901</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae nisi admoto igne ignem concipere possit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 45 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: culina ut sit admota, i. e. <hi rend="ital">near</hi> or <hi rend="ital">close by</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:13:2" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 13, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">genus admotum Superis,</quote> <trans><tr>nearly related</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:295" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 295</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admota Nilo Africa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:149" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 10, 149</bibl></cit>.—Hence, aliquem alicui, <hi rend="ital">to bring one near another</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to make friends</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to reconcile</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mors Agrippae admovit propius Neronem Caesari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:96" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 96</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n926.5" n="2" level="3"> With the access. idea of regard to an object to be attained, <hi rend="ital">to move</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bring</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">apply a thing to;</hi> e. g. admovere aures (or aurem), <hi rend="ital">to lend an ear to</hi>: manus (or manum) operi, <hi rend="ital">to put one's hand to a work</hi>, etc.: accessi, adstiti, animam (<hi rend="ital">my breath</hi>) compressi, aurem admovi, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:6:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 5, 6, 28</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">admovere aures et subauscultando excipere voces,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 36</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">aures adhibere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:chapter=3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Arch. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praebere aures,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:3:7:25" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 3, 7, 25</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">tenere aures,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:4:10:49" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 10, 49</bibl></cit>); and aures, <usg type="style">poet.</usg> for auditores: <cit><quote lang="la">cum tibi sol tepidus plures admoverit aures,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 20, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admovent manus vectigalibus populi Rom.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 1, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:218" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 218</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:22:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 22, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in marmoribus, quibus Nicias manum admovisset,</quote> <trans><tr>which he had put his hand to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:133" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 11, 40, § 133</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:7" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ruderibus purgandis manus primus admovit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:8" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vesp. 8</bibl></cit>. But sometimes manus admovere signif., <hi rend="ital">to lay violent hands on</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to attack</hi> or <hi rend="ital">assault</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam deos ipsos admovere nocentibus manus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 11 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit> al.—</sense><sense id="n926.6" n="II" level="1"> Fig., of mental objects, <hi rend="ital">to put</hi>, <hi rend="ital">apply</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">direct to</hi> any thing: <cit><quote lang="la">quid praedicem ... quot stimulos admoverit homini,</quote> <trans><tr>put the goad to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:5:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 5, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mulier saevissima est, Cum stimulos odio pudor admovet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:328" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 10, 328</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">num admoveri possit oratio ad sensus animorum inflammandos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:14:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 14, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animis judicum admovere orationem, tamquam fidibus manum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:54:200" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 54, 200</bibl></cit>: sed alia quaedam sit ad eum admovenda curatio (just before: adhibenda oratio; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">adhibeo),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:28:61" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 4, 28, 61</bibl></cit>: mentem ad voces alicujus, <hi rend="ital">to direct to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attend to</hi>, Auct. Harusp. Resp. 10: serus enim Graecis admovit acumina chartis, <hi rend="ital">not until late did</hi> (<hi rend="ital">the Roman</hi>) <hi rend="ital">apply his wits to Greek literature</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 161</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">terrorem,</quote> <trans><tr>to strike with terror</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:41:17" default="NO" valid="yes">41, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">spes est admota,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:11:454" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 11, 454</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spes cupiditati admota occaecavit animum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:43:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 43, 10</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 27, 43</bibl>: desiderium patriae, <hi rend="ital">to instil</hi> or <hi rend="ital">infuse</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:2 al" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 2 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
admugio: <entryFree id="n927" type="main" key="admu_gi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-mūgĭo</orth>, <itype>ii, 4</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, of oxen, <sense id="n927.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to low</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bellow to</hi>: admugit femina tauro. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:279" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 1, 279</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">submissis admugit cornibus Apis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Cons. Honor. 4, 576</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rap. Pr. 3, 443</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
admulceo: <entryFree id="n928" type="hapax" key="admulce^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-mulcĕo</orth>, <itype>ēre, 2</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n928.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to stroke</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ca. ress</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nares,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 4, 12, 2</bibl></cit>. <pb n="43" /> <cb n="ADOL" /></sense></entryFree>
admurmuratio: <entryFree id="n929" type="main" key="admurmu^ra_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">admurmŭrātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>admurmuro</etym>, <sense id="n929.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a murmurong</hi>, <hi rend="ital">murmur.</hi> </sense><sense id="n929.1" n="I" level="1"> In disapprobation: <cit><quote lang="la">vestra admurmuratio facit, Quirites, ut agnoscere videamini, qui haec fecerint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:13:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 13, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Qui non admurmuratione, sed voce et clamore abjecti hominis furorem fregistis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:14:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pis. 14, 32</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:6:12:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 6, 12, 27</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 16, 41</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n929.2" n="II" level="1"> In approbation: <cit><quote lang="la">grata contionis admurmuratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:15:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 15, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">secundae admurmurationes cuncti senatūs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 1, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
admurmuro: <entryFree id="n930" type="main" key="admurmu^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-murmŭro</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n930.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to murmur with approbation</hi> or <hi rend="ital">disapprobation</hi> (cf. acclamo): <cit><quote lang="la">quam valde universi admurmurārint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">admurmurante senatu neque me invito,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:13:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 13, 2</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Impers.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum esset admurmuratum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:70:285" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 70, 285</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
admurmuror: <entryFree id="n931" type="hapax" key="admurmu^ror"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-murmŭror</orth>, <itype>ātus, āri</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> Same as preceding: <sense id="n931.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">ad hoc pauca admurmurati sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:ad Caes. Ep. 2:1" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> ad Caes. Ep. 2, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
admutilo: <entryFree id="n932" type="main" key="admu^ti^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-mŭtĭlo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n932.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to crop</hi> or <hi rend="ital">clip close</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to shave;</hi> hence, trop., <hi rend="ital">to defraud</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cheat</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fleece one of his money</hi> (only in Plaut.): <cit><quote lang="la">tu Persa's, qui me usque admutilavisti ad cutem,</quote> <trans><tr>you have shorn me to the skin</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:5:2:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 5, 2, 48</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:173" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 173</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 2, 2, 19</bibl> (cf. the simple verb, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:1:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 1, 1, 8</bibl>).</sense></entryFree>
adnascor: <entryFree id="n933" type="main" key="adnascor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adnascor</orth>, v. agnascor.</entryFree>
adnato: <entryFree id="n934" type="main" key="adnato"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adnato</orth>, v. annato.</entryFree>
adnatus: <entryFree id="n935" type="main" key="adnatus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adnatus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. agnascor.</entryFree>
adnavigo: <entryFree id="n936" type="main" key="adnavigo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adnavigo</orth>, v. annavigo.</entryFree>
adnecto: <entryFree id="n937" type="main" key="adnecto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adnecto</orth>, v. annecto.</entryFree>
adnepos: <entryFree id="n938" type="main" key="adne^pos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-nĕpos</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">atn-</orth>), <itype>ōtis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n938.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a son of the</hi> abnepos or <hi rend="ital">of the</hi> abneptis, i. e. <hi rend="ital">the grandson of a great-grandson</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">of a greatgranddaughter</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">a fourth - grandson;</hi> corresponding in the descending line to <hi rend="ital">atavus</hi> in the ascending. So in the epitaph of the emperor Commodus: DIVI NERVAE ADNEPOTI, Orell. Inscr. 887; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:10:1:section=7 al" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 38, 10, 1, § 7 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
adneptis: <entryFree id="n939" type="main" key="adneptis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-neptis</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">atn-</orth>), <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n939.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a daughter of the</hi> abnepos or <hi rend="ital">of the</hi> abneptis, i. e. <hi rend="ital">a granddaughter of a great-grandchild</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">a fourth granddaughter</hi>, antith. to the atavia, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:10:1:section=7" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 38, 10, 1, § 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adnomen: <entryFree id="n940" type="main" key="adnomen"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adnomen</orth>, <itype>adnominatio, adnosco</itype>, v. agnomen, agnominatio, agnosco.</entryFree>
adn: <entryFree id="n941" type="main" key="adn"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adn-</orth>. For all words in adn- not found here, v. under ann-.</entryFree>
adobruo: <entryFree id="n942" type="main" key="a^dobru^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-obrŭo</orth>, <itype>ĕre, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n942.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to cover up with earth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to bury</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">alte circumfodere et adobruere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:4:15:3" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 4, 15, 3</bibl></cit>; so 2, 11, 12; 5, 5, 2; 11, 2, 54 al.</sense></entryFree>
adolabilis: <entryFree id="n943" type="main" key="adolabilis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adolabilis</orth>, v. adulabilis.</entryFree>
adolatio: <entryFree id="n944" type="main" key="a^do^la_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŏlātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = adoratio, a read. in <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Apol. 25 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></entryFree>
adolefactus: <entryFree id="n945" type="gloss" key="a^do^le_factus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŏlēfactus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n945.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">set on fire</hi>, <hi rend="ital">kindled</hi>: ARBORES ADOLEFACTAE, fragm. of the Fratr. Arval., Grut. Inscr. p. 121 [1. adoleofacio].</sense></entryFree>
adolenda: <entryFree id="n946" type="gloss" key="Ado^lenda"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Adŏlenda</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>1. adoleo</etym>, appears to be <sense id="n946.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of a Roman goddess</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who presided over the burning of trees struck by lightning</hi>: (immolavit) ADOLENDAE. COMMOLENDAE. DEFERVNDAE. OVES. II., etc., Frat. Arval., Orell. Inscr. 961 and 2270.</sense></entryFree>
adoleo: <entryFree id="n947" type="main" key="a^do^le^o1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ŏlĕo</orth>, ui. <itype>ultum, 2</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>oleo</etym>. <sense id="n947.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To magnify;</hi> hence, in sacrificial language, to which this word chiefly belongs, <hi rend="ital">to honor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to worship</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">to offer in worship</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to sacrifice</hi>, <hi rend="ital">burn</hi>, according as it has such words as <hi rend="ital">deos</hi>, <hi rend="ital">aras</hi>, etc., or <hi rend="ital">hostiam</hi>, <hi rend="ital">viscera</hi>, and <hi rend="ital">tura</hi>, for its object; v. explanation of this word in <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 58, 21</bibl>: “Adolere verbum est proprie sacra reddentium, quod significat votis ac supplicationibus numen auctius facere;” and “Adolere est urere, Verg. in Bucol. [8, 65], verbenasque adole pinguis et mascula tura. Adolere, augere, honorare, propitiare; et est verbum sacratum, ut macte, magis aucte.” etc.; so <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 1, 704</bibl>: “Flammis adolere penates, i. e. colere, sed adolere est proprie augere. In sacris autem, <foreign lang="greek">kat) eu)fhmismo/n</foreign>, adolere per bonum omen dicitur, nam in aris non adolentur aliqua, sed cremantur,”) and ad E. 8, 65: “Adole: incende, sed <foreign lang="greek">kat) eu)fhmismo\n</foreign> dicitur; <cit><quote lang="la">nam adole est auge” (not used in Cic.): sanguine conspergunt aras adolentque altaria donis,</quote> <trans><tr>cover the altar with gifts</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1237" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 1237</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">castis adolet dum altaria taedis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">verbenasque adole pingues et mascula tura,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:8:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> E. 8, 65</bibl></cit> (on which Serv. l. l.): flammis adolere <cb n="ADON" /> penates, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:704" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 1, 704</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">viscera tauri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:803" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 3, 803</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 276</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">focos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:1:514" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 1, 514</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cruore captivo adolere aras,</quote> <trans><tr>to sprinkle the altars with the blood of captives</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">precibus et igne puro altaria adolentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 2, 3</bibl></cit>: adolere honores, <hi rend="ital">to honor the gods by offered gifts</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Junoni Argivae jussos adolemus honores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:547" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 547</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nullos aris adoleret honores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:741" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 741</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n947.1" n="II" level="1"> In later Lat., in gen., <hi rend="ital">to burn</hi>, <hi rend="ital">consume by fire</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut leves stipulae demptis adolentur aristis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:192" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 192</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">id (corpus) igne adoleatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:31" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut Aeneida, quam nondum satis elimāsset, adolerent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 17, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quas (prunas) gravi frigore adoleri multas jusserat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Eutr.</author> 10, 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n948" type="hapax" key="a^do^le^o2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ŏlĕo</orth>, <itype>ēre</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>oleo</etym>, <sense id="n948.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to give out</hi> or <hi rend="ital">emit a smell</hi> or <hi rend="ital">odor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to smell</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">unde hic, amabo, unguenta adolent?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:3:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 2, 3, 19</bibl></cit> (cf. aboleo).</sense></entryFree>
adolesc: <entryFree id="n949" type="main" key="a^do^lesc"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŏlesc-</orth>, v. adulesc-.</entryFree>
adolesco: <entryFree id="n950" type="main" key="a^do^lesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ŏlesco</orth>, <itype>ēvi</itype> (rare <sense id="n950.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">ui</hi>, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 872</bibl> P.; <cit><quote lang="la">adolēsse sync. for adolevisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:6:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 6, 11</bibl></cit>), ultum, 3, <hi rend="ital">v. inch.</hi> [1. adoleo], <hi rend="ital">to grow up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to grow</hi> (of everything capable of increase in magnitude). </sense><sense id="n950.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen. </sense><sense id="n950.2" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, of men, animals, plants; seasons, passions, etc.; <cit><quote lang="la">but esp. of age: postquam adolevit ad eam aetatem, uti, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:prol. 47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. prol. 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi robustis adolevit viribus aetas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:450" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 450</bibl></cit>; cf. 4, 1035; <cit><quote lang="la">2, 1123: adultum robur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:1131" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 1131</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:798" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 798</bibl>: postquam adoluerit haec juventus, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 872</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">qui adoleverit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:35" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">viriditas herbescens, quae sensim adolescit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:15:51" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 15, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ter senos proles adoleverat annos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:59" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 3, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adolescere ramos cernat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:376" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 4, 376</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adolēsse segetes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:6:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 6, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">simul atque adoleverit aetas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:9:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 9, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum matura adoleverit aetas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:438" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 438</bibl></cit>.—Hence, transf. from age to the person, <hi rend="ital">to grow up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">come to maturity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mature</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adulta virgo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:50 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 50 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arundines non sine imbre adolescunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 16, 23, § 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in amplitudinem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 12, 1, 3, § 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in crassitudinem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 13, 7, 15, § 58</bibl></cit>; so 16, 34, 62, § 151; <cit><quote lang="la">8, 14, 14, § 36 al.: ac dum prima novis adolescit frondibus aetas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:362" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 362</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quoad capillus adolesceret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:9" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 17, 9</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n950.3" n="B" level="2"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">to grow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">increase</hi>, <hi rend="ital">augment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to become greater</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cupiditas agendi adolescit una cum aetatibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ratio cum adolevit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 1, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ingenium brevi adolevit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 63:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 63, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">postquam res publica adolevit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 51:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> C. 51, 40</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> J. 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quantum superbiae socordiaeque Vitellio adoleverit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 73</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cremona numero colonorum, adolevit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ver adolescit,</quote> <trans><tr>advances</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 13, 36</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 50</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">caepe revirescit, decedente luna, inarescit adolescente,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:8" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n950.4" n="II" level="1"> Esp., in sacrificial lang., <hi rend="ital">to be kindled</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to burn</hi> (cf. 1. adoleo): <cit><quote lang="la">Panchaeis adolescunt ignibus arae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:379" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 379</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŏlescens</orth>, <itype>entis</itype>, v. adules-.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">ădultus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">grown up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adult.</hi> </sense><sense id="n950.5" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n950.6" n="1" level="3"> Of living beings: <cit><quote lang="la">Ab his ipsis (virginibus), cum jam essent adultae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:20:58" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 20, 58</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">virgo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:96:330" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 96, 330</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 50</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:2:8 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 2, 8 al.</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">adultae aetate virgines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:69" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pueri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:2:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 2, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">liberi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:10" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">filius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:39" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Claud. 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">catuli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 8, 7, § 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">locustae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 11, 29, 35, § 105</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fetus (apum),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:162" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 162</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">(hirundinum) pullorum adultiores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 33, 49, § 92</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n950.7" n="2" level="3"> Of things (concrete and abstract): <cit><quote lang="la">vitium propagine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:2:9" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 2, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">crinis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:2:122" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 2, 122</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lanugo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 16, 12 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aetas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:1123" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 1123</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:68:section=160" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 68, § 160</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aestas,</quote> <trans><tr>advanced</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">autumnus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 11</bibl></cit>. 31: <cit><quote lang="la">nox,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 3, 23</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n950.8" n="B" level="2"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">grown</hi>, <hi rend="ital">matured</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adult</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">populus adultus jam paene et pubes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 11</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">qui non nascentibus Athenis, sed jam adultis fuerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:7:27" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 7, 27</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">nascenti adhuc (eloquentiae) nec satis adultae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Or. 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">res nondum adultae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 1, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pestis rei publicae (of Catiline),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:12:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 1, 12, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">auctoritas nondum adulta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">conjuratio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 73</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">incipiens adhuc et necdum adulta seditio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:31 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 1, 31 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
adominatio: <entryFree id="n951" type="gloss" key="a^do_mi^na_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădōmĭnātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n951.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a good</hi> or <hi rend="ital">favorable omen</hi>, in Gloss. Gr. Lat.</sense></entryFree>
adoneus: <entryFree id="n952" type="main" key="A^do_neus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ădōneus</orth>, <itype>ei</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (trisyl.). <sense id="n952.0" n="I" level="1"> = Adonis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:1:2:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 1, 2, 35</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 2, p. 126</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n952.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An epithet of Bacchus</hi>, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">*)adwneu/s, e/ws</foreign>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Epigr. 30, 6</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 28</bibl>. <cb n="ADOP" /></sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n953" type="main" key="A^do_ne_us2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ădōnēus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n953.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to</hi> Adonis: <cit><quote lang="la">caedes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Mon. de Histt. 3</bibl></cit>: lusus, Grut. Inscr. 1123, 7.</sense></entryFree>
adonia: <entryFree id="n954" type="main" key="A^do_ni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ădōnĭa</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <foreign lang="greek">ta\ *)adw/nia</foreign>, <sense id="n954.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the festival of Adonis.</hi> It returned annually in June, about the time of the summer solstice, and was celebrated (even in Rome; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Manso, Essays on Myth.) with alternate lamentations and exultations, on account of the death of Adonis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 22, 9</bibl></cit>. This festival was a symbol of the dying and reviving again of nature; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Hier.</author> ad Ez. 8</bibl>; Creuz. Symb. 2, 86; Böttig. Sab. 1, 261 sq.</sense></entryFree>
adonidium: <entryFree id="n955" type="main" key="a^do_ni^di^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădōnĭdĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, v. adonium, II.</entryFree>
adonis: <entryFree id="n956" type="main" key="A^do_nis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ădōnis</orth>, <itype>nis or nĭdis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/adwnis</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">*)/adwn</foreign> (<case>nom.</case> Adon, Venant. Carm. 7, 12 and 18; <sense id="n956.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> Adonis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 4, 19, § 49</bibl>; <case>dat.</case> Adonidi, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 23</bibl>; <case>acc.</case> Adonidem, Claud. Nupt. Hon. et Mar. 16: <cit><quote lang="la">Adonim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:5:37" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 5, 37</bibl></cit>, acc. to Müller, Adonem: <cit><quote lang="la">Adonem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. E. 10, 18</bibl></cit>; Arnob. 4, p. 184; <case>voc.</case> Adoni, <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Met. 10, 542</bibl>; <case>abl.</case> Adone, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 8, p. 213</bibl>). </sense><sense id="n956.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A son of Cinyras</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Cyprus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">beloved by Venus on account of his extraordinary beauty;</hi> he was torn in pieces in the chase by a wild boar, which Mars (acc. to some, Diana) sent against him out of jealousy, but was changed by Venus to a flower, which bore the name Adonium, and was yearly bewailed by her on the anniversary of his death, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:503 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 503 sq.</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 21</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. E. 8, 37</bibl>; cf. with 10, 18, and Adonia: Adonis horti, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">kh=poi *)adw/nidos</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">pots of lettuce and other plants</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which blossom quick</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but wither as soon</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 4, 19, § 49</bibl>; cf. Böttig. Sab. 1, 264.—</sense><sense id="n956.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A name of the Sun-god among the Assyrians and Phœnicians</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 21</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n956.3" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A name of a fish</hi>, i. q. exocoetus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 19, 34, § 70</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adonium: <entryFree id="n957" type="greek" key="a^do_ni^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădōnĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)dw/nion</foreign>. <sense id="n957.0" n="I" level="1"> Acc. to some <hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a species of southernwood</hi>, bearing a flower of golden color or bloodred, as if from the blood of Adonis; acc. to others, a mode of cultivating flowers, as if <hi rend="ital">Adonis horti</hi>, the garden of Adonis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 10, 34, § 60</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n957.1" n="II" level="1"> In gram., <hi rend="ital">the Adonic verse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">composed of a dactyl and spondee</hi>, ¯˘˘¯¯˘, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> 1820</bibl> P.; Grot. 2, 104; e. g. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 4</bibl>: terruit urbem; visere montes, etc., said to have been so named because used in the festival of Adonis; also <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădōnĭdĭum</orth>, Mar. Vict. 2, p. 2518 P.</sense></entryFree>
adoperio: <entryFree id="n958" type="main" key="a^do^pe^ri^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ŏpĕrĭo</orth>, <itype>ĕrŭi, ertum, 4</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n958.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to cover up</hi> or <hi rend="ital">over</hi> (not used before the Aug. per., and gen. in the <hi rend="ital">part. perf. pass.</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">capite adoperto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 26</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Epit. 89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Epit. 89</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:48" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 48</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">purpureo adopertus amictu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:405" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 405</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempora adoperta cucullo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:8:145" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 8, 145</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adopertam floribus humum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:688" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 688</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:8:701" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 701</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hiems gelu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:235" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 3, 235</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aether nubibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:2:75" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 75</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lumina somno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:714" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 1, 714</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tenebris mors,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:1:70" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 1, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">foribus adopertis,</quote> <trans><tr>with closed doors</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:11" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Oth. 11</bibl></cit>.—In the <hi rend="ital">verb. finit.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quidam prius tuto sale sex horis (ova) adoperiunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:6" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 8, 6</bibl></cit>: pellem setis adoperuit, Lact. Op. Dei, 7.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŏpertē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">the foll.</ref></xr> art.</sense></entryFree>
adoperte: <entryFree id="n959" type="main" key="a^do^perte_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŏpertē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>adoperio</etym>, <sense id="n959.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">covertly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in a dark</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mysterious manner</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">denuntiare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 8, p. 303</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adopertum: <entryFree id="n960" type="main" key="a^do^pertum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŏpertum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n960.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that which is mysterious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a mystery</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adopinor: <entryFree id="n961" type="hapax" key="a^do^pi_nor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ŏpīnor</orth>, <itype>āri</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos>, <sense id="n961.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to think</hi>, <hi rend="ital">suppose</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">conjecture further</hi> ( = opinando adicio): <cit><quote lang="la">adopinamur de signis maxima parvis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:816" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 816</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adoptaticius: <entryFree id="n962" type="main" key="a^dopta_ti_ci^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădoptātīcĭus</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">-tītĭus</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>adopto</etym>, <sense id="n962.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adopted</hi>, <hi rend="ital">received in the place of a child;</hi> only in Plaut., Poen. 5, 2, 85: <cit><quote lang="la">Demarcho item ipse fuit adoptaticius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 100</bibl></cit>. —Acc. to Festus, it signifies <hi rend="ital">the son of one who is adopted</hi>: ex adoptato filio natus, p. 29 Müll.</sense></entryFree>
adoptatio: <entryFree id="n963" type="main" key="a^dopta_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădoptātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.; access. form of adoptio, by which it was supplanted after the class. per.</etym>, <sense id="n963.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an adopting</hi>, <hi rend="ital">receiving as a child</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">ui(oqesi/a</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid propagatio nominis, quid adoptationes filiorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:14:31" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 14, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adoptatio Theophani agitata est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,026:25:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Balb. 25, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipsum illum adoptatione in regnum pervenisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 11:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 11, 6</bibl></cit>: quod per praetorem fit, adoptatio dicitur; <cit><quote lang="la">quod per populum, arrogatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:5:19" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 5, 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Gent. 2, 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adoptator: <entryFree id="n964" type="main" key="a^dopta_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădoptātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n964.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one that</hi> <pb n="44" /> <cb n="ADOP" /> <hi rend="ital">adopts another</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an adopter</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:5:19" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 5, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:37:9:1:section=12" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 37, 9, 1, § 12 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
adoptio: <entryFree id="n965" type="main" key="a^dopti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădoptĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>v. adoptatio</etym>, <sense id="n965.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a taking</hi> or <hi rend="ital">receiving of one in the place of a child</hi> (also <hi rend="ital">of a grandchild</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:7:10" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 1, 7, 10</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">an adopting</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adoption</hi> (properly of one still under paternal authority, in patria potestate; on the contr., <hi rend="ital">arrogatio</hi> referred to one who was already independent, homo sui juris. The former took place before the praetor or other magistrate and five witnesses, by a threefold mancipatio, i. e. sham sale; <cit><quote lang="la">the latter could only be effected before the assembled people in the comitia curiata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:5:19" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 5, 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:Inst. 1:11" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> Inst. 1, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:7" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 1, 7</bibl>. More used than adoptatio, q. v.): <cit><quote lang="la">emancipare filium alicui in adoptionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:7" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dare se alicui in adoptionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:8:2" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 8, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:2" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 2</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 40</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adscire aliquem per adoptionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 3</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">or, in adoptionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 2, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inserere aliquem familiae per adoptionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:39" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 39 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adscitus adoptione in imperium et cognomentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adoptio in Domitium festinatur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adoptionem nuncupare,</quote> <trans><tr>to make known</tr>, <tr>to announce</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 1, 17</bibl></cit>: adoptio consularis, <hi rend="ital">performed by a consul</hi>, Quint. prooem. 6, 13 Spald. al.—</sense><sense id="n965.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, of plants, <hi rend="ital">the ingrafting</hi>, Plin. prooem. 1, 16.—Of bees, <hi rend="ital">the admittance to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">reception in</hi> a new hive: <cit><quote lang="la">ut tamquam novae prolis adoptione domicilia confirmentur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:13:9" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 9, 13, 9</bibl></cit>.—In eccl. Lat., in spiritual sense of adoption as children of God: <cit><quote lang="la">adoptionem filiorum Dei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,006:8:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Rom. 8, 23</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,009:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Gal. 4, 5</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Ephes. 1, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adoptivus: <entryFree id="n966" type="main" key="a^dopti_vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădoptīvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>adopto</etym>, <sense id="n966.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to adoption</hi>, <hi rend="ital">made</hi> or <hi rend="ital">acquired by adoption</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adoptive</hi>: filius, <hi rend="ital">an adopted son</hi>: P. Scipio, Fragm. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:5:19" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 5, 19</bibl> (opp. naturalis, a son by birth): <cit><quote lang="la">filiorum neque naturalem Drusum neque adoptivum Germanicum patria caritate dilexit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:52" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 52</bibl></cit>: pater adoptivus, <hi rend="ital">who has adopted one as son</hi> (or <hi rend="ital">grandson</hi>, v. adoptio), <hi rend="ital">an adoptive father</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:45:1:107" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 45, 1, 107</bibl>: frater, soror, etc., <hi rend="ital">a brother</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sister</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">by adoption</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not by birth</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:23:2:12" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 23, 2, 12</bibl>, and 38, 8, 3; <cit><quote lang="la">so also, familia,</quote> <trans><tr>the family into which one has been received by adoption</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:37:4:3" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 37, 4, 3</bibl></cit>: adoptiva sacra, <hi rend="ital">of the family into which one has been adopled</hi> (opp. paterna): <cit><quote lang="la">neque amissis sacris paternis in haec adoptiva venisti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:13:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Dom. 13, 35</bibl></cit>: nomen, <hi rend="ital">received by adoption</hi> (opp. nomen gentile), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:41" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 41</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nobilitas,</quote> <trans><tr>nobility acquired by adoption</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:22" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 22</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, of the ingrafting of plants (cf. adoptio): <cit><quote lang="la">fissaque adoptivas accipit arbor opes,</quote> <trans><tr>bears fruits not natural to it</tr>, <tr>ingrafted</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,003:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Med. Fac. 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:13:46" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 13, 46</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae sit adoptivis arbor onusta comis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> de Insit. 20</bibl></cit>; cf. 144, 160 (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 82</bibl>: Miraturque (arbos) novas frondes et non sua poma).</sense></entryFree>
adopto: <entryFree id="n967" type="main" key="a^dopto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-opto</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n967.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to take to</hi> one's self <hi rend="ital">by wish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">choice</hi> (optando); <hi rend="ital">to choose</hi>, <hi rend="ital">select.</hi> </sense><sense id="n967.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">sociam te mihi adopto ad meam salutem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:4:2:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 4, 2, 78</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui manstutorem me adoptavit bonis,</quote> <trans><tr>who has chosen me as a guardian of his property</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 4, 4, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quem sibi illa (provincia) defensorem sui juris adoptavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:in Caecin. 16" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. in Caecin. 16 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: eum sibi patronum, id <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 20, 64</bibl>: quem potius adoptem aut invocem, Vatin. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 9</bibl>: Frater, Pater, adde; Ut cuique est aetas, ita quemque facetus adopta (i. e. adscisce, adjunge, sc. tuo alloquio, Cruqu.), <hi rend="ital">make him by thy greeting a father</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brother</hi>, etc., i. e. <hi rend="ital">call him</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 6, 55</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Etruscas Turnus adoptat opes,</quote> <trans><tr>strives after</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:880" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 880</bibl></cit>.—Hence: adoptare se alicui, <hi rend="ital">to give</hi> or <hi rend="ital">attach one's self to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui se potentiae causā Caesaris libertis adoptāsset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 1, 5, § 12</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n967.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. as t. t., <hi rend="ital">to take one</hi> in the place of a child or grandchild, <hi rend="ital">to adopt</hi> (diff. from arrogo; v. adoptio). </sense><sense id="n967.3" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, constr. with <hi rend="ital">aliquem</hi>, also with <hi rend="ital">ab aliquo aliquem</hi> (from the real father, a patre naturali), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:prol. 74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. prol. 74</bibl> (cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 2, 82</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">adoptat illum puerum subreptitium sibi filium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:prol. 60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. prol. 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">filium senatorem populum Romanum sibi velle adoptare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:chapter=14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Dom. 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adoptatus patricius a plebeio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 7, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">is qui hunc minorem Scipionem a Paulo adoptavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:19:77" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 19, 77</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adoptavit eum heredemque fecit ex dodrante,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 5, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adoptatus testamento,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:6" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 6</bibl></cit>: adoptari a se Pisonem <cb n="ADOR" /> pronuntiat, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Pisonem pro contione adoptavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:17" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quem illa adoptavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 2, 10</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">in</hi> and <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in regnum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 22:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 22, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in familiam nomenque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:83" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 83</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in successionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:9:2" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 9, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n967.4" n="B" level="2"> Fig.: <cit><quote lang="la">servi in bona libertatis nostrae adoptantur,</quote> <trans><tr>are</tr>, <tr>as it were</tr>, <tr>adopted into freedom</tr>, <tr>are made participants of freedom</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:3:20" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 3, 20</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and of ingrafting (cf. adoptivus): venerit insitio: fac ramum ramus adoptet,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> R. Am. 195</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:10:38" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 10, 38</bibl>. Those who were adopted commonly received the family name of the adoptive father, with the ending -anus, e. g. Aemilianus, Pomponianus, etc.—Hence Cic. says ironic. of one who appropriated to himself the name of another: <cit><quote lang="la">ipse se adoptat: et C. Stalenus, qui se ipse adoptaverat et de Staleno Aelium fecerat,</quote> <trans><tr>had changed himself from a Stalenus to an Ælius</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Brut.</author> 68, 241</bibl></cit>; and Vitruv.: Zoilus qui adoptavit cognomen, ut Homeromastix vocitaretur, <hi rend="ital">had himself called</hi>, 7, 8.
