So: <cit><quote lang="la">ergo aliquod gratum Musis tibi nomen adopta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:6:31" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 6, 31</bibl></cit>; in Pliny, very often, adoptare aliquid (also with the addition of nomine suo or in nomen), <hi rend="ital">to give a thing its name</hi>: Baetis Oceanum Atlanticum, provinciam adoptans, petit, <hi rend="ital">while it gives to the province the name</hi> (Baetica). <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 1, 3, § 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">A Zmyrna Hermus campos facit et nomini suo adoptat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 29, 31, § 119</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so 25, 3, 7, § 22: in nomen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 37, 3, 12, § 50</bibl></cit>; so also Statius, Theb. 7, 259.</sense></entryFree>
ador: <entryFree id="n968" type="main" key="a^dor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădor</orth>, <itype>ŏris and ōris</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>cf. 1. edo, <foreign lang="greek">e)/domai</foreign>, Engl. to eat, Goth. ita, Sanscr. admi; and Ang.-Sax. ata = Engl. oat, and Sanscr. annam (for adnam) = food, corn</etym>, <sense id="n968.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of grain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">spelt</hi>, Triticum spelta, Linn. (acc. to Paul. ex Fest.: <cit><quote lang="la">Ador farris genus, edor quondam appellatum ab edendo, vel quod aduratur, ut fiat tostum, unde in sacrificio mola salsa officitur, p. 3 Müll.: Ador frumenti genus, quod epulis et immolationibus sacris pium putatur, unde et adorare, propitiare religiones, potest dictum videri,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 52, 20</bibl></cit>): <cit><quote lang="la">cum pater ipse domus palea porrectus in horna Esset ador loliumque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:6:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 6, 89</bibl></cit>: adŏris de polline, Aus. Mon. de Cibis, p. 238; Gannius ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 700</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">satos adŏris stravisse,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ardor adōris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit> (Ador is often indeclinable, acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 785, 100</bibl> P.)</sense></entryFree>
adorabilis: <entryFree id="n969" type="hapax" key="a^do_ra_bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădōrābĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>adoro</etym>, <sense id="n969.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">worthy of adoration</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adorable</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">beneficium deae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 11, p. 265</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adoratio: <entryFree id="n970" type="main" key="a^do_ra_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădōrātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n970.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">worship</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adoration</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">prosku/nhsis</foreign> (rare; not in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:16:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 16, 5</bibl>, where the correct read. is adulationi, Weissenb.): <cit><quote lang="la">propitiare deos adoratione,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:29:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 29, 4, 20, § 67</bibl></cit>.—In <number>plur.</number>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 4, p. 155</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adorator: <entryFree id="n971" type="main" key="a^do_ra_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădōrātor</orth>, <itype>ŏris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n971.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who adores</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a worshipper</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> de Spec. 8</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Joh. 4, 23</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adordino: <entryFree id="n972" type="hapax" key="a^dordi^no"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ordĭno</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n972.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to set in order</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to arrange</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">patellam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2003,001:4:2" default="NO"><author>Apic.</author> 4, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adorea: <entryFree id="n973" type="main" key="a^do_re^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădōrĕa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădōrĕum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, see the foll. art., II. A. and B.</entryFree>
adoreus: <entryFree id="n974" type="main" key="a^do_re^us1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădōrĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ador</etym>, <sense id="n974.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to spelt</hi>, <hi rend="ital">consisting of spelt.</hi> </sense><sense id="n974.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Adj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">far adoreum = ador,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 83</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:9:4" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 9, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:2:74 sq" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 11, 2, 74 sq.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">semen,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:6:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 6, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">liba,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:109" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 109</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bellaria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:1:6:10" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 1, 6, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n974.2" n="II" level="1"> <pos>Subst.</pos> </sense><sense id="n974.3" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădōrĕa</orth> (adoria, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=3" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 3</bibl> Müll.; see below), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (sc. donatio), <hi rend="ital">a reward of valor</hi> (in early ages this usually consisted of <hi rend="ital">grain</hi>); hence, trop., <hi rend="ital">glory</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fame</hi>, <hi rend="ital">renown</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">gloriam denique ipsam a farris honore adoream appellabant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 3, 3, § 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 8, 9, 19, § 83</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">praedā agroque adoreāque affecit populares suos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 38</bibl></cit>: pulcher fugatis Ille dies Latio tenebris, Qui primus almā risit adoreā, <hi rend="ital">in lordly honor</hi>, viz. by the defeat of Hasdrubal, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:4:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 4, 41</bibl>. (Festus gives another explanation for the signif. <hi rend="ital">honor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">renown</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">adoriam laudem sive gloriam dicebant, quia gloriosum eum putabant esse, qui farris copia abundaret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=3" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 3</bibl></cit> Müll.). —</sense><sense id="n974.4" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădōrĕum</orth>. <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (sc. far), i. q. ador, <hi rend="ital">spelt</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:8:5" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 8, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n975" type="main" key="Adore^us2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Adorĕus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n975.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mountain of Galatia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in the neighborhood of Pessinus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with the source of the river Sangarius</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Elmah Dagh</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:18:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 18, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adorio: <entryFree id="n976" type="hapax" key="a^do^ri^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ŏrĭo</orth>, <itype>īre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, the act. form of <cb n="ADOR" /> adorior, <sense id="n976.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to attack</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to assail</hi>: tunc ipsos adoriant, Naev. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 801</bibl> P. (Trag. Rel. p. 8 Rib.).—Hence also <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi> adortus, Aur. Fragm. Naev. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 791</bibl> P.; <cit><quote lang="la">and, acc. to some,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:6:46" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 2, 6, 46</bibl></cit>, where Halm reads <hi rend="ital">adoratam.</hi></sense></entryFree>
adorior: <entryFree id="n977" type="main" key="a^do^ri^or"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ŏrĭor</orth>, <itype>ortus, 4</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> (<sense id="n977.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">part.</hi> adorsus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:9:2:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 9, 2, 10</bibl>; see the passage at the end of this art.; the second and third pers. of the <hi rend="ital">pres. ind.</hi>, acc. to the fourth conj.: adorīris, adorītur; forms analogous to orĕris, orĭtur, of the simple verb occur in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:513" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 513</bibl>; Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 880</bibl> P.), <hi rend="ital">to rise up for the purpose of going to some one</hi> or <hi rend="ital">something</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">of undertaking something great</hi>, <hi rend="ital">difficult</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">hazardous</hi> (clandestinely, artfully, when a hostile approach is spoken of; while <hi rend="ital">aggredi</hi> indicates a direct, open attack from a distance: aggredimur de longinquo; adorimur ex insidiis et ex proximo; nam adoriri est quasi ad aliquem oriri, i. e. exsurgere, Don. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:3:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 3, 50</bibl>; cf. the same ad Heaut. 4, 5, 9). </sense><sense id="n977.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to approach a person in order to address him</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to ask something of him</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to accost</hi>, etc. (cf. accedo, adeo): <cit><quote lang="la">cesso hunc adoriri? (quasi de improviso alloqui, Don.),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:4:5:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 4, 5, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si ab eo nil fiet, tum hunc adorior hospitem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:4:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 4, 2, 15</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n977.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n977.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To approach one with hostile intent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to assault</hi>, <hi rend="ital">assail</hi>, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 886</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">inermem tribunum gladiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:chapter=37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">a tergo Milonem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">navem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 34 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">impeditos adoriebantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hos Conon adortus magno proelio fugat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,009:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Con. 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbem vi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oppugnatio eos aliquanto atrocior quam ante adorta est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 11</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">21, 28: praetorem ex improviso in itinere adortus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">variis criminationibus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 14, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">minis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 1, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jurgio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:3:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 3, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">senatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:9" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 9</bibl></cit>.—Also <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0530,001:B. Afr. 69" default="NO"><author>Hirt.</author> B. Afr. 69</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n977.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To enter upon any course of action</hi>, esp. <hi rend="ital">to engage in</hi> or <hi rend="ital">undertake any thing difficult</hi> or <hi rend="ital">dangerous;</hi> with <case>acc.</case> or <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">commutare animum quicumque adoritur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:515" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 515</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne convellere adoriamur ea, quae non possint commoveri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:51:205" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 51, 205</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 13, 22</bibl>: <foreign lang="greek">*(hraklei/dion</foreign>, si Brundisium salvi, adoriemur (sc. scribere), <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 16, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 2, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">majus adorta nefas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:2:2:16" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 2, 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hi dominam Ditis thalamo deducere adorti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:397" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 397</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 386</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:63:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 63, 11</bibl>.—So esp. in the histt., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Dion. 6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dion. 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hanc (Munychiam) bis tyranni oppugnare sunt adorti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Thras. 2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Thras. 2, 5</bibl></cit>; so also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 51</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:3" default="NO" valid="yes">28, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:5:32" default="NO" valid="yes">37, 5, 32</bibl>; 40, 22; 43, 21; 44, 12; cf. also 3, 44: hanc virginem Appius pretio ac spe pellicere adortus.— Once in the form of the <hi rend="ital">part. perf.</hi> adorsus: <cit><quote lang="la">qui Hippiam tyrannum interficere adorsi erant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:9:2:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 9, 2, 10</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adoriosus: <entryFree id="n978" type="gloss" key="a^do_ri^o_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădōrĭōsus</orth>, <pos>adj.</pos>, in the Gloss. Gr. Lat. as translation of <foreign lang="greek">e)/ndocos</foreign>, <sense id="n978.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that has often obtained the</hi> adorea, <hi rend="ital">celebrated.</hi></sense></entryFree>
adornate: <entryFree id="n979" type="main" key="a^dorna_te_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădornātē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. adorno <sense id="n979.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
adorno: <entryFree id="n980" type="main" key="a^dorno"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-orno</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n980.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to prepare a thing for</hi> some definite object, <hi rend="ital">to get ready</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to furnish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">provide</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fit out</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equip</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">kosme/w</foreign>. </sense><sense id="n980.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen. (class.; <cit><quote lang="la">esp. freq. in Plaut. and Cic.): quin tu mihi adornas ad fugam viaticum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:5:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 5, 1, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nuptias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:6:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. 2, 6, 67</bibl></cit>; so also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:1:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Aul. 2, 1, 35</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">fugam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 4, 6</bibl></cit> (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">fugam aut furtum parat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:1:4:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 1, 4, 14</bibl></cit>): <cit><quote lang="la">maria classibus et praesidiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:12:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 12, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">forum comitiumque adornatum, ad speciem magnifico ornatu, ad sensum cogitationemque acerbo et lugubri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut accusationem et petitionem consulatus adornet atque instruat,</quote> <trans><tr>prepare</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:22:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 22, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">testium copiam,</quote> <trans><tr>to produce</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">invenire et adornare comparationem criminis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 67</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">contra haec Pompeius naves magnas onerarias adornabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omni opulentiā insignium armorum bellum adornaverant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 38</bibl></cit>.—Anteclass. constr. with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tragulam in te inicere adornat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:5:2:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 5, 2, 25</bibl></cit>.—And <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adorna, ut rem divinam faciam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 4, 6, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:5:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 3, 5, 34</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n980.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To put an ornament upon</hi> one; hence, <hi rend="ital">to decorate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adorn</hi>, <hi rend="ital">embellish</hi> with something (mostly in the Aug. per.; esp. in the histt.): <hi rend="ital">aliquem aliqua re</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">(Numa) flaminem insigni veste et curuli regiā sellā adornavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">triumphum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:122" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 122</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:29" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:43" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tib. 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:45" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Calig. 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:12" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ner. 12</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">38</bibl>: <pb n="45" /> <cb n="ADOR" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:3:3:13" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 3, 3, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:17 al" default="NO">17 al.</bibl>—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">tantis adornatus virtutibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:2" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praecipuis donis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:121" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 2, 121</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bene facta suis verbis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:1:8:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 1, 8, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adornata verbis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">legem leviter (sc. verbis) adornabit, ut justam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:1:47" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 1, 47</bibl></cit>.—Hence, * <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădornātē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>: declamabat splendide atque adornate, <hi rend="ital">brilliantly and elegantly</hi> (opp. circumcise ac sordide), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,004:6" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Rhet. 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adoro: <entryFree id="n981" type="main" key="a^do_ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ōro</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <sense id="n981.0" n="I" level="1"> In the earliest per., <hi rend="ital">to speak to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">accost</hi> one, <hi rend="ital">to address;</hi> hence, also, <hi rend="ital">to treat of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">negotiate a matter with one</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adorare veteribus est alloqui,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 10, 677</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">immo cum gemitu populum sic adorat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Met. 2, p. 127</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">3</bibl>, p. 130: adorare apud antiquos significabat agere: unde et legati oratores dicuntur, quia mandata populi agunt, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=19" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 19</bibl> Müll.; cf. oro and orator.— Hence, also, in judicial lang., <hi rend="ital">to bring an accusation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to accuse;</hi> so in the Fragm. of the XII. Tab. lex viii.: SEI (Si) ADORAT FVRTO QVOD NEC MANIFESTVM ERIT, Fest. S. V. NEC, p. 162 Müll.—</sense><sense id="n981.1" n="II" level="1"> In the class. per., <hi rend="ital">to speak to one</hi> in order to obtain something of him; <hi rend="ital">to ask</hi> or <hi rend="ital">entreat</hi> one, esp. a deity, <hi rend="ital">to pray earnestly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to beseech</hi>, <hi rend="ital">supplicate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">implore;</hi> constr. with <case>acc.</case>, <hi rend="ital">ut</hi>, or the simple <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quos adorent, ad quos precentur et supplicent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">affaturque deos et sanctum sidus adorat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:700" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 700</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in rupes, in saxa (volens vos Turnus adoro) Ferte ratem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 677</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Junonis prece numen,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 437</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">prece superos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:1:3:41" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 1, 3, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non te per meritum adoro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:10:141" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 10, 141</bibl></cit>.—With the thing asked for in the <case>acc.</case> (like rogo, peto, postulo): <cit><quote lang="la">cum hostiā caesā pacem deūm adorāsset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 12</bibl></cit> Drak.—With <hi rend="ital">ut</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adoravi deos, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 40</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:300" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 300</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adorati di, ut bene ac feliciter eveniret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hanc ego, non ut me defendere temptet, adoro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:2:2:55" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 2, 2, 55</bibl></cit>.—With the <hi rend="ital">subj.</hi> without <hi rend="ital">ut</hi>, <usg type="style">poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">maneat sic semper adoro,</quote> <trans><tr>I pray</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:1:4:27" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 1, 4, 27</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n981.2" n="III" level="1"> Hence, </sense><sense id="n981.3" n="A" level="2"> Dropping the idea of asking, entreating, <hi rend="ital">to reverence</hi>, <hi rend="ital">honor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adore</hi>, <hi rend="ital">worship</hi> the gods or objects of nature regarded as gods; more emphatic than <hi rend="ital">venerari</hi>, and denoting the highest degree of reverence (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">proskunei=n</foreign>); the habitus adorantium was to put the right hand to the mouth and turn about the entire body to the right (dextratio, q. v.); cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 2, 5, § 25</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 21</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 4, 28</bibl>. —Constr. with <case>acc.</case>, <case>dat.</case>, with <hi rend="ital">prepp.</hi> or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> </sense><sense id="n981.4" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Auctoremque viae Phoebum taciturnus adorat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Janus adorandus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:3:881" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 3, 881</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in delubra non nisi adoraturus intras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:52" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">large deos adorare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 14, 32, § 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nil praeter nubes et caeli numen adorat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:97" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14, 97</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adorare crocodilon,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:15:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 15, 2</bibl></cit>.— <cit><quote lang="la">In eccl. Lat. of the worship of the true God: adoravit Israel Deum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:47:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 47, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Dominum Deum tuum adorabis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:4:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 4, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Deum adora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:22:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Apoc. 22, 9</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so of Christ: videntes eum adoraverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:28:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 28, 17</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">adorent eum omnes angeli Dei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,019:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Heb. 1, 6</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n981.5" n="(b)" level="5"> With <case>dat.</case> (eccl.): adorato (<hi rend="ital">imperat.</hi>) Domino Deo tuo, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:26:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Deut. 26, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec adorabis deo alieno,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ital. Ps. 80, 10</bibl></cit> Mai (deum alienum, Vulg.): <cit><quote lang="la">qui adorant sculptibus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 96, 7</bibl></cit> Mai (sculptilia, Vulg.).—</sense><sense id="n981.6" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">prepp.</hi> (eccl.): <cit><quote lang="la">si adoraveris coram me,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Luc. 4, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adorabunt in conspectu tuo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:15:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Apoc. 15, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adorent ante pedes tuos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 3, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">22, 8</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n981.7" n="(d)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg> (eccl.): <cit><quote lang="la">Patres nostri in hoc monte adoraverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:4:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Joan. 4, 20</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">bis.;</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:24:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 24, 11</bibl>.—And, </sense><sense id="n981.8" n="B" level="2"> The notion of religious regard being dropped, <hi rend="ital">to reverence</hi>, <hi rend="ital">admire</hi>, <hi rend="ital">esteem highly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adorare priscorum in inveniendo curam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:27:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 27, 1, 1, § 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Ennium sicut sacros vetustate lucos adoremus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:88" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 88</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">veteris qui tollunt grandia templi pocula adorandae rubiginis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:13:148" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 13, 148</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec tu divinam Aeneida tenta, Sed longe sequere et vestigia semper adora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:12:816" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 12, 816</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n981.9" n="C" level="2"> Under the emperors the Oriental custom being introduced of worshipping the Cæsars with divine ceremony, <hi rend="ital">to worship</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to reverence</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">C. Caesarem adorari ut deum constituit, cum reversus ex Syria, non aliter adire ausus esset quam capite velato circumvertensque se, deinde procumbens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vit.:2" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vit. 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 4, 28</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Min. Fel.</author> 2, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non salutari, sed adorari se jubet (Alexander),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:12:7" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 12, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adorare Caesarum imagines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:14" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 14</bibl></cit>: coronam a judicibus ad se delatam adoravit, <hi rend="ital">did obeisance</hi> <cb n="ADRU" /> <hi rend="ital">before</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:12" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ner. 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adorare purpuram principis,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>touched his purple robe and brought it to the mouth in reverence</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 21, 9</bibl></cit>.—Of adulation to the rabble, <hi rend="ital">to pay court to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec deerat Otho protendens manus, adorare volgum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 36</bibl></cit>.!*? This word does not occur in Cic.; for in Arch. 11, 28, where adoravi was given by Mai in Fragm. p. 124, Halm reads <hi rend="ital">adhortatus sum</hi>, and B. and K. <hi rend="ital">adornavi.</hi></sense></entryFree>
adortus: <entryFree id="n982" type="main" key="a^dortus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădortus</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădorsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of adorior.</entryFree>
adosculor: <entryFree id="n983" type="hapax" key="a^doscu^lor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-oscŭlor</orth>, <itype>āri</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos>, <sense id="n983.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to give a kiss to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to kiss</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">manus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Dict. Cret.</author> 2, 51</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adp: <entryFree id="n984" type="main" key="adp"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adp-</orth>. Words beginning thus, v. under app-.</entryFree>
adquiesco: <entryFree id="n985" type="main" key="adqui^esco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adquĭesco, adquīro</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adquīsītĭo</orth>, v. acquiesco, etc.</entryFree>
adquo: <entryFree id="n986" type="main" key="adquo_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-quō</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, i. q. the later quoad reversed, <sense id="n986.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">how far</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as far as</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as much as;</hi> only in two examples: iratus essem ad quo liceret, Afran. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 76, 9</bibl> (Com. Rel. p. 196 Rib.): ut scire possis, ad quo te expediat loqui, Afran. l. l. (p. 200 Rib.); cf. Hand, Turs. I. p. 178.</sense></entryFree>
adr: <entryFree id="n987" type="main" key="adr"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adr-</orth>, for all words in adr- not found here, v. under arr-.</entryFree>
adrachne: <entryFree id="n988" type="greek" key="adrachne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adrachnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> = <foreign lang="greek">a)dra/xnh</foreign>, <sense id="n988.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the wild strawberry-tree</hi>: Arbutus adrachne, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 13, 22, 40, § 120</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:80" default="NO" valid="yes">16, 21, 33, § 80</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:234" default="NO" valid="yes">17, 24, 37, § 234</bibl> (Silling and Jan in all these passages read andrachle).</sense></entryFree>
adrado: <entryFree id="n989" type="main" key="adra_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-rādo</orth>, <itype>si, sum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>ad, <hi rend="ital">intens.</hi></etym>, <sense id="n989.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to scrape</hi>, <hi rend="ital">shave</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">pare close.</hi> </sense><sense id="n989.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: scobina ego illam actutum adraserim, Plaut. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=68" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 68</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">adrasum cacumen,</quote> <trans><tr>lopped off</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:138" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 19, 30, § 138</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">scalpello acuto (sarmentum) in modum cunei adradito,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:de Arb. 8" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> de Arb. 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">conspexit Adrasum quendam,</quote> <trans><tr>newly shaved</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 7, 50</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n989.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig.: <foreign lang="greek">*aeitou/rgion</foreign> illud, nescio an satis, circumcisum tamen et adrasum est, i. e. <hi rend="ital">if it be not yet completed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">still it is nearly so</hi> (the fig. is prob. derived from sculpture), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 2, 12</bibl> Keil.</sense></entryFree>
adramytteos: <entryFree id="n990" type="main" key="Adra^mytte_os"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Adrămyttēos, Adrămyttēum</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Adrămyttĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)adramu/tteion</foreign>, <sense id="n990.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a maritime town in Mysia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not far from the foot of Ida</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Adramyti</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:18:2" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 18, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 30, 32, § 112</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 28, 68</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:19:8 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 19, 8 al.</bibl>; hence: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Adrămyttēnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>: <cit><quote lang="la">homo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 13, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Xenocles,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:91:316" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 91, 316</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adrana: <entryFree id="n991" type="main" key="Adra^na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Adrăna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n991.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river of Hesse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in Germany</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">the Eder</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 56</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adrastea: <entryFree id="n992" type="main" key="A_^draste_a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^drastēa</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^drastīa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)adra/steia</foreign>. <sense id="n992.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The daughter of Jupiter and Necessity</hi> (so called from an altar erected to her by Adrastus), <hi rend="ital">the goddess who rewards men for their deeds</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and who esp. punishes pride and arrogance</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod nec sinit Adrastea,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Verg.</author> Cir. 239</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ineffugibilis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> de Mund. p. 75</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 11</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n992.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A city of Mysia</hi>, late<hi rend="ital">r</hi> called Parium, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:141" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 32, 40, § 141</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:11:6:10" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 11, 6, 10</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adrasteus: <entryFree id="n993" type="main" key="A_^draste_us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^drastēus</orth> <itype>a, um</itype>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ādrastīus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n993.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to Adrastus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Arion,</quote> <trans><tr>the horse given to Adrastus by Neptune</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:1:1:52" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 1, 1, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Adrasteo pallore perfusus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 11</bibl></cit> (with ref. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:480" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 480</bibl>; cf. Adrastus).</sense></entryFree>
adrastis: <entryFree id="n994" type="main" key="A_^drastis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^drastis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <sense id="n994.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">patr. f.</hi>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)adrasti/s</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">a female descendant of Adrastus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Creon Adrastida leto Admovet,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Argia</tr>, <tr>daughter of Adrastus</tr>, <tr>and wife of Polynices</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:12:678" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 12, 678</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adrastus: <entryFree id="n995" type="main" key="A_^drastus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^drastus</orth>, i. <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/adrastos</foreign>, <sense id="n995.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">king of Argos</hi>, <hi rend="ital">father-in-law of Tydeus and Polynices</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who</hi>, <hi rend="ital">acc. to the fable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">saw them both die</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and turned so pale from grief that he never recovered his former complexion;</hi> hence: <cit><quote lang="la">pallor Adrasti,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Verg.</author> 6, 480</bibl></cit> Serv.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:1:3:79" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 1, 3, 79</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:6:433" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 6, 433</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:74 al" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 4, 74 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
adrasus: <entryFree id="n996" type="main" key="adra_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adrāsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of adrado.</entryFree>
adrectarius: <entryFree id="n997" type="main" key="adrecta_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adrectārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. arrectarius.</entryFree>
adrectus: <entryFree id="n998" type="main" key="adrectus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adrectus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">arr-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, v. arrigo.</entryFree>
adremigo: <entryFree id="n999" type="main" key="adre_mi^go"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-rēmĭgo</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n999.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to row to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">toward</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">litori classis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1:18:4" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 1, 18, 4</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:3:7:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 7, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:8:12" default="NO">2, 8, 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adria: <entryFree id="n1000" type="main" key="A_^dria"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ā^dria, Ā^driăcus, Ā^driānus</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Ā^driātĭcus</orth>, etc., v. Hadria, etc.</entryFree>
adroro: <entryFree id="n1001" type="main" key="adro_ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-rōro</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>ros</etym>, <sense id="n1001.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to bedew</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">herbam vino,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Marc. Emp.</author> 34</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adrumetum: <entryFree id="n1002" type="main" key="Adru_me_tum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Adrūmētum</orth>, v. Hadrum-.</entryFree>
adrumo: <entryFree id="n1003" type="gloss" key="adru_mo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-rūmo</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, acc. to Fest., <sense id="n1003.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make a noise</hi>: quod verbum quidam a rumine,<cb n="ADSU" />  id est parte gutturis, putant deduci, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=9" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 9</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
adruo: <entryFree id="n1004" type="hapax" key="adru^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-rŭo</orth>, <itype>ĕre, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n1004.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to scrape up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to heap up</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">terra adruenda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:35" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 35</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adsc: <entryFree id="n1005" type="main" key="adsc"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adsc-</orth>. Words beginning thus, v. under asc-.</entryFree>
adse: <entryFree id="n1006" type="main" key="adse"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adse-, adsi-, adso-</orth>. Words beginning thus, v. under asse-, assi-, asso-.</entryFree>
adsp: <entryFree id="n1007" type="main" key="adsp"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adsp-</orth>. Words beginning thus, v. under asp-.</entryFree>
adst: <entryFree id="n1008" type="main" key="adst"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adst-</orth>. Words beginning thus, v. under ast-.</entryFree>
adsu: <entryFree id="n1009" type="main" key="adsu"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adsu-</orth>. Words beginning thus not found here, v. under assu-.</entryFree>
adsum: <entryFree id="n1010" type="main" key="adsum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-sum</orth> (Ribbeck has written <sense id="n1010.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">assum</hi> in Novius by conj. from <hi rend="ital">suum</hi> of the MSS., Com. Trag. p. 262; in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 67</bibl>, <hi rend="ital">adsum</hi> must be pronounced <hi rend="ital">assum</hi>, as the pun on the word requires, Roby, I. p. 49), adfui (affui, Merkel, L. Müller), <itype>adesse</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> (arfui = adfui, S. C. de Bacch.; arf = adfuerunt, ib.; arfuise = adfuisse, ib.; v. ad <hi rend="ital">init.</hi>; <cit><quote lang="la">adsiem = adsim,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Verg.</author> Cat. 5, 6</bibl></cit> (<hi rend="ital">dicam</hi>, Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">adsiet,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 141, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:4:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 4, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:4:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 4, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adsient,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:18:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phorm. 2, 18, 3</bibl></cit>: adfore now and then takes the place of adfuturus esse, and adforem of adessem, which is written with one s, adesent, in S. C. de Bacch.), <hi rend="ital">to be at</hi> or <hi rend="ital">near</hi> a person or place, <hi rend="ital">to be</hi> somewhere, <hi rend="ital">to be present</hi> (opp. absum, to be distant, removed, absent). </sense><sense id="n1010.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1010.2" n="(a)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: visus Homerus adesse poëta, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 16, 51</bibl> (Ann. v. 6 Vahl.), imitated by <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:271" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 271</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:635" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 635</bibl>; v. below: Hegio adsum; <cit><quote lang="la">si quid me vis, impera,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:5:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 5, 3, 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:6:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 2, 6, 33</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 3, 52</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quasi adfuerim simulabo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 1, 1, 45</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n1010.3" n="(b)" level="5"> With <pos>adv.</pos> or <pos>adj.</pos>: <cit><quote lang="la">etsi abest, hic adesse erum Arbitror,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:7:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 4, 7, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Philolaches jam hic aderit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:5:1:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 5, 1, 29</bibl></cit>; and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:2:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 2, 48</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod adest praesto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1412" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1412</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut quasi coram adesse videare, cum scribo aliquid ad te,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:15:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 15, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:18:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 5, 18, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:595" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 595</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non quia ades praesens dico hoc,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:3:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 3, 39</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1010.4" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">prepp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad exercitum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 3, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in tabernaculo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 1, 269</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adsum apud te,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:2:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 1, 2, 67</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mulier ad eam rem divinam ne adsit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 83</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad portam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:27:57" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 27, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ante oculos maestissimus Hector Visus adesse mihi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:271" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 271</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ante oculos eadem mihi quercus adesse ... visa est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:635" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 635</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n1010.5" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adsum praesens praesenti tibi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:5:1:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 5, 1, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">DVM. NE. MINVS. SENATORIBVS. C. ADESENT. S. C. de Bacch. (see Append. to this dictionary): portis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:330" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 330</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">senatui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">convivio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:61" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 61 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quaestioni,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 62</bibl></cit>: pugnae. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Oth. 9</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n1010.6" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1010.7" n="A" level="2"> Of time, <hi rend="ital">to be present</hi>, <hi rend="ital">be at hand</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dum tempestates adsunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:178" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 178</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Vesper adest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:62:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 62, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jamque dies aderit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:519" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 519</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">9, 285</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">12, 150</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aderat judicio dies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum jam partus adesset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:674" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 674</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1010.8" n="B" level="2"> Of other abstr. things, <hi rend="ital">to be present</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be at hand</hi> (incorrectly made syn. with the simple esse). </sense><sense id="n1010.9" n="(a)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc adest occasio benefacta cumulare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:3:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 3, 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad narrandum argumentum adest benignitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:prol. 16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. prol. 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia adsunt bona, quem penes est virtus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 2, 2, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut tranquillitas animi et securitas adsit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tanti aderant morbi vesicae et viscerum, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:30" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 2, 30</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1010.10" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hominum quīs pudor paulum adest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 1, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vigilantibus hinc aderant solacia somni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1405" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1405</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vis ad resistendum nulli aderat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:61" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 61</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:21" default="NO">2, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vim adfore verbo Crediderat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:547" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 547</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tantus decor adfuit arti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">simplicitas puerilibus adfuit annis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:5:400" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 400</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quantus adest equis Sudor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:15:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 15, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">uti mox Nulla fides damnis adsit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 17, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quousque patieris, Caesar, non adesse caput reipublicae?</quote> <trans><tr>to be in his place</tr>, <tr>to be present</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 13</bibl></cit> et saep.—</sense><sense id="n1010.11" n="C" level="2"> Animo or animis, <hi rend="ital">to be present in mind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with attention</hi>, <hi rend="ital">interest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sympathy;</hi> also, <hi rend="ital">with courage</hi> (cf. animus); <hi rend="ital">to give attention to</hi> something, <hi rend="ital">to give heed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">observe</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attend to;</hi> also, <hi rend="ital">to be fearless</hi>, <hi rend="ital">be of good courage</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut intellegeretis eum non adfuisse animo, oum ab illis causa ageretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:chapter=10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 10 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adestote omnes animis, qui adestis corporibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:11:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 11, 33</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:8:10:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 8, 10, 30</bibl> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:prol. 24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. prol. 24</bibl>, and Phorm. prol. 30: adeste aequo animo):<pb n="46" /> <cb n="ADUL" />  quam ob rem adeste animis, judices, et timorem, si quem habetis, deponite, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 2, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ades animo et omitte timorem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 6, 10 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1010.12" n="D" level="2"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to be present with</hi> one, <hi rend="ital">to be associated with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to attend</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Tu ducibus Latiis aderis, cum laeta Triumphum Vox canet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:560" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 560</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">of the cypress: aderis dolentibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:10:142" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 142</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n1010.13" n="E" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To be present with one's aid</hi> or <hi rend="ital">support; to stand by</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to assist</hi>, <hi rend="ital">aid</hi>, <hi rend="ital">help</hi>, <hi rend="ital">protect</hi>, <hi rend="ital">defend</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sustain</hi> (esp. freq. of advocati; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">absum): ibo ad forum atque aliquot mihi amicos advocabo, ad hanc rem qui adsient,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:1:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 2, 1, 82</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:6:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 4, 6, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes enim hi, quos videtis adesse in hac causa, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:chapter=29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:37:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 37, 95</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:4" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:30" default="NO">8, 30</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">ego tamen tuis rebus sic adero ut difficillimis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 6, 14 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Camulogenus suis aderat atque eos cohortabatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dictator intercessioni adero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cui sententiae adest Dicaearchus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:65:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 65, 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aderam Arrionillae, Timonis uxori,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:1:5:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 1, 5, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:11:2" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 11, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod ille adversus privatum se intemperantius adfuisset,</quote> <trans><tr>had taken part</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:38" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 38</bibl></cit> Bremi.—With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">non Teucros delere aderam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:9:532" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 9, 532</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so of a protecting, aiding divinity, esp. in invocations, adsis, adsit, etc.: adsis, o Tegeaee, favens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:578" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 4, 578</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adsis, o Cytherea,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Cat. 6, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ades, Dea, muneris auctor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:673" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 673</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">Huc ades,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:7:49" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 7, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">di omnes nemorum, adeste,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:198" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 198</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nostris querelis adsint (dii),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">frugumque aderit mea Delia custos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:5:21" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 5, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si vocata partubus Lucina veris adfuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:5:6" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 5, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">origini Romanae et deos adfuisse et non defuturam virtutem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:51 al" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 51 al.</bibl>—<hi rend="ital">To be present</hi> as a witness: <cit><quote lang="la">(testes) adsunt cum adversariis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 23</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">promissi testis adesto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 45</bibl></cit>; hence the t. t. scribendo adesse, <hi rend="ital">to be present as a witness to some writing</hi> or <hi rend="ital">contract</hi> (usually placed at the beginning of the writing), S. C. de Bacch. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:8:8:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 8, 8, 5</bibl> and 6 al.— </sense><sense id="n1010.14" n="F" level="1"> Involving the idea of motion, <hi rend="ital">to come</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to appear</hi> (most freq. in post-Aug. prose): adsum atque advenio Acherunte, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:16:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 16, 37</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">jam ego hic adero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 3, 7</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:2:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 2, 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:1:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 3, 1, 96</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:7:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 4, 7, 41</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hi ex Africa jam adfuturi videntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:11:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 11, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Hymen ades o Hymenaee,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:62:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 62, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Galli per dumos aderant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:657" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 657</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">11, 100</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">huc ades, o formose puer,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:2:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> E. 2, 45</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">7, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:598" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 598</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 513</bibl> (cf. also adesdum): <cit><quote lang="la">ecce Arcas adest,</quote> <trans><tr>appears</tr>, <tr>is arrived</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:2:497" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 497</bibl></cit>; so 3, 102; 528; 4, 692; 5, 46; 8, 418; 9, 200, 304, 363, 760; 11, 349; 12, 341; <cit><quote lang="la">13, 73, 82, 662, 906: adfore tempus, quo, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:1:256" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 256</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">cum hostes adessent, i. e. appropinquarent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">truci clamore aderant semisomnos in barbaros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">infensi adesse et instare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod serius adfuisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:94 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 94 al.</bibl></cit>—In App. with <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cubiculum adero, Met. 2, p. 119 Elm.: scopulum aderunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 5, p. 160</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1010.15" n="G" level="1"> As judicial t. t., <hi rend="ital">to appear</hi> before a tribunal: <cit><quote lang="la">C. Verrem altera actione responsurum non esse, neque ad judicium adfuturum ... quod iste certe statuerat non adesse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">augures adsunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:chapter=34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Dom. 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">augurem adesse jusserunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:10" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 10</bibl></cit>; cf. Brisson. de Form. V. p. 446.—</sense><sense id="n1010.16" n="H" level="1"> Of the senate, <hi rend="ital">to attend</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to convene</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">edixit ut adesset senatus frequens a. d. viii. Kal. Decembris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:3:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 3, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne sine causa videretur edixisse, ut senatus adcsset,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 24</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adt: <entryFree id="n1011" type="main" key="adt"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adt-</orth>. Words beginning thus, v. under att-.</entryFree>
aduatuca: <entryFree id="n1012" type="main" key="Adu^a_tu^ca"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Adŭātŭca</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> in the Tab. Peuting, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aduaca</orth>, <sense id="n1012.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a fortress in the country of the Eburones</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the Netherlands</hi>, <hi rend="ital">between Maestricht and Louvain</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Tongres</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 32</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aduatuci: <entryFree id="n1013" type="main" key="Adu^a_tu^ci"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Adŭātŭci</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Adŭātĭci</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1013.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people of Cimbrian origin in</hi> Gallia Belgica, whose capital, acc. to D'Anville, was Falais sur la Mehaigne (acc. to Reich. Orb. Antiq. this town was i. q. Aduatuca), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 16, 29 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
adulabilis: <entryFree id="n1014" type="main" key="a^du_la_bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădūlābĭlis</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">adōl-</orth>), <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>adulor</etym>, <sense id="n1014.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">suited to flatter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">flattering</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adulatory</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sermo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sententia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 31, 12</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 155, 30</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adulans: <entryFree id="n1015" type="main" key="a^du_lans"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădūlans</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, v. <itype>adulor</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> <cb n="ADUL" /></entryFree>
adulanter: <entryFree id="n1016" type="main" key="a^du_lanter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădūlanter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. <itype>adulor</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos></entryFree>
adulatio: <entryFree id="n1017" type="main" key="a^du_la_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădūlātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>adulor</etym>, <sense id="n1017.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a fawning</hi>, <hi rend="ital">like that of a dog</hi> (adulatio est blandimentum proprie canum, quod et ad homines tractum consuetudine est, <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 17, 4</bibl>).—In the post-Aug. historians, esp. in Tac., very freq. for a servile respect exhibited by bowing the body = adoratio. </sense><sense id="n1017.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">canum tam fida custodia tamque amans dominorum adulatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:63" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 63</bibl></cit>.—So of doves, <hi rend="ital">a billing</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 34, 52, § 104</bibl>.—Of men toward animals, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:2:5" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 2, 5</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1017.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">low</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cringing flattery</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adulation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in amicitiis nullam pestem esse majorem quam adulationem, blanditiam, assentationem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:25:91" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 25, 91</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pars altera regiae adulationis (i. e. adulatorum) erat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">humi jacentium adulationes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:9:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 9, 18</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:6" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 6</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:13:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 13, 14</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 32</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 2</bibl>; 4, 6; 5, 7; 15, 59; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 8</bibl>, etc.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:53" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 53</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:41:3 al" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 41, 3 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
adulator: <entryFree id="n1018" type="main" key="a^du_la_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădūlātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1018.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a low</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cringing flatterer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a sycophant</hi> (homo fallax et levis, ad voluptatem facit ac dicit omnia, nihil ad veritatem, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:25:91" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 25, 91</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 25, 93</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">nolo esse laudator, ne videar adulator,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 4, 21</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10:13" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 10, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vit.:1" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vit. 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">versabilium adulatorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 11, 2</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adulatorius: <entryFree id="n1019" type="main" key="a^du_la_to_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădūlātōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>adulator</etym>, <sense id="n1019.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">flattering</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adulatory</hi> (rare): <cit><quote lang="la">dedecus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 32</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">fin.—Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădūlātōrĭē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">flatteringly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fawningly</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">agere rem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>August.</author> Ep. 148</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adulatrix: <entryFree id="n1020" type="main" key="a^du_la_trix"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădūlātrix</orth>, <itype>īcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1020.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a female flatterer</hi>: adulatrices exterae gentes, Treb. Poll. <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> 3</bibl>; so tert. Anim. 51.</sense></entryFree>
adulescens: <entryFree id="n1021" type="main" key="a^du^lescens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŭlescens</orth> (only <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŏl-</orth> in the <sense id="n1021.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">verb</hi> and <hi rend="ital">part. proper</hi>), entis (<hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> usu. adulescentium, e. g. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:27 al" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 27 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adulescentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:3:130" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 3, 130</bibl></cit>). </sense><sense id="n1021.1" n="A" level="2"> <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">growing up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not yet come to full growth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">young</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">eodem ut jure uti senem liceat, quo jure sum usus adulescentior, Ter. Hec. prol. alt. 3: uti adulescentior aetati concederet, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:H. 1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> H. 1, 11</bibl></cit> (Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 902</bibl>).— <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of the new Academic philosophy: <cit><quote lang="la">adulescentior Academia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 8, 1</bibl></cit>.— <hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi> and <pos>adv.</pos> not used.—</sense><sense id="n1021.2" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Subst. comm. gen.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">one who has not yet attained maturity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a youth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a young man; a young woman</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a maiden</hi> (between the puer and juvenis, from the 15th or 17th until past the 30th year, often even until near the 40th; but the same person is often called in one place <hi rend="ital">adulescens</hi>, and in another <hi rend="ital">juvenis</hi>, e. g. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 1</bibl>, with <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:2:12" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> 2, 12</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:Top. 7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Top. 7</bibl>; often the <hi rend="ital">adulescentia</hi> passes beyond the period of manhood, even to <hi rend="ital">senectus;</hi> while in other cases adulescentia is limited to 25 years, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:1:2" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 1, 2</bibl> Goer.: “Primo gradu usque ad annum XV. pueros dictos, quod sint puri, i. e. impubes. Secundo ad XXX. annum ab adolescendo sic nominatos,” Varr. ap. Censor. cap. 14. “Tertia (aetas) adulescentia ad gignendum adulta, quae porrigitur (ab anno XIV.) usque ad vigesimum octavum annum,” <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 11, 2, 4</bibl>. Thus Cicero, in de Or. 2, 2, calls Crassus adulescens, though he was 34 years old; in <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 44</bibl>, Brutus and Cassius, when in their 40th year, are called adulescentes; and in <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 46</bibl>, Cicero calls himself, at the time of his consulship, i. e. in his 44th year, adulescens; cf. Manut. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:1, p. 146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 1, p. 146</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">tute me ut fateare faciam esse adulescentem moribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 67</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bonus adulescens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:7:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 7, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adulescentes bonā indole praediti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:8:26" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 8, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adulescens luxu perditus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:7:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 7, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adulescens perditus et dissolutus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:25" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 25</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:34:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 34, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:19:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 19, 20</bibl>.—Homo and adulescens are often used together: <cit><quote lang="la">amanti homini adulescenti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:2:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 4, 2, 94</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:9:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 5, 9, 53</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc se labore durant homines adulescentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B.
