G. 6, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 38</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> J. 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 6</bibl>.— <hi rend="ital">Fem.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">optimae adulescenti facere injuriam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 2, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Africani filia adulescens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 18 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit> The young Romans who attended the proconsuls and propraetors in the provinces were sometimes called <hi rend="ital">adulescentes</hi> (commonly <hi rend="ital">contubernales</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 23</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 51</bibl>. Sometimes adulescens serves to distinguish <hi rend="ital">the younger</hi> of two persons of the same name: <cit><quote lang="la">Brutus adulescens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 87</bibl></cit>: P. <cb n="ADUL" /> Crassus adulescens, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 52</bibl>, and 3, 7: <cit><quote lang="la">L. Caesar adulescens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 1, 8</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adulescentia: <entryFree id="n1022" type="main" key="a^du^lescenti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŭlescentĭa</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŏl-</orth>), ae. <gen>f.</gen> <etym>adulescens</etym>, <sense id="n1022.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the age of the</hi> adulescens, <hi rend="ital">the time between the age of the</hi> puer and juvenis, i. e. <hi rend="ital">from the 15th to the 30th year</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the time of youth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">youth</hi>, = <foreign lang="greek">e)fhbi/a, h(liki/a</foreign> (cf. adulescens): <cit><quote lang="la">quid enim? Citius adulescentiae senectus quam pueritiae adulescentia obrepit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:chapter=2" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui adulescentiam florem aetatis, senectutem occasum vitae velit definire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:7:32" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Top. 7, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nemo adulescentiam tuam contemnat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,015:4:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Tim. 4, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ineunte adulescentia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:32" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam a prima adulescentia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 9 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ab adulescentia sua,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:8:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 8, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in adulescentia = adulescens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:41" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 41</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adulescentior: <entryFree id="n1023" type="hapax" key="a^du^lescenti^or"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŭlescentĭor</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŏl-</orth>), <itype>āri</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1023.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to behave like an</hi> adulescens: tu adhuc adulescentiaris, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 71, 30</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adulescentula: <entryFree id="n1024" type="main" key="a^du^lescentu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŭlescentŭla</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŏl-</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1024.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a very young maiden;</hi> also as a term of endearment for an adult: <cit><quote lang="la">salveto, adulescentula,</quote> <trans><tr>good morrow</tr>, <tr>my child</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 4, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:91" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 91</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adulescentula speciosa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,013:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 3 Reg. 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adulescentula virgo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adulescentulae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,017:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Tit. 2, 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adulescentulus: <entryFree id="n1025" type="main" key="a^du^lescentu^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŭlescentŭlus</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŏl-</orth>), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1025.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a very young man</hi>, = <foreign lang="greek">neani/skos</foreign> (when 27 years old, Cicero calls himself adulescentulus, Or. 30; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:15:28" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 15, 28</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:6" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 6</bibl>. So <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 49</bibl> calls Cæsar adulescentulus, although he was then 33, or perhaps 35 years old): <cit><quote lang="la">neque admodum adulescentulust,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0112,001:Com. Rel. p. 11" default="NO"><author>Naev.</author> Com. Rel. p. 11</bibl></cit> Rib.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0112,001:ib" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl> p. 29: <cit><quote lang="la">Rhodius adulescentulus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:3:1:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 3, 1, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">modestissimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:chapter=11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 11</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:4:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 4, 23</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adulescentulus et virgo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,053:9:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Ezech. 9, 6</bibl></cit>.—Also, <hi rend="ital">a young soldier</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a recruit</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:1:15" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 1, 15</bibl> B.; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,004:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Paus. 4</bibl> and Ham. 1. Sometimes it indicates contempt: Proveniebant oratores novi, stulti adulescentuli, Naev. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:6:20" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Sen. 6, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">imberbis adulescentulus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:chapter=14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Dom. 14</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adulescenturio: <entryFree id="n1026" type="hapax" key="a^du^lescentu_ri^o_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŭlescentūrĭō</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădŏl-</orth>), <itype>īre</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1026.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to behave like an</hi> adulescens: incipio adulescenturire et nescio quid nuga rum facere, Laber. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 74</bibl> 15 Com Rel. p. 299 Rib.).</sense></entryFree>
adulo: <entryFree id="n1027" type="main" key="a^du_lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădūlo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (a rare form for adulor; hence <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 791</bibl> P. ranks this form, as an exception, among the other active forms of the deponents, adipiscor, admiror, auxilior, etc.; cf. Don. p. 1756 P. and Ars <bibl default="NO"><author>Consent.</author> p. 2054</bibl> P.), <sense id="n1027.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to fawn like a dog</hi>: (canes) gannitu vocis adulant, Luor. 5, 1070: caudā nostrum adulat sanguinem (<hi rend="ital">the eagle</hi>), <hi rend="ital">strokes</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">wipes off our blood</hi>, Cic. poët. ap. Tusc. 2, 10, 24, as trans. of Aeschyl. Prometh. Solut.: <cit><quote lang="la">Dionysium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:4:3" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 4, 3</bibl></cit>, ext. 4.—<hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be flattered</hi> nec adulari nos sinamus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:26:91" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 26, 91</bibl>: tribunus militum adulandus erat, Val. M. 2, 7, 15: adulati erant ab amicis, Cass. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 791</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
adulor: <entryFree id="n1028" type="main" key="a^du_lor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădūlor</orth>, <itype>ātus, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>acc. to Lobeck, the -ulo, -ulor is connected with <foreign lang="greek">i)/llein</foreign> (cf. <foreign lang="greek">ei)lu/w, e)lu/w</foreign>, and volvo), and thus denoted orig. the wagging of the tail and fawning of brutes; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=21" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 21</bibl> Müll., thought adulor was a form of adludo, to play with; cf. Ger. wedeln and Eng. to wheedle</etym>, <sense id="n1028.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to cling to one fawningly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to fawn as a dog;</hi> and trop., of cringing flattery, which is exhibited in words and actions, <hi rend="ital">to flatter in a cringing manner</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to fawn upon</hi> (while <hi rend="ital">assentari</hi> signified to yield to one in everything, to assent to what he says, and is used only of men; and <hi rend="ital">blandiri</hi>, to be soft and pleasing in manner, to flatter by honeyed words as well as by captivating manners; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:chapter=25" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 25</bibl>).— Constr. with <case>acc.</case>, more rarely with <case>dat.</case>, Rudd. II. p. 136; Zumpt, § 389. </sense><sense id="n1028.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">ferarum Agmen adulantum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quin etiam blandas movere per aëra caudas, Nostraque adulantes comitant vestigia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:14:257" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 14, 257</bibl></cit>. caudam more adulantium canum blande movet, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:5:14" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 5, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hi (canes) furem quoque adulantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:7:12" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 7, 12</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Meton.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">horrentem, trementem, adulantem omnīs videre te volui: vidi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aperte adulantem nemo non videt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:chapter=26" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aut adulatus aut admiratus fortunam sum alterius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:2:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 2, 6</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">Liv 45, 31: quemcunque principem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Neronem aut Tigellium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:16:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 16, 19</bibl></cit>: dominum, Sen. de Ira, 2, 31; Nep., Liv., and Curt. have the <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: Antonio, Nep. <pb n="47" /> <cb n="ADUL" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0400,001:8" default="NO"><author>Att.</author> 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">praesentibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 36, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">singulis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:1:19" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 1, 19</bibl></cit>.—In the time of Quint. the use of the <case>dat.</case> was predominant: <hi rend="ital">huic</hi> non <hi rend="ital">hunc</hi> adulari jam dicitur, 9, 3, 1; yet Tac. preferred the <case>acc.</case>, v. the passages cited above.—</sense><sense id="n1028.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. of the servile reverence paid to Asiatic kings, <foreign lang="greek">proskunei=n</foreign>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">adulatio: more adulantium procubuerunt: conveniens oratio tam humili adulationi fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">more Persarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:4:7" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 4, 7</bibl></cit>, ext. 2; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:ib. 6:3" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 3</bibl>, ext. 2.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădū-lans</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">flattering</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adulatory</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">verba,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:26" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid adulantius?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 1, 27</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi> is wanting.—* <hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădūlanter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">flatteringly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fawningly</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Fulg.</author> Contin. Verg. p. 153</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adulter: <entryFree id="n1029" type="main" key="a^dulter1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ulter</orth>, <itype>ĕri</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, and <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădultĕra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>alter, acc. to Fest.: adulter et adultera dicuntur, quia et ille ad alteram et haec ad alterum se conferunt, p. 22 Müll.</etym>, orig. <sense id="n1029.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who approaches another</hi> (<hi rend="ital">from unlawful</hi> or <hi rend="ital">criminal love</hi>), <hi rend="ital">an adulterer</hi> or <hi rend="ital">adulteress</hi> (as an <pos>adj.</pos> also, but only in the poets). </sense><sense id="n1029.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop.: <cit><quote lang="la">quis ganeo, quis nepos, quis adulter, quae mulier infamis, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sororis adulter Clodius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:chapter=39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 39</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:20:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 20, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:22:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Deut. 22, 22</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adultera,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:3:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 3, 25</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:347" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 347</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:10:104" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 10, 104</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:24" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:22:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Deut. 22, 22</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and with mulier: via mulieris adulterae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,029:30:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Prov. 30, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,053:16:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Ezech. 16, 32</bibl>.—Also of animals: <cit><quote lang="la">adulter,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Grat.</author> Cyneg. 164</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Cons. Mall. Theod. 304</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adultera,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 16, 17, § 43</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg> in gen. of unlawful love, without the access. idea of adultery, <hi rend="ital">a paramour</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Danaën munierant satis nocturnis ab adulteris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:16:1 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 16, 1 sq.</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 36, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:338" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Ib. 338</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1029.2" n="II" level="1"> Adulter solidorum, i. e. monetae, <hi rend="ital">a counterfeiter</hi> or <hi rend="ital">adulterator of coin</hi>, Const. 5, Cod. Th.—</sense><sense id="n1029.3" n="III" level="1"> The offspring of unlawful love: nothus, <hi rend="ital">a bastard</hi> (eccl.): <cit><quote lang="la">adulteri et non filii estis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,019:12:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Heb. 12, 8</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1030" type="main" key="a^dulter2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădulter, -tĕra</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">-tĕrum</orth>, <pos>adj.</pos> (Rudd. I. p. 51, n. 36), for adulterinus, <sense id="n1030.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adulterous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unchaste</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">crines,</quote> <trans><tr>finely-curled hair</tr>, <tr>like that of a full-dressed paramour</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:15:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 15, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mens,</quote> <trans><tr>that thinks only of illicit love</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:4:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 3, 4, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">clavis,</quote> <trans><tr>a key to the chamber of a courtesan</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:643" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. A. 3, 643</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n1030.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">counterfeit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">false</hi>: imitatio solidi, Cod. Th. 9, 22, 1.</sense></entryFree>
adulteratio: <entryFree id="n1031" type="main" key="a^dulte^ra_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădultĕrātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>adultero</etym>, <sense id="n1031.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an adulteration</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sophistication</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">croci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 6, 17, § 32</bibl></cit>; so prooem. 1, 2.</sense></entryFree>
adulterator: <entryFree id="n1032" type="main" key="a^dulte^ra_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădultĕrātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1032.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a counterfeiter</hi>: monetae, Cod. Th. 11, 21, 1; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:48:19:16" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 48, 19, 16 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
adulteratrix: <entryFree id="n1033" type="main" key="a^dulte^ra_trix"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădultĕrātrix</orth>, <itype>īcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = adultera, Gloss. Gr. Lat. as trans. of <foreign lang="greek">moixali/s</foreign>.</entryFree>
adulterinus: <entryFree id="n1034" type="main" key="a^dulte^ri_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădultĕrīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>adulter</etym>. <sense id="n1034.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Adulterous</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">liberi adulterino sanguinen nati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 2, 2, § 14</bibl></cit>; and of animals, <hi rend="ital">not full-blooded</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pullus adulterinus et degener,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 10, 3, 3, § 10</bibl></cit>.—But oftener, </sense><sense id="n1034.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">That has assumed the nature of something foreign</hi> (cf. the etym. of adulter), <hi rend="ital">not genuine</hi>, <hi rend="ital">false</hi>, <hi rend="ital">counterfeit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">impure</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">symbolum,</quote> <trans><tr>a false seal</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 2, 3</bibl></cit>. 32; cf. Paul. ex Fest. p 28 Müll.: adulterina signa dicuntur alienis anulis facta; <cit><quote lang="la">and Cic.: testamentum signis adulterinis obsignare, Clu. 14: nummus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">semina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:40" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">claves,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 12</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adulterio: <entryFree id="n1035" type="main" key="a^dulte^ri^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădultĕrĭo</orth>, ōnis. A word formed by Laberius = adulter, acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 70, 5</bibl>; or adulterium, acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:7" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 16, 7</bibl>, the latter of whom censures this form.</entryFree>
adulteritas: <entryFree id="n1036" type="main" key="a^dulte^ri^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădultĕrĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, = adulterium, Laber. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:7" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 16, 7</bibl>.</entryFree>
adulterium: <entryFree id="n1037" type="main" key="a^dulte^ri^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădultĕrĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>adulter</etym>. <sense id="n1037.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Adultery</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Adulterium est cum aliena uxore coire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:3:10" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 3, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui in adulterio deprehenditur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:68:275" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 68, 275</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mulierem in adulterio deprehensam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:8:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Joan. 8, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum aliqua facere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:67:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 67, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:45" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adulteria exercere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:69" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adulterio cognoscere alicujus uxorem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:22:1" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 22, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vasa adulteriis caelata,</quote> <trans><tr>decorated with immodest figures</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:140" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 22, 28, § 140</bibl></cit>.—Of brutes: <cit><quote lang="la">nec (elephanti) adulteria novere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 5, 5, § 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 10, 34, 52, § 104</bibl>.—Of plants, <hi rend="ital">an ingrafling</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inoculating</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 5, 266</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1037.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Adulteration</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia in adulterium mellis excogitata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 9, 11, § 80</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mercis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 19, 3, 15, § 44</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adultero: <entryFree id="n1038" type="main" key="a^dulte^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădultĕro</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> and <sense id="n1038.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a.</hi> [id.], <hi rend="ital">to commit adultery</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to pollute</hi>, <hi rend="ital">defile.</hi> <cb n="ADUN" /> </sense><sense id="n1038.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> or with <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">latrocinari, fraudare, adulterare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:35" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jus esset latrocinari: jus adulterare: jus testamenta falsa supponere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> de Leg. 16, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui dimissam duxerit, adulterat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:5:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 5, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">matronas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:67" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 67</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Caes. 6</bibl>.—Also of brutes: <cit><quote lang="la">adulteretur et columba milvio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:16:32" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 16, 32</bibl></cit>.—As <hi rend="ital">verb. neutr.</hi> of a woman: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Graeco adulescente,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:43:4" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 43, 4</bibl></cit>.—Freq., </sense><sense id="n1038.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">to falsify</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adulterate</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">give a foreign nature to a thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to counterfeit</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">laser adulteratum cummi aut sacopenio aut fabā fractā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 3, 15, § 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jus civile pecuniā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:chapter=26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">simulatio tollit judicium veri idque adulterat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:25:92" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 25, 92</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Part. 25, 90</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adulterantes verbum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,008:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Cor. 2, 17</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg> of Proteus: <cit><quote lang="la">faciem,</quote> <trans><tr>changes his form</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:373" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 373</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adultus: <entryFree id="n1039" type="main" key="a^dultus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădultus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, from adolesco.</entryFree>
adumbratim: <entryFree id="n1040" type="hapax" key="a^dumbra_tim"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădumbrātim</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>adumbro</etym>, <sense id="n1040.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sketched in shadow</hi>, à la silhouette, <hi rend="ital">in general</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in outline</hi> (opp. adamussim): <cit><quote lang="la">quasi adumbratim paulum simulata videntur,</quote> <trans><tr>as it were covered with shadows</tr>, <tr>dimly resembling</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:363" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 363</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adumbratio: <entryFree id="n1041" type="main" key="a^dumbra_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădumbrātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1041.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a sketch in shadow</hi>, à la silhouette, <hi rend="ital">a perspective sketch</hi> or <hi rend="ital">draft</hi> (cf. adumbro). </sense><sense id="n1041.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">scenographia est frontis et laterum abscedentium adumbratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 1, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1041.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">a sketch</hi>, <hi rend="ital">outline</hi>: nulla est laus oratoris, cujus in nostris orationibus non sit aliqua, si non perfectio, at conatus tamen atque adumbratio, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:chapter=29" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 29</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1041.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A false show</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the semblance of a thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pretence</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">insidiosa beneficii adumbratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:7:3:8" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 7, 3, 8</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:14:44" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 14, 44</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adumbro: <entryFree id="n1042" type="main" key="a^dumbro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-umbro</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n1042.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to bring a shadow over a thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to cast a shadow on</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to shade or overshadow by something.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1042.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen. </sense><sense id="n1042.2" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, constr.: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid aliqua re (so only in later authors): palmeis tegetibus vineas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:5:5" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 5, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adumbrantur stramentis uvae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:11:2:61" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 11, 2, 61</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1042.3" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut notae quoque litterarum, non adumbratae comarum praesidio, totae ad oculos legentium accederent,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> Sat. 105</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1042.4" n="II" level="1"> Esp. in painting, <hi rend="ital">to shade</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to represent an object with the due mingling of light and shade</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">skiagrafe/w</foreign> (therefore not of the sketch in shadow, as the first outline of a figure, but of a picture already fully sketched, and only wanting the last touches for its completion): <cit><quote lang="la">quis pictor omnia, quae in rerum natura sunt, adumbrare didicit?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:10:9" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 10, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quod pictor adumbrare non valuit, casus imitatus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:8:11" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 8, 11 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1042.5" n="B" level="2"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n1042.6" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To represent a thing in the appropriate manner</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo in genere orationis utrumque oratorem cognoveramus, id ipsum sumus in eorum sermone adumbrare conati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:22" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 5, 22</bibl>: rerum omnium quasi adumbratas intellegentias animo ac mente concipere, i. e. <hi rend="ital">preconceptions</hi>, <hi rend="ital">innate ideas</hi>, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">prolh/yeis</foreign>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 1, 20</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1042.7" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To represent a thing only in outline</hi>, and, consequently, <hi rend="ital">imperfectly</hi>: cedo mihi istorum adumbratorum deorum lineamenta atque formas, <hi rend="ital">these semblances</hi>, <hi rend="ital">outlines of deities</hi> (of the gods of Epicurus), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:27" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 27</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">consectatur nullam eminentem effigiem virtutis, sed adumbratam imaginem gloriae,</quote> <trans><tr>imperfectly represented</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 3, 2</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădumbrātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> </sense><sense id="n1042.8" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Delineated only in semblance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">counterfeited</hi>, <hi rend="ital">feigned</hi>, <hi rend="ital">false</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">comitia (opp. vera),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:12:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 12, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">indicium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:chapter=18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 18 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aeschrio, Pippae vir adumbratus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:33:section=77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 33, § 77</bibl></cit>: laetitia, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 31</bibl>.—Also, </sense><sense id="n1042.9" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Devised in darkness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dark</hi>, <hi rend="ital">secret</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fallaciae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 11</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi>, and <pos>adv.</pos> not used.</sense></entryFree>
adunatio: <entryFree id="n1043" type="main" key="a^du_na_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădūnātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (like the verb aduno, only in later authors), <sense id="n1043.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a making into one</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a uniting</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a union</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">e(/nwsis</foreign>, Cyp. Ep. 57 (60 Oxon.), 61 (62 ib.); <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> Ep. 4, 33</bibl> and 36.</sense></entryFree>
adunatus: <entryFree id="n1044" type="main" key="a^du_na_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădūnātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of aduno.</entryFree>
aduncitas: <entryFree id="n1045" type="main" key="a^dunci^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăduncĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aduncus</etym>, <sense id="n1045.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the curvature of a point inwards</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hookedness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">aduncity</hi>: rostrorum, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:47:122" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 47, 122</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">rostri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:97" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 27, 41, § 97</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:196" default="NO" valid="yes">10, 71, 91, § 196</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aduncus: <entryFree id="n1046" type="main" key="a^duncus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-uncus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1046.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">bent in the manner of a hook</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hooked</hi>: nasus, <hi rend="ital">a hooked</hi> or <hi rend="ital">aquiline nose</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:5:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 5, 5, 18</bibl> (on the contr. reduncus nasus, a snub or turned-up nose): serrula adunca ex omni parte dentium<cb n="ADVE" />  et tortuosa, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 48</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">corpuscula curvata et quasi adunca,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:24" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ungues,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 2, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">baculum aduncum tenens, quem lituum appellaverunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliis cornua adunca, aliis redunca,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 37, 45, § 125</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">magni praepes adunca Jovis,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the eagle</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:6:196" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 6, 196</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi>, and <pos>adv.</pos> not used.</sense></entryFree>
aduno: <entryFree id="n1047" type="main" key="a^du_no"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ūno</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n1047.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make one</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to unite</hi> (in Just. several times, elsewhere rare, except in the Chr. fathers): <cit><quote lang="la">cum adunata omnis classis esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:12" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 2, 12</bibl></cit>; so 7, 1; 15, 4; <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> 3, 29</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 10</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> Opif. D. 17 al.</bibl> (Non. reads also, in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:8:35" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 8, 35</bibl>, erroneously, adunatam for <hi rend="ital">adjunctam</hi>, B. and K.).</sense></entryFree>
adurgeo: <entryFree id="n1048" type="main" key="a^durge^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-urgĕo</orth>, <itype>ēre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n1048.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to press to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">close to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">press against.</hi>—<usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">dens digito adurgendus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:7:12:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 7, 12, 1</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">(aliquem) remis volantem,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>to pursue closely</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:37:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 37, 17</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aduro: <entryFree id="n1049" type="main" key="a^du_ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ūro</orth>, <itype>ussi, ustum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n1049.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to set fire to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to kindle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to set in a flame</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to burn</hi>, <hi rend="ital">singe</hi>, <hi rend="ital">scorch</hi> (cf. accendo), etc. </sense><sense id="n1049.1" n="I. A." level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, of food: hoc adustum est, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:3:3:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 3, 3, 71</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:8:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 8, 68</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">90</bibl>: splendor quicunque est acer, adurit Saepe oculos, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:330" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 330</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Dionysius candente carbone sibi adurebat capillum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:7:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 7, 23</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:20:58" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 5, 20, 58</bibl>.—So of the Indian sages: <cit><quote lang="la">sine gemitu aduruntur,</quote> <trans><tr>suffer themselves to be burned</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:27:77" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 27, 77</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignes caelestes adussisse complurium vestimenta dicebantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 22</bibl></cit>.—So in Cels., of the burning or cauterizing of a diseased limb: os eodem ferramento adurendum, 8, 2; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:26:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 5, 26, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33" default="NO" valid="yes">33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">flammis aduri Colchicis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:5:24" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 5, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in desertis adustisque sole,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 1, 4, § 19</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1049.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to hurt</hi>, <hi rend="ital">damage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">consume;</hi> of locusts: <cit><quote lang="la">multa contactu adurentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 29, 35, § 104</bibl></cit>.— So of wind, <hi rend="ital">to blast</hi>, from its effects: <cit><quote lang="la">(arbores) aduri fervore aut flatu frigidiore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:216" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 24, 37, § 216</bibl></cit>.—And also of cold and frost, <hi rend="ital">to nip</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to freeze</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne frigus adurat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 92</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec vernum nascentia frigus adurat poma,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:763" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 763</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adusta gelu,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:918" default="NO"><author>id.</author> F. 4, 918</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rigor nivis multorum adussit pedes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:7:3" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 7, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(leonis adipes) sanant adusta nivibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:89" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 8, 25, § 89</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n1049.3" n="II" level="1"> Fig., <usg type="style">poet.</usg> of the fire (flame) of love, <hi rend="ital">to burn</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inflame</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Venus non erubescendis adurit Ignibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:27:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 27, 14</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ardores vincet adusta meos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:12:180" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 12, 180</bibl></cit>.— Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădustus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> </sense><sense id="n1049.4" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Burned by the sun;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">scorched</hi>, <hi rend="ital">made brown</hi>, and, in gen., <hi rend="ital">brown</hi>, <hi rend="ital">swarthy</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si qui forte adustioris coloris ex recenti via essent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adustus corpora Maurus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:269" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 269</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lapis adusto colore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:149" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 58, 59, § 149</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n1049.5" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ădusta</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">burns upon the flesh</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 5, 27</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adusque: <entryFree id="n1050" type="main" key="a^dusque"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-usque</orth>, <itype>for usque ad</itype> (like abusque for usque ab); hence, <sense id="n1050.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Prep.</hi> with <case>acc.</case>, <hi rend="ital">to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">quite</hi> or <hi rend="ital">even to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">all the way to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as far as</hi> (rare, not used in Cic., and for the most part only in the poets of the Aug. per. (<hi rend="ital">metri gratiā</hi>) and their imitators among later prose writers): <cit><quote lang="la">adusque columnas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:262" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 262</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adusque Bari moenia piscosi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:5:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 5, 96</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">97</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:15:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 15, 2</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1050.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>, a strengthened form for usque, <hi rend="ital">throughout</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wholly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">entirely</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oriens tibi victus adusque qua, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adusque deraso capite,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 2, p. 147</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:2:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 5, 2, 7</bibl>: attonsae hae quidem umbrae usque sunt), v. Hand, Turs. I. p. 189.</sense></entryFree>
adustio: <entryFree id="n1051" type="main" key="a^dusti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădustĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aduro</etym>. <sense id="n1051.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A kindling</hi>, <hi rend="ital">burning; a burn</hi> (concrete only in Pliny): <cit><quote lang="la">ulcera frigore aut adustione facta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 32, 4, 14, § 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adustiones sanat (lactuca),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 20, 7, 26, § 61</bibl></cit>.—Also of plants, e. g. vines, <hi rend="ital">a rubbing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">galling</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:116 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 15, 25, § 116 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n1051.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An inflammation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adustio infantium, quae vocatur siriasis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:135" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 30, 15, 47, § 135</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a burned state</hi>, picis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:127" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 20, 25, § 127</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adustus: <entryFree id="n1052" type="main" key="a^dustus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădustus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, from aduro.</entryFree>
adutor: <entryFree id="n1053" type="spur" key="a^du_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăd-ūtor</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">-ūsus</orth>, a false reading in <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 76, 4</bibl>, instead of <sense id="n1053.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">abusus.</hi></sense></entryFree>
advecticius: <entryFree id="n1054" type="hapax" key="advecti_ci^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advectīcĭus</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">-tius</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>adveho</etym>, <sense id="n1054.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">brought to a place</hi> from a distance, <hi rend="ital">foreign</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vinum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 44:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 44, 5</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
advectio: <entryFree id="n1055" type="hapax" key="advecti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advectĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1055.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a bringing</hi> or <hi rend="ital">conveying</hi>, <hi rend="ital">transportation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">longa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:169" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 54, 79, § 169</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
advecto: <entryFree id="n1056" type="hapax" key="advecto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advecto</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <sense id="n1056.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. freq.</hi> [id.], <hi rend="ital">to carry</hi> or <hi rend="ital">convey to a place often</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">rei frumentariae copiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 13</bibl></cit>. <pb n="48" /> <cb n="ADVE" /></sense></entryFree>
advector: <entryFree id="n1057" type="main" key="advector"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advector</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>adveho</etym>, <sense id="n1057.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who conveys</hi> or <hi rend="ital">carries a thing to a place</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a carrier</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">advector equus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Flor. p. 363</bibl></cit> (but in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:2:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 2, 92</bibl>, the correct reading is <hi rend="ital">adventorem</hi>, Fleck.).</sense></entryFree>
advectus: <entryFree id="n1058" type="main" key="advectus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advectus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of adveho.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1059" type="hapax" key="advectus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advectus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>adveho</etym>, = advectio, <sense id="n1059.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a bringing</hi> or <hi rend="ital">conveying to</hi> a place: <cit><quote lang="la">haec de origine et advectu deae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 84</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adveho: <entryFree id="n1060" type="main" key="adve^ho"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-vĕho</orth>, <itype>xi, ctum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (advexti = advexisti, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:3:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 2, 3, 56</bibl>; <sense id="n1060.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">advexe = advexisse,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 2, 61</bibl></cit>), <hi rend="ital">to conduct</hi>, <hi rend="ital">carry</hi>, <hi rend="ital">convey</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bear</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bring</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">a person</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thing to a place;</hi> and <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be carried</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to ride</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to come to a place</hi> upon a horse, in a carriage, ship, etc. (syn.: invehere, inferre, deferre; <cit><quote lang="la">class., and in the histt. very freq.): eam huc mulierem in Ephesum advehit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:1:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 1, 35</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:3:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 2, 3, 56</bibl>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 1, 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:2:88 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 4, 2, 88 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">istam nunc times, quae advectast,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:2:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 1, 2, 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex agris frumentum Romam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad urbem advectus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:31:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 31, 77</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sacerdos advecta (curru) in fanum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:47" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">equo advectus ad fluminis ripam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:28" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sestertiūm sexagies, quod advexerat Domitius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vasa aerea advexerunt populi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,053:27:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Ezech. 27, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Marius Uticam advehitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 86 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in eam partem citato equo advectus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae (naves) advexerant legatos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:23:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 23, 38</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:37 al" default="NO" valid="yes">42, 37 al.</bibl>—So <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:5:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 5, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:45" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:2" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:864" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 864</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">8, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:5:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 5, 90</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:5:134 al" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 5, 134 al.</bibl>—Also: <cit><quote lang="la">humero advehit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:3:69" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 3, 69</bibl></cit>.—In Verg. and Tac. also with <hi rend="ital">acc. pers.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">advehitur Teucros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:136" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 136</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">equo collustrans omnia ut quosque advectus erat, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 45</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:5:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 5, 16</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
advelitatio: <entryFree id="n1061" type="gloss" key="adve_li^ta_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-vēlĭtātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>velitor</etym>, <sense id="n1061.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a skirmish of words</hi>, <hi rend="ital">logomachy</hi>: jactatio quaedam verborum figurata ab hastis velitaribus, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=28" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 28</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
advelo: <entryFree id="n1062" type="main" key="adve_lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-vēlo</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n1062.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to put a veil on a person</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to veil;</hi> <usg type="style">poet.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to wreathe</hi> or <hi rend="ital">crown</hi>: tempora lauro, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:246" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 246</bibl>; and besides only <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Com. 15</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
advena: <entryFree id="n1063" type="main" key="adve^na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advĕna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype> (acc. to Valer. Prob. 1439 and 1445 P., <gen>m.</gen>, <gen>f.</gen>, and <gen>n.</gen>, like verna; cf.<sense id="n1063.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">, however,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 677</bibl></cit> P.: Inveniuntur quaedam ex communibus etiam neutri generi adjuncta, sed figurate per <foreign lang="greek">a)lloio/thta</foreign>, ut advena, mancipium) [advenio], <hi rend="ital">one who comes to</hi> a place; <hi rend="ital">a foreigner</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stranger</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">alien;</hi> and <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">strange</hi>, <hi rend="ital">foreign</hi>, <hi rend="ital">alien</hi>, etc. (syn.: peregrinus, externus, exterus, alienus, alienigena; opp. indigena, native; class. both in prose and poetry). </sense><sense id="n1063.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: defessus perrogitandod advenas Fuit de gnatis, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 634</bibl> P. (Trag. Rel. p. 116 Rib.): advena anus paupercula, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 44</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">volucres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:5" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">advenam gruem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:2:35" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 2, 35</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illas (ciconias) hiemis, has (grues) aestatis advenas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 23, 31, § 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Zeno Citieus advena,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 11 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">advena possessor agelli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:9:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 9, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exercitus advena,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 7, 38</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 460</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Tibris advena,</quote> <trans><tr>as flowing from Etruria into the Roman territory</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:68" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amor advena,</quote> <trans><tr>love for a foreign maiden</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:1:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. A. 1, 75</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">advenae reges,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:19:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 19, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">advenae Romani,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 2, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1063.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">a stranger to a thing</hi>, i.e. <hi rend="ital">ignorant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unskilled</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inexperienced</hi> = ignarus: <cit><quote lang="la">ne in nostra patria peregrini atque advenae esse videamur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:58:249" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 58, 249</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">non hospites, sed peregrini atque advenae nominabamur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 2, 34 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; hence, <usg type="style">poet.</usg> with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">belli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:8:556" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 8, 556</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adveneror: <entryFree id="n1064" type="main" key="adve^ne^ror"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-vĕnĕror</orth>, <itype>āri, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos>, <sense id="n1064.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to give honor to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to adore</hi>, <hi rend="ital">worship</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Minervam et Venerem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:1:6" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 1, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Prosequiturque oculis puer adveneratus (duces) euntes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:13:704" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 13, 704</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
advenientia: <entryFree id="n1065" type="hapax" key="adve^ni^enti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advĕnĭentĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>advenio</etym>, <sense id="n1065.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an arrival</hi>: cohortium, Sisenn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 161 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
advenio: <entryFree id="n1066" type="main" key="adve^ni^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-vĕnĭo</orth>, <itype>vēni, ventum, 4</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n1066.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to come to</hi> a place, <hi rend="ital">to reach</hi>, <hi rend="ital">arrive at</hi> (syn.: accedere, adventare, adire, appellere, adesse); constr. <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in</hi>, or <case>acc.</case> </sense><sense id="n1066.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: verum praetor advenit, Naev. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 468, 27</bibl> (Bell. Pun. v. 44 Vahl.): ad vos adveniens, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:16:38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 16, 38</bibl> (Trag. v. 14 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">ad forum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 4, 2, 6</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:2:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Curc. 1, 2, 55</bibl>; <cb n="ADVE" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. prol. 32</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 5, 2, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">advenis modo? Admodum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:5:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 5, 8</bibl></cit>; Caecil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 247, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">procul a patria domoque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1103" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1103</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad auris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:166" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 166</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:783" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 783</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:874" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 874</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:234" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 234</bibl>: in montem Oetam, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 223, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in provinciam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:11:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 11, 12</bibl></cit> (so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:155" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 155</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">somnus in ignotos oculos): ex Hyperboreis Delphos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">est quiddam, advenientem non esse peregrinum atque hospitem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 6, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:346" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 346</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:1:9:41" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 1, 9, 41</bibl>.—With simple <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Tyriam urbem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:388" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 388</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">unde hos advenias labores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:5:47" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 5, 47</bibl></cit> (whether in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 18</bibl>, properantibus Blaesus advenit, the first word is a <case>dat.</case>, as Rudd. II. p. 135, supposes, or an <hi rend="ital">abl. absol.</hi>, may still be doubted).—Also with <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tentatum advenis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:3:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 2, 3, 41</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 13</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1066.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1066.3" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, in adding an entire thought as an amplification of what precedes (for accedo, q. v.): praeter enim quam quod morbis cum corporis aegret, Advenit id quod eam de rebus saepe futuris Macerat, etc., <hi rend="ital">beside that it often suffers with the body itself</hi>, <hi rend="ital">this often occurs</hi>, <hi rend="ital">that it is itself tormented in regard to the future</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:825" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 825</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1066.4" n="B" level="2"> In the <hi rend="ital">perf.</hi>, the act of coming being considered as completed, <hi rend="ital">to have come</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to be somewhere</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be present</hi> (v. adventus, B.; cf. Herz. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 27</bibl>); <cit><quote lang="la">of time: mterea dies advenit, quo die, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>appeared</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 15</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">ubi dies advenit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 113:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 113, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">advenit proficiscendi hora,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 62</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempus meum nondum advenit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:7:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Joan. 7, 6</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n1066.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To come into one's possession</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to accrue</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 111</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 19 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl>—</sense><sense id="n1066.6" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To come by conveyance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be brought;</hi> of a letter: <cit><quote lang="la">advenere litterae (for allatae sunt),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:7" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vesp. 7</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adventicius: <entryFree id="n1067" type="main" key="adventi_ci^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adventīcĭus</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">-tĭus</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>advenio</etym>, <sense id="n1067.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that is present by coming</hi>, <hi rend="ital">coming from abroad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">foreign</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strange</hi> (extrinsecus ad nos perveniens non nostrum, aut nostro labore paratum, Ern. Clav. Cic.; opp. proprius, innatus, insitus, etc.; in Cic. very freq., elsewhere rare). </sense><sense id="n1067.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">genus (avium),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:5:7" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 5, 7</bibl></cit> (cf. advena): <cit><quote lang="la">Mithridates magnis adventiciis copiis juvabatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:9:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Imp. Pomp. 9, 24</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">auxilium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">externus et adventicius tepor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">externa atque adventicia visio,</quote> <trans><tr>proceeding from the senses</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:58:128" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 58, 128</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">doctrina transmarina et adventicia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dos,</quote> <trans><tr>given by another than the father</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:23:3:5" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 23, 3, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1067.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n1067.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">That is added to what is customary</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">happens out of course</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unusual</hi>, <hi rend="ital">extraordinary</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fructus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 28</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">casus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:40:9:6" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 40, 9, 6</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n1067.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">That is acquired without one's own effort</hi>: adventicia pecunia, <hi rend="ital">obtained</hi>, <hi rend="ital">not from one's own possessions</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but by inheritance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">usury</hi>, <hi rend="ital">presents</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:21" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,030:chapter=17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rab. Post. 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">humor adventicius,</quote> <trans><tr>rain</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:41:3" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 41, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adventiciae res,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:ad Helv. 5" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> ad Helv. 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1067.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">That pertains to arrival</hi> (adventus): <cit><quote lang="la">adventicia cena,</quote> <trans><tr>a banquet given on one's arrival</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vit.:13" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vit. 13</bibl></cit> (cf. adventorius).—<hi rend="ital">Adv. phrase</hi>: ex adventicio, <hi rend="ital">from without</hi>, <hi rend="ital">extrinsically</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quidquid est hoc, quod circa nos ex adventicio fulget, liberi, honores, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Consol. ad Marc. 10" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Consol. ad Marc. 10</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
advento: <entryFree id="n1068" type="main" key="advento"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advento</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <sense id="n1068.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. freq.</hi> [id.], <hi rend="ital">to come continually nearer to</hi> a point (cotidianis itineribus accedere et appropinquare, Manut. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 6 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi></bibl>), <hi rend="ital">to come on</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to approach</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to arrive at</hi> or <hi rend="ital">come to</hi> (esp. with the access. idea of speed, haste; only a few times in Cic., and never in his orations; in the histt. used esp. of the advance of the enemy's army in military order, and the like, cf. Herz. ad Auct. B. G. 8, 20; hence without the signif. of a hostile attack, which adoriri and aggredi have); constr. <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, with <pos>adv.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">prepp.</hi>, the <case>dat.</case>, or <case>acc.</case>, cf. Rudd. II. p. 136. </sense><sense id="n1068.1" n="(a)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: multi alii adventant, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> 6, 15</bibl> (Trag. v. 73 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">te id admonitum advento,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 1, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod jam tempus adventat,</quote> <trans><tr>advances with rapid strides</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:45:199" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 45, 199</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adventans senectus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,051:1:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Sen. 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tu adventare ac prope adesse jam debes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:chapter=4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 4</bibl></cit>. 17: <cit><quote lang="la">Caesar adventare, jam jamque adesse ejus equites falso nuntiabantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 14</bibl></cit>; Auct. B. G. 8, 20.—</sense><sense id="n1068.2" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">adv. of place</hi>: quo cum adventaret, etc., Auct. B. G. 8, 26.—</sense><sense id="n1068.3" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">prepp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad Italiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 6, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad urbem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:514" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 514</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sub ipsam finem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 428</bibl></cit>: in subsidium,<cb n="ADVE" />  <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 32</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1068.4" n="(d)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adventante fatali urbi clade,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accipiendo Armeniae regno adventabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:16:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 16, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">portis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:11:20:2" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 11, 20, 2</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With <case>acc.</case> (cf. advenio): <cit><quote lang="la">propinqua Seleuciae adventabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 44</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">barbaricos pagos ad ventans,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 10</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so of name of town: postquam Romam adventabant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 28</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adventor: <entryFree id="n1069" type="main" key="adventor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adventor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>advenio</etym>, <sense id="n1069.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one that arrives</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a guest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">visitor.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1069.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:2:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 2, 92</bibl>.—So in two inscriptions, Orell. 2287, and Grut. 444, 8; cf. Barth. Adv. p. 1487.—</sense><sense id="n1069.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp., <hi rend="ital">one that comes to a pothouse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">visitor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">customer</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:1:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 1, 2, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adventores meos non incuses,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 7, 55</bibl></cit>, etc.; so <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 10, p. 248</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adventoria: <entryFree id="n1070" type="main" key="advento_ri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adventōrĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, see the foll. art. II.</entryFree>
adventorius: <entryFree id="n1071" type="main" key="advento_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adventōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>adventor</etym>, <sense id="n1071.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that pertains to an arrival</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to a guest</hi>, cf. adventicius: hospitium, <hi rend="ital">in which strangers were received</hi>, Inscr. ap. Mur. 470, 9.—</sense><sense id="n1071.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">adventōria</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (sc. cena), <hi rend="ital">a banquet given on one's arrival</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:12 praef" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 12 praef.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
adventus: <entryFree id="n1072" type="main" key="adventus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adventus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype> (<sense id="n1072.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen.</hi> adventi, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:1:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 1, 3, 2</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 712</bibl> P.), <gen>m.</gen> <etym>advenio</etym>, <hi rend="ital">a coming</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an approach</hi>, <hi rend="ital">arrival</hi> (class., also in <number>plur.</number>). </sense><sense id="n1072.1" n="I. A." level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: Beluarum [haec] ferarum adventus ne taetret loca, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 178, 8</bibl> (Trag.
