Rel. p. 114 Rib.): <cit><quote lang="la">adventum Veneris fugiunt venti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in adventu Titi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,008:7:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Cor. 7, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad urbem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in urbes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,009:chapter=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Imp. Pomp. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut me levārat tuus adventus, sic discessus afflixit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 12, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praestolabor adventum tuum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Judic. 6, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adventibus se offerre, i. e. advenientibus obviam ire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 6, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lucis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 96</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">consulis Romam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 61 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—Sometimes of the approach of an enemy: <cit><quote lang="la">nisi adventus ejus appropinquāsset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,011:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Iph. 2</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:3:6" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 2, 3, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,024:14:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Macc. 14, 17</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1072.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">the state of having arrived</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an arrival</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the being present by arriving</hi> (cf. advenio, B.): <cit><quote lang="la">quorum adventu altera castra ad alteram oppidi partem ponit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">horum adventu tanta rerum commutatio est facta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. G. 2, 27</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1072.3" n="II" level="1"> Fig.: <cit><quote lang="la">adventus in animos et introitus imaginum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:38:105" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 38, 105</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">malorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 3, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exspectantes adventum gloriae Dei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,017:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Tit. 2, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nuptiarum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Paul.</author> Sent. 2, 21</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adverbero: <entryFree id="n1073" type="hapax" key="adverbe^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-verbĕro</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n1073.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to strike on</hi> a thing; with <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adverberat unguibus armos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:9:686" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 9, 686</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adverbialis: <entryFree id="n1074" type="main" key="adverbia_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adverbiālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>adverbium</etym>, <sense id="n1074.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to an adverb</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adverbial: super</hi> et <hi rend="ital">subter</hi> adverbiales sunt, i. e. <hi rend="ital">are sometimes used as adverbs</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> II. p. 182</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">nomina,</quote> <trans><tr>derived from adverbs</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> IV. p. 619</bibl></cit> P.: adjectivum, <hi rend="ital">derived from an adverb</hi>, as <hi rend="ital">externus</hi> from <hi rend="ital">extra</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> II. p. 579</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adverbialiter: <entryFree id="n1075" type="main" key="adverbi^a_li^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adverbĭālĭter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, in gram., <sense id="n1075.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">in the manner of an adverb</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adverbially</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 403</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> 197</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 1012</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
adverbium: <entryFree id="n1076" type="main" key="adverbi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-verbĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>verbum</etym>, in gram., <sense id="n1076.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an adverb</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">e)pi/rrhma</foreign>; acc. to Priscian's expl.: pars orationis indeclinabilis, cujus significatio <hi rend="ital">verbis adicitur</hi>, p. 1003 P.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:5:48" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 5, 48</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:50" default="NO">50</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:3:53" default="NO">9, 3, 53</bibl>; 11, 3, 87 al.</sense></entryFree>
advereor: <entryFree id="n1077" type="spur" key="adve^re^or"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-vĕrĕor</orth>, <itype>ēri</itype>, a false reading in Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 280, 5</bibl>, instead of <sense id="n1077.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">at vereor</hi>, v. Trag. Rel. p. 145 Rib.</sense></entryFree>
adverro: <entryFree id="n1078" type="spur" key="adverro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-verro</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, a false reading in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:4:712" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 4, 712</bibl>, instead of <sense id="n1078.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">advolvensque.</hi></sense></entryFree>
adversaria: <entryFree id="n1079" type="main" key="adversa_ri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adversārĭa</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, see the foll. art. I.</entryFree>
adversarius: <entryFree id="n1080" type="main" key="adversa_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adversārĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>adversus</etym>. <sense id="n1080.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Turned toward</hi> one or <hi rend="ital">lying before</hi> one's eyes; hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">adversārĭa</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype> (sc. scripta), in mercantile language, <hi rend="ital">a book at hand in which all matters are entered temporarily as they occur</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a waste-book</hi>, <hi rend="ital">day-book</hi>, <hi rend="ital">journal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">memoranda</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">Quid est quod neglegenter scribamus adversaria? quid est. quod diligenter conficiamus tabulas? Qua de causa? Quia haec sunt menstrua, illae sunt aeternae: haec delentur statim, illae servantur sancte, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Com. 2, 5</bibl></cit> and 7.</sense><sense id="n1080.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Standing opposite</hi> or <hi rend="ital">opposed to one</hi>, <hi rend="ital">as an antagonist</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in any kind of contest</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in which the contending parties may be the best friends</hi>, e. g. in elections, auctions, <hi rend="ital">discussions</hi>, etc. (cf. Doed. Syn. 4, 395; <cit><quote lang="la">in gen., only of persons, while contrarius is used of things,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1245,001:Differ. 2198" default="NO"><author>Front.</author> Differ. 2198</bibl></cit> P.). </sense><sense id="n1080.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Adj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tribunus seditiosis adversarius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 34</bibl></cit>, <pb n="49" /> <cb n="ADVE" /> 94: <cit><quote lang="la">vis juri adversaria,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:chapter=2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Caecin. 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">opinio oratori,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">duces,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 3, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">populus, adversarius, invidus etiam potentiae,</quote> <trans><tr>in hostile opposition to those in power</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,013:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Timoth. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">factio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,019:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phoc. 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">frater,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 18, 63 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n1080.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">adversārĭus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">an antagonist</hi>, <hi rend="ital">opponent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adversary</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an enemy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rival</hi> (the most usual class. signif. of the word): <cit><quote lang="la">valentiorem nactus adversarium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:prol. 64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. prol. 64</bibl></cit>: injuria adversariūm, Ter. Hec. prol. alt. 14; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ad. prol. 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tribuni plebis illius adversarii, defensores mei,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 15</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Quint. 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,023:chapter=1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Vatin. 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,021:16:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Har. Resp. 16, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Dion. 7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dion. 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:9:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 9, 75</bibl>.—Of wrestlers and other athletæ: <cit><quote lang="la">pugiles etiam cum feriunt adversarium ... ingemiscunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:23:56" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 23, 56</bibl></cit>; also, <cit><quote lang="la">in auctions, of opposing bidders: res major est quam facultates nostrae praesertim adversario et cupido et locuplete,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 12, 43</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 13, 31</bibl>.—In Cic. also in the <hi rend="ital">fem.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">adversārĭa</orth>, ae: <cit><quote lang="la">est tibi gravis adversaria constituta et parata, incredibilis quaedam exspectatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 2, 4, 2</bibl></cit>; and in the <hi rend="ital">neutr. plur.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">adversārĭa</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <hi rend="ital">the arguments</hi>, <hi rend="ital">assertions of the antagonist</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:35:122" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 35, 122</bibl>.!*? The histt. more freq. than Cic. and Hor. use adversarius like hostis for <hi rend="ital">an enemy in war</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversarios in fuga esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,002:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Them. 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">multitudo adversariorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Dat. 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">montem occupat, ne forte cedentibus adversariis receptui foret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 50</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:30:36:68" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 30, 36, 68</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Dom. 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:3:11" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 3, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:20:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Deut. 20, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Vir. Illustr. 75:8" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Vir. Illustr. 75, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:69:2" default="NO">69, 2</bibl>; cf. advosem in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=25" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 25</bibl> Müll.</sense></entryFree>
adversatio: <entryFree id="n1081" type="main" key="adversa_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adversātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>adversor</etym>, <sense id="n1081.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an opposing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">opposition</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Gnost. 5</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> de Pudic. 15</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adversativus: <entryFree id="n1082" type="main" key="adversa_ti_vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adversātīvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1082.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">adversative;</hi> in gram.: conjunctiones adversativae, <hi rend="ital">which have an adversative signif.</hi> as opp. to each other, as tamen, quamquam, etsi, etiamsi, etc., <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 1030</bibl> P.; while quamquam, etsi, etc., we now designate as <hi rend="ital">concessive</hi> in relation to <hi rend="ital">tamen.</hi></sense></entryFree>
adversator: <entryFree id="n1083" type="hapax" key="adversa_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adversātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1083.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who opposes a thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an opponent</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversator malis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> de Deo Socrat. p. 44</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adversatrix: <entryFree id="n1084" type="main" key="adversa_trix"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adversātrix</orth> (archaic <orth extent="full" lang="la">advor-</orth>), <itype>īcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>adversator</etym>, <sense id="n1084.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a female antagonist</hi> or <hi rend="ital">adversary</hi> (in Plaut. and Ter., and then again in Tert.): <cit><quote lang="la">nunc assentatrix, dudum advorsatrix,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:3:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 1, 3, 100</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 5, 3, 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> de Anim. 31</bibl>: quin tu in ea re mihi fueris advorsatrix.</sense></entryFree>
adversatus: <entryFree id="n1085" type="main" key="adversa_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adversātus</orth>, <itype>a um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of adversor.</entryFree>
adverse: <entryFree id="n1086" type="main" key="adverse_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adversē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. adverto, 1. adversus B. <sense id="n1086.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
adversio: <entryFree id="n1087" type="main" key="adversi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adversĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>adverto</etym>, <sense id="n1087.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a turning</hi> or <hi rend="ital">directing</hi> one thing <hi rend="ital">to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">toward</hi> another: <cit><quote lang="la">animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:7:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Arch. 7, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 2, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
adversipedes: <entryFree id="n1088" type="gloss" key="adversi^pe^des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adversĭpĕdes</orth>, <foreign lang="greek">a)nti/podes</foreign>, <sense id="n1088.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">antipodes</hi>, Gloss. Gr. Lat.</sense></entryFree>
adversitas: <entryFree id="n1089" type="main" key="adversi^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adversĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>adversus</etym>, <sense id="n1089.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">opposition</hi>, <hi rend="ital">contrariety.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1089.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">magnam adversitatem scorpionibus et stellionibus putant esse,</quote> <trans><tr>a great natural hostility</tr>, <tr>antipathy</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 25, 30, § 90</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1089.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp., <hi rend="ital">misfortune</hi>, <hi rend="ital">suffering</hi>, Cassiod.</sense></entryFree>
adversitor: <entryFree id="n1090" type="gloss" key="adversi^tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adversĭtor</orth> (archaic <orth extent="full" lang="la">advor-</orth>), <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>adversus</etym>, <sense id="n1090.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who goes to meet another; a slave who went to meet his master</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in order to conduct him home</hi>: “<hi rend="ital">advorsum ierant</hi> proprie locutus est, nam adversitores dicuntur,” Don. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 1, 1, 1</bibl>; cf. also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:4:1:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 4, 1, 23</bibl>, and 2, 32. Among the dramatis personæ of the Mostellaria of Plautus, PHANISCVS ADVORSITOR is found; but the word is nowhere used in the play itself.</sense></entryFree>
adverso: <entryFree id="n1091" type="main" key="adverso"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adverso</orth> (archaic <orth extent="full" lang="la">advor-</orth>), <itype>āre</itype>, <sense id="n1091.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">verb. freq.</hi> [adverto], <hi rend="ital">to turn to</hi> a thing: <cit><quote lang="la">animum advorsavi sedulo, ne, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 2, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adversor: <entryFree id="n1092" type="main" key="adversor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adversor</orth> (archaic <orth extent="full" lang="la">advor-</orth>), <itype>ātus, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym>adversus</etym>: alicui, <sense id="n1092.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to stand opposite to one</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be against</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to resist</hi> or <hi rend="ital">oppose</hi> (in his opinions, feelings, intentions, etc.; while <hi rend="ital">resistere</hi> and <hi rend="ital">obsistere</hi> denote resistance through external action, Doed. Syn. 4, 303; cf. adversarius; class.; freq. in Cic.); constr. with <case>dat.</case> or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">idem ego arbitror nee tibi advorsari certum est de istac re usquam, soror,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 1</bibl></cit>, <cb n="ADVE" /> 21: <cit><quote lang="la">meis praeceptis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 3, 1, 5</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:1:108" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 2, 1, 108</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mihi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:4:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 4, 4, 32</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 2, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hujus libidini,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:31:section=81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 31, § 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ornamentis tuis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:18:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 18, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Isocrati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:51:172" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 51, 172</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">commodis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversantes imperio Domini,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,005:1:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Deut. 1, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">invitā Minervā, id est, adversante et repugnante natura,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:31" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non adversatur jus, quo minus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 3, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversante vento,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversantibus amicis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ann. 13, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversans factio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:11" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversantibus diis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:10" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non adversata petenti Annuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:127" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 127</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,014:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Thess. 2, 4</bibl> al.!*? </sense><sense id="n1092.1" n="a" level="4"> In Tac. constr. also adversari aliquem, H. 1, 1; 1, 38.—</sense><sense id="n1092.2" n="b" level="4"> In Plaut. pleonastic, adversari contra, Cas. 2, 3, 35, and adversari adversus aliquid, Mer. 2, 3, 43.</sense></entryFree>
adversus: <entryFree id="n1093" type="main" key="adversus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adversus</orth> (archaic <orth extent="full" lang="la">advor-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <sense id="n1093.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">turned toward</hi>, <hi rend="ital">opposite</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in front of</hi>, etc., v. <itype>adverto</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> 1.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1094" type="main" key="adversus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adversus</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">adversum</orth> (archaic <orth extent="full" lang="la">advor-</orth>), <pos>adv.</pos> and <sense id="n1094.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">prep.: adv.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">opposite to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">against; prep.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">toward</hi>, <hi rend="ital">against</hi>, <hi rend="ital">before</hi>, etc.; v. <itype>adverto</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> 2.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1096" type="main" key="adversus3" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adversus</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">adversum</orth> (archaic <orth extent="full" lang="la">advor-</orth>) (like rursus and rursum, prorsus and prorsum, quorsus and quorsum), <pos>adv.</pos> and <pos>prep.</pos>, denoting <sense id="n1096.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">direction to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">toward</hi> an object (syn.: contra, in with <case>acc.</case>, ad, erga). </sense><sense id="n1096.1" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Adv.: opposite to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">against</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">toward</hi> a thing, in a friendly or hostile sense: <cit><quote lang="la">ibo advorsum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:2:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 2, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">facito, ut venias advorsum mihi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:2:3:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 2, 3, 82</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">obsecro te, matri ne quid tuae advorsus fuas, Liv. And. ap. Non. s. v. fuam, 111, 12 (Trag. Rel. p. 3 Rib.): quis hic est, qui advorsus it mihi?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:3:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 3, 2, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversus resistere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Pelop. 1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Pelop. 1, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nemo adversus ibat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:13:8 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 13, 8 al.</bibl></cit> In Plaut. and Ter. advorsum ire, or venire, <hi rend="ital">to go to meet;</hi> also of a slave, <hi rend="ital">to go to meet his master and bring him from a place</hi> (hence adversitor, q. v.): <cit><quote lang="la">solus nunc eo advorsum hero ex plurimis servis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:4:1:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 4, 1, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ei advorsum venimus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 2, 32</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:1:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 1, 1, 2</bibl> Ruhnk.—</sense><sense id="n1096.2" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Prep.</hi> with <case>acc.</case>, <hi rend="ital">toward</hi> or <hi rend="ital">against</hi>, in a friendly or a hostile sense. </sense><sense id="n1096.3" n="1" level="3"> In a friendly sense. </sense><sense id="n1096.4" n="(a)" level="5"> Of place, <hi rend="ital">turned to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">toward</hi>, <hi rend="ital">opposite to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">before</hi>, <hi rend="ital">facing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">over against</hi>: qui cotidie unguentatus adversum<cb n="ADVE" />  speculum ornetur, <hi rend="ital">before the mirror</hi>, Scipio ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:7:12" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 7, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversus advocatos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:7:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 7, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">medicus debet residere illustri loco adversus aegrum,</quote> <trans><tr>opposite to the patient</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 3, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversus Scyllam vergens in Italiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 8, 14, § 87</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Lerina, adversum Antipolim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 5, 11, § 79</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1096.5" n="(b)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">In the presence of any one</hi>, <hi rend="ital">before</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">egone ut te advorsum mentiar, mater mea?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:4:7:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 4, 7, 9</bibl></cit>: idque gratum fuisse advorsum te habeo gratiam, <hi rend="ital">I am thankful that this is acceptable before</hi> (<hi rend="ital">to</hi>) <hi rend="ital">thee</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 15</bibl>: paululum adversus praesentem fortitudinem mollitus, <hi rend="ital">somewhat softened at such firmness</hi> (of his wife), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 63</bibl>.—Hence very often with verbs of speaking, answering, complaining, etc., <hi rend="ital">to declare</hi> or <hi rend="ital">express one's self to any one</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to excuse one's self</hi> or <hi rend="ital">apologize</hi>, and the like: te oportet hoc proloqui advorsum illam mihi, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 232, 24</bibl> (Trag. v. 385 Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">immo si audias, quae dicta dixit me advorsum tibi,</quote> <trans><tr>what he told me of you</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:4:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 4, 47</bibl></cit>: de vita ac morte domini fabulavere advorsum fratrem illius, Afran. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 232, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mulier, credo, advorsum illum res suas conqueritur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Titin.</author> ib. 232, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">utendum est excusatione etiam adversus eos, quos invitus offendas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:19:68" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 19, 68</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 71</bibl>.— With that to which a reply is made, <hi rend="ital">to</hi> (= ad): <cit><quote lang="la">adversus ea consul ... respondit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:10:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 10, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:40:1" default="NO" valid="yes">22, 40, 1</bibl>; cf. Drak. ad 3, 57, 1.— </sense><sense id="n1096.6" n="(g)" level="5"> In comparison, as if one thing were held <hi rend="ital">toward</hi>, set <hi rend="ital">against</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">before</hi> another (v. ad, I. D. 4.); <hi rend="ital">against</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in comparison with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">compared to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">repente lectus adversus veterem imperatorem comparabitur,</quote> <trans><tr>will be compared with</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:8:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 8, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid autem esse duo prospera bella Samnitium adversus tot decora populi Rom.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:32:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 7, 32, 8</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n1096.7" n="(d)" level="5"> Of demeanor toward one, <hi rend="ital">to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">toward</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quonam modo me gererem adversus Caesarem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:11:27:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 11, 27, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">te adversus me omnia audere gratum est,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>on my account</tr>, <tr>on my behalf</tr>, <tr>for my advantage</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 9, 22, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lentae adversum imperia aures,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 65</bibl></cit>.—Esp. often of friendly feeling, love, esteem, respect <hi rend="ital">toward</hi> or <hi rend="ital">for</hi> one (cf. Ruhnk. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 4, 1, 15</bibl>; Manut. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 22</bibl>; Heusing. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:11:1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 11, 1</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">Hab. Syn. 49): est enim pietas justitia adversus deos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:41:116" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 41, 116</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:6:28" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 6, 28</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adhibenda est igitur quaedam reverentia adversus homines,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 28, 99</bibl></cit> Beier: <cit><quote lang="la">sunt quaedam officia adversus eos servanda, a quibus injuriam acceperis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 11, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversus merita ingratissimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:69:5" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 69, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">summa adversus alios aequitas erat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:33:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 33, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ob egregiam fidem adversus Romanos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:8:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 29, 8, 2</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:8:4 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 45, 8, 4 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">beneficentiā adversus supplices utendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 17</bibl></cit>.— More rarely (<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) of the general relation of an object or act to a person or thing (v. ad, I. D. 1.), <hi rend="ital">in relation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in respect</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">in regard to</hi> a thing: <cit><quote lang="la">epistula, ut adversus magistrum morum, modestior,</quote> <trans><tr>as addressed to a censor of manners</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:13:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 3, 13, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quasi adversus eos acquieverit sententiae,</quote> <trans><tr>in regard to the same</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:49:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 49, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:3:1" default="NO">3, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1096.8" n="2" level="3"> In a hostile sense, <hi rend="ital">against</hi> (the most usual class. signif. of this word): “Contra et adversus ita differunt, quod contra, ad locum, ut: contra basilicam; adversus, ad animi motum, ut: adversus illum facio; interdum autem promiscue accipitur,” <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 207</bibl> P.; cf. Cort. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 101:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 101, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">advorsum legem accepisti a plurimis pecuniam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:4:2:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 4, 2, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">advorsum te fabulare illud,</quote> <trans><tr>against thy interest</tr>, <tr>to thy disadvantage</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:4:2:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Stich. 4, 2, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">stultus est advorsus aetatem et capitis canitudinem, id. ap. Fest. s. v. canitudinem, p. 47: advorsum animi tui libidinem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 4, 1, 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversum leges, adversum rem publicam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:84:section=195" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 84, § 195</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">respondebat, SI PARET, ADVERSUM EDICTUM FECISSE,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 3, 28</bibl></cit>, § <cit><quote lang="la">69: me adversus populum Romanum possem defendere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:1:13 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 1, 13 al.</bibl></cit>—In the histt., of a hostile attack, approach, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">gladiis districtis impetum adversus montem in cohortes faciunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversus se non esse missos exercitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 66</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bellum adversum Xerxem moret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Caes. 24:3" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Caes. 24, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">copiis quibus usi adversus Romanum bellum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversus vim atque injuriam pugnantes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:25:10 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 26, 25, 10 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">T. Quintius adversus Gallos missus est,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Eutr.</author> 2, 2</bibl></cit>: Athenienses adversus tantam tempestatem belli duos duces deligunt, <cb n="ADVO" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:3:6:12 al" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 3, 6, 12 al.</bibl>—Among physicians, of preventives against sickness, <hi rend="ital">against</hi> (v. ad, I. A. 2.): <cit><quote lang="la">adversus profusionem in his auxilium est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:5:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 5, 26</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:6:27 al" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 27 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">frigidus jam artus et cluso corpore adversum vim veneni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 64</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">egregium adversus tempestates receptaculum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:2:17:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 2, 17, 4</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:ib. 2:15:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 15, 36</bibl>.—Hence: firmus, invictus, fortis adversus aliquid (like contra), <hi rend="ital">protected against a thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">firm</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fixed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">secure</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">advorsum divitias animum invictum gerebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 43:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 43, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">invictus adversum gratiam animus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversus convicia malosque rumores firmus ac patiens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:28" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Adversus omnes fortis feras canis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0975,001:5:10:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Phaedr.</author> 5, 10, 1</bibl></cit>; and in opp. sense: infirmus, inferior adversus aliquid, <hi rend="ital">powerless against</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unequal to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fama, infirmissimum adversus vivos fortes telum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:14" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">infirmus adversum pecuniam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Caes. 9:6" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Caes. 9, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inferior adversus laborem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Epit. 40:20" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Epit. 40, 20</bibl></cit>.!*? </sense><sense id="n1096.9" n="a" level="4"> Adversus is rarely put after the word which it governs: <cit><quote lang="la">egone ut te advorsum mentiar,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:4:7:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 4, 7, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hunc adversus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,009:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Con. 2, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Tim. 4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Tim. 4, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quos advorsum ierat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 101:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 101, 8</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1096.10" n="b" level="4"> It sometimes suffers tmesis: <cit><quote lang="la">Labienum ad Oceanum versus proficisci jubet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 33</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animadvortit fugam ad se vorsum fieri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animum advortere ad se vorsum exercitum pergere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 69</bibl></cit>: ad Cordubam versus iter facere coepit, Auct. B. Hisp. 10 and 11; cf. <hi rend="ital">in-versus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in Galliam vorsus castra movere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 56</bibl></cit>; Sulp. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 12</bibl>; Traj. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:10:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 10, 78</bibl>; the Eng. <hi rend="ital">to-ward</hi>: to us ward, Psa. 40, 5; and the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">ei)s-de</foreign>: <foreign lang="greek">ei)s a(/lade</foreign>, Hom. Od. 10, 351.</sense></entryFree>
adverto: <entryFree id="n1095" type="main" key="adverto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-verto</orth> (archaic <orth extent="full" lang="la">advor-</orth>), <itype>ti, sum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n1095.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to turn</hi> a thing <hi rend="ital">to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">toward</hi> a place (in this signif., without animus; mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>; syn.: observare, animadvertere, videre, cognoscere). </sense><sense id="n1095.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1095.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen., with <hi rend="ital">in</hi> or <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">illa sese huc advorterat in hanc nostram plateam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:3:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 3, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in quamcunque domus lumina partem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:180" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 180</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:8:482" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 482</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">malis numen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:611" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 611</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">huc aures, huc, quaeso, advertite sensus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:16:213" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 16, 213</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:6:105" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 105</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1095.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp., a naut. t. t., <hi rend="ital">to turn</hi>, <hi rend="ital">direct</hi>, <hi rend="ital">steer a ship to a place</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">classem in portum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 37, 9</bibl></cit> Drak.: <cit><quote lang="la">terrae proras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 35</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:117 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 4, 117 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Colchos puppim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:12:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 12, 23</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">profugi advertere coloni,</quote> <trans><tr>landed</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:1:288" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 1, 288</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">hence also transf. to other things: aequore cursum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:196" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 196</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedem ripae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 386</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbi agmen,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 555</bibl></cit>: adverti with <case>acc.</case> <usg type="style">poet.</usg> for verti ad: <cit><quote lang="la">Scythicas advertitur oras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:649" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 649</bibl></cit> (cf. adducor litora remis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:3:598" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 598</bibl>, and Rudd. II. p. 327).</sense><sense id="n1095.4" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n1095.5" n="A" level="2"> Animum (in the poets and Livy also animos, rarely mentem) advertere; <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, or with <pos>adv.</pos> or ad aliquid, or alicui rei, <hi rend="ital">to direct the mind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">thoughts</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">attention to a thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to advert to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">give attention to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attend to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to heed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">observe</hi>, <hi rend="ital">remark</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si voles advortere animum, Enn. ap. Var. L. L. 7, § 89 Müll. (Trag. v. 386 Vahl.): facete advortis animum tuum ad animum meum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:1:1:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 1, 1, 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc huc animum advortite ambo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 1, 169</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">advertunt animos ad religionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">monitis animos advertite nostris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:140" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 140</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animum etiam levissimis rebus adverterent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:13:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 13, 49</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">ne</hi>, when the object of attention is expressed: <cit><quote lang="la">ut animum advertant, ne quos offendant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:19:68" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 19, 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adverterent animos, ne quid novi tumultūs oriretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 45</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1095.6" n="B" level="2"> Animum advertere, <hi rend="ital">to observe a thing by directing the mind to it</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to observe</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to notice</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to remark</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to perceive</hi> (in the class. period contracted to animadvertere, q. v.).—Constr. with <hi rend="ital">two accusatives</hi>, animum advertere aliquid (where aliquid may be regarded as depending on the prep. in comp., Roby, § 1118, or on animum advertere, considered as one idea, <hi rend="ital">to observe</hi>), with <case>acc.</case> and <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">rel. clause</hi> (the first mode of construction, most frequent with the pronouns id, hoc, illud, etc., is for the most part ante-class., and appears in Caes., Cic., and Sall. as an archaism): <cit><quote lang="la">et hoc animum advorte,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:3:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 3, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hanc edictionem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 2, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec animum te advertere par est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 125</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animum adverti columellam e dumis eminentem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:23:65" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 23, 65</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:51:153" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Inv. 2, 51, 153</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Postquam id animum advertit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 24</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quidam Ligus animum advortit inter saxa repentīs cocleas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 93:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 93, 2</bibl></cit>. In Vitruv. once with hinc: <cit><quote lang="la">ut etiam possumus hinc animum advertere,</quote> <trans><tr>as we can hence perceive</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:10:22:262" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 10, 22, 262</bibl></cit>.—With the <case>acc.</case> and <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">postquam tantopere id vos velle animum advorteram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:5:8:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 5, 8, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animum advertit magnas esse copiashostium instructas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 18</bibl></cit>: cum animum adverteret locum relictum esse, Auct. B. Alex. 31; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 46</bibl>.—With the <hi rend="ital">rel. clause</hi>: nunc quam rem vitio dent, quaeso, animum <cb n="ADVE" /> advortite, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:prol. 8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. prol. 8</bibl>: quid ille sperare possit, animum adverte, Dolab. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quam multarum rerum ipse ignarus esset ... animum advertit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 48</bibl></cit>. Sometimes advertere alone = animum advertere; so once in Cicero's letters: nam advertebatur Pompeii familiares assentiri Volcatio, Fam. 1, 1 (although here, as well as almost everywhere, the readings fluctuate between advertere and animadvertere; cf. Orell. ad h. l.; <hi rend="ital">animadvertebatur</hi>, B. and K.). So Verg. in the <hi rend="ital">imp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qua ratione quod instat, Confieri possit, paucis, adverte, docebo,</quote> <trans><tr>attend!</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:115" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 115</bibl></cit>.—In the histt., esp. Tac. and Pliny, more frequently: <cit><quote lang="la">donec advertit Tiberius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Zenobiam advertere pastores,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">advertere quosdam cultu externo in sedibus senatorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 13, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quotiens novum aliquid adverterat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 30</bibl></cit> al.: <cit><quote lang="la">hirudo quam sanguisugam appellari adverto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 10, 10, § 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut multos adverto credidisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:168" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 67, 67, § 168</bibl></cit>. Still more rarely, advertere animo: <cit><quote lang="la">animis advertite vestris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:712" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 712</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hanc scientiam ad nostros pervenisse animo adverto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 2, 3, § 5</bibl></cit>; cf. Drak. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:27:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 27, 8</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1095.7" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To draw</hi> or <hi rend="ital">turn something</hi>, esp. <hi rend="ital">the attention of another</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">upon one's self</hi> (in the histt.): <cit><quote lang="la">gemitus ac planctus militum aures oraque advertere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">octo aquilae imperatorem advertere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 17</bibl></cit>: recentia veteraque odia advertit, <hi rend="ital">drew them on</hi> himself, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 21</bibl> al.—</sense><sense id="n1095.8" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To call the attention of one to a definite act</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to admonish of it</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to urge to it</hi> (cf. II. A.): <cit><quote lang="la">non docet admonitio, sed advertit,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>directs attention</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 94" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 94</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">advertit ea res Vespasiani animum, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 48</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1095.9" n="E" level="2"> Advertere in aliquem, for the more usual animadvertere in aliquem, <hi rend="ital">to attend to one</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to punish one</hi> (only in Tac.): <cit><quote lang="la">in P. Marcium consules more prisco advertere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut in reliquos Sejani liberos adverteretur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 9</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Germ. 7, 3</bibl>: animadvertere).—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1095.10" n="1" level="3"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">adversus</orth> (archaic <orth extent="full" lang="la">advor-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">turned to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">toward</hi> a thing, <hi rend="ital">with the face</hi> or <hi rend="ital">front toward</hi>, <hi rend="ital">standing over against</hi>, <hi rend="ital">opposite</hi>, <hi rend="ital">before</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in front of</hi> (opp. aversus). </sense><sense id="n1095.11" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">solem adversum intueri,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Somn. Scip. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Iris ... Mille trahens varios adverso sole colores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:701" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 701</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:218" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 1, 218</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">antipodes adversis vestigiis stant contra nostra vestigia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 39</bibl></cit>: dentes adversi acuti (<hi rend="ital">the sharp front teeth</hi>) morsu dividunt escas, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:54" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 54</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod is collis, tantum adversus in latitudinem patebat, quantum etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 8</bibl></cit> Herz. So, hostes adversi, <hi rend="ital">who make front against one advancing</hi> or <hi rend="ital">retreating</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 24</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">L. Cotta legatus in adversum os fundā vulneratur,</quote> <trans><tr>in front</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 35</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 7 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl> al.; hence, vulnus adversum, <hi rend="ital">a wound in front</hi> (on the contr., vulnus aversum, <hi rend="ital">a wound in the back</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,021:chapter=19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Har. Resp. 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversis vulneribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Vir. Illustr. 35:4" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Vir. Illustr. 35, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">judicibus cicatrices adversas ostendere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cicatrices populus Romanus aspiceret adverso corpore exceptas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 5, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">impetus hostium adversos, Auct. B. Alex. 8: Romani advorso colle evadunt,</quote> <trans><tr>ascend the hill in front</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversa signa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">legiones quas Visellius et C. Silius adversis itineribus objecerant,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>marches in which they went to meet the enemy</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 42</bibl></cit>: sed adverso fulgure (<hi rend="ital">by a flash of lightning falling directly before him</hi>) pavefactus est Nero, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:48" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 48</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">armenta egit Hannibal in adversos montes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:17:19" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 17, 19</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:1013" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 1013</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:1:103" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 1, 103</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 3, 205</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui timet his adversa,</quote> <trans><tr>the opposite of this</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1, 6, 9 al.</bibl></cit>—Hence, of rivers: flumine adverso, <hi rend="ital">up the stream</hi>, <hi rend="ital">against the stream</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in adversum flumen contendere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:423" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 423</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adverso feruntur flumine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:720" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 720</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:201" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 201</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adverso amne,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 6, 7, § 33</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">adverso Tiberi subvehi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Vir. Illustr. 22:3" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Vir. Illustr. 22, 3</bibl></cit> (opp. to secundā aquā, <hi rend="ital">down stream</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with the stream</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">rate in secundam aquam labente,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:47:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 47, 3</bibl></cit>); and of winds, <hi rend="ital">opposed to</hi> a vessel's course, <hi rend="ital">head winds</hi>, <hi rend="ital">contrary winds</hi>, consequently <hi rend="ital">unfavorable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adverse</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">navigationes adversis ventis praecluduntur, Auct. B. Alex. 8: adversissimi navigantibus venti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 107</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">adversum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <hi rend="ital">the opposite</hi>: hic ventus a septentrionibus oriens adversum tenet Athenis proficiscentibus, <pb n="50" /> <cb n="ADVE" /> <hi rend="ital">holds the opposite to those sailing from Athens</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">blows against them</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Milt. 1</bibl> (so Nipperdey; but v. Hand, Turs. I. p. 183). —<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: ex adverso, also written exadverso and exadversum, <hi rend="ital">opposite to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">over against</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">e)k tou= e)nanti/ou</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">portus ex adverso urbi positus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 10</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Patrae ex adverso Aetoliae et fluminis Eveni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 4, 5, § 11</bibl></cit>.—Without case: <cit><quote lang="la">cum ex adverso starent classes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:14" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 2, 14</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:39" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 39</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:33" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 33</bibl>.—In adversum, <hi rend="ital">to the opposite side</hi>, <hi rend="ital">against</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">et duo in adversum immissi per moenia currus,</quote> <trans><tr>against each other</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:9:23" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 3, 9, 23</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:2:30" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 2, 30</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:237" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 237</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">in adversum Romani subiere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:23" default="NO" valid="yes">7, 23</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1095.12" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">In hostile opposition to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adverse to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unfavorable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unpropitious</hi> (opp. secundus; frequent and class.): conqueri fortunam adversam, Pac. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:21:50" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 21, 50</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic dies pervorsus atque advorsus mihi obtigit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:5:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 5, 5, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">advorsus nemini,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:1:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 1, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mentes improborum mihi infensae et adversae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:chapter=10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sull. 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acclamatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 83</bibl></cit>: adversā avi aliquid facere, vet. poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:16" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversis auspiciis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:Vir. Illustr. 64:6" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> Vir. Illustr. 64, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversum omen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vit.:8" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vit. 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversissima auspicia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Oth. 8</bibl></cit>: adversae res, <hi rend="ital">misfortune</hi>, <hi rend="ital">calamity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adverse fortune</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut adversas res, sic secundas immoderate ferre levitatis est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:26" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 26</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">adversi casus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dat. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversae rerum undae,</quote> <trans><tr>a sea of troubles</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 22</bibl></cit>: omnia secundissima nobis, adversissima illis accidisse, Caes. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:10:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 10, 9</bibl> (the <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi> is found also in Cæs. B. C. 3, 107): <cit><quote lang="la">quae magistratus ille dicet, secundis auribus, quae ab nostrum quo dicentur, adversis accipietis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversus annus frugibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">valetudo adversa,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>sickness</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 10, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversum proelium,</quote> <trans><tr>an unsuccessful engagement</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 7, 29</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">8, 31: adverso rumore esse,</quote> <trans><tr>to be in bad repute</tr>, <tr>to have a bad reputation</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Ann. 14, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversa subsellia,</quote> <trans><tr>on which the opposition sit</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:1:39" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 1, 39</bibl></cit>.—Sometimes met. of feeling, <hi rend="ital">contrary to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hated</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hateful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">odious</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quīs omnia regna advorsa sint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 83</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:2:229" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 2, 229</bibl> Bentl.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque est aliud adversius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 32, 4, 14, § 35</bibl></cit>.—* <hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">adver-sē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">self-contradictorily</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:3:16" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 3, 16</bibl>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-versum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, esp. in the <number>plur.</number> adversa, <hi rend="ital">misfortune</hi>, <hi rend="ital">calamity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">disaster</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adversity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">evil</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mischief</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">advorsa ejus per te tecta sient,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:3:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 3, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil adversi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:1:4" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quid adversi accidisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,007:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Alc. 8</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 40</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:13" default="NO" valid="yes">35, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">secunda felices, adversa magnos probant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:31" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 31</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">esp. freq. in Tac.: prospera et adversa pop. Rom., Ann. 1, 1: adversa tempestatum et fluctuum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:Agr. 25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 25</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:A. 3:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 3, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:45" default="NO" valid="yes">45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:69" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 69</bibl>; 4, 13 al.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">adversus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">an opponent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">adversary</hi> (rare): <cit><quote lang="la">multosque mortalīs ea causa advorsos habeo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 52:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 52, 7</bibl></cit>.—In Quint. also once <orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-versa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a female opponent</hi> or <hi rend="ital">adversary</hi>: natura noverca fuerit, si facultatem dicendi sociam scelerum, adversam innocentiae, invenit, 12, 1, 2.—</sense><sense id="n1095.13" n="C" level="2"> In rhet., <hi rend="ital">opposed to another of the same genus</hi>, e. g. sapientia and stultitia: “Haec quae ex eodem genere contraria sunt, appellantur adversa,” <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:chapter=11" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 11</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
advesperascit: <entryFree id="n1097" type="main" key="advespe^rascit"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-vespĕrascit</orth>, <itype>āvit, 3</itype>, <sense id="n1097.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. impers.</hi> and <hi rend="ital">inch.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">it approaches evening</hi>, <hi rend="ital">it is getting to be evening</hi>, <hi rend="ital">twilight is coming on</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">advesperascit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 4, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:24:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Luc. 24, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum jam advesperasceret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 65</bibl></cit>, etc.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:28" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 4, 28</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nisi advesperāsset, Auct. B. Hisp. 24: cum advesperavisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:178" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 52, 53, § 178</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">advesperascente die,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,029:7:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Prov. 7, 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
advigilo: <entryFree id="n1098" type="main" key="advi^gi^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-vĭgĭlo</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n1098.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to watch by</hi> or <hi rend="ital">at</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to keep guard over</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be watch ful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vigilant for;</hi> constr. with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> or <case>dat.</case>, Rudd. II. p. 136 </sense><sense id="n1098.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad custodiam ignis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:12" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">parvo nepoti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:5:93" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 5, 93</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vallo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Eutr. 2, 419</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1098.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">to bestow care</hi> or <hi rend="ital">attention upon a thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to watch</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to watch for.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1098.3" n="(a)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">exquire, heus tu, advigila,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:4:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 4, 4, 63</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tanto magis te advigilare aequomst,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:1:4:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 1, 4, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si advigilaveris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:4:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 4, 1, 19</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1098.4" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">pro</hi>: si advigilamus pro rei dignitate, Q. Cic. Petr. Cons. <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n1098.5" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">stupris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> L. Stil. 2, 140</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sibi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 1, 81</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
advivo: <entryFree id="n1099" type="main" key="advi_vo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-vīvo</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <sense id="n1099.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To live with one;</hi> joined with cum by pleonasm: <cit><quote lang="la">CONIVGI DVLCISSIMO CVM QVO ADVIXIT SINE QVERELA PER ANNOS XX.,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 1145, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1115, 8</bibl> (Orell. 3094).—</sense><sense id="n1099.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To live</hi>, with the access. idea of continuance, <hi rend="ital">to live on</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to continue living</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dum adviveret,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Josh. 4, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">donec advivet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:34:3:28" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 34, 3, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quamdiu advixerit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:3:4:4" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 3, 4, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:30" default="NO">30</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
advocamentum: <entryFree id="n1100" type="main" key="advocamentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advocamentum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = advocatio: <sense id="n1100.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">veniam advocamenti peto,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:5:8:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 5, 8, 11</bibl></cit>, where the better read. is <hi rend="ital">advocandi</hi>, Keil.</sense></entryFree>
advocatio: <entryFree id="n1101" type="main" key="advo^ca_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advŏcātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>advoco</etym>, <sense id="n1101.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a calling to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">summoning</hi> (in the class. per. only as t. t. in judicial lang.). </sense><sense id="n1101.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, abstr., <hi rend="ital">legal assistance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">judicial aid</hi> (v. advoco and advocatus): <cit><quote lang="la">tu in re militari multo es cautior quam in advocationibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 10</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1101.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n1101.3" n="A" level="2"> Concr., <hi rend="ital">legal assistance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the whole body of assistants</hi>, <hi rend="ital">counsel</hi> (= <hi rend="ital">the bar</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">haec advocatio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:chapter=56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 56</bibl></cit>: so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Quint. 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:chapter=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Com. 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:chapter=15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Caecin. 15</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:chapter=29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 49</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:chapter=21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Dom. 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:47 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 47 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n1101.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The time allowed for procuring legal assistance</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut binas advocationes postulent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 11</bibl></cit> Manut.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:Decl. 280" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> Decl. 280</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n1101.5" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Any kind of delay</hi> or <hi rend="ital">adjournment</hi> (freq. in Seneca): ratio advocationem sibi petit, ira festinat, Sen. de Ira, 1, 16; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:Cons. ad Marc. 10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Cons. ad Marc. 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:Q. N. 7:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Q. N. 7, 10</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1101.6" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Consolation</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Patient. 11</bibl>; v. advoco, II. C.</sense></entryFree>
advocator: <entryFree id="n1102" type="main" key="advo^ca_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advŏcātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>: qui advocat, <sense id="n1102.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an advocate</hi> (eccl. Lat.): Deus divitum aspernator, mendicorum advocator, Tert contr. Marc. 4, 15.</sense></entryFree>
advocatus: <entryFree id="n1103" type="main" key="advo^ca_tus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advŏcātus</orth>. a. um. <mood>Part.</mood> of advoco <pb n="51" /> <cb n="ADVO" /></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n1104" type="main" key="advo^ca_tus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advŏcātus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1104.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a legal assistant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">counsellor</hi>, etc., v. advoco <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
advoco: <entryFree id="n1105" type="main" key="advo^co"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-vŏco</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n1105.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to call</hi> or <hi rend="ital">summon one to</hi> a place, esp. for counsel, aid, etc.; constr. <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in</hi>, or <case>dat.</case> </sense><sense id="n1105.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen. </sense><sense id="n1105.2" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego Tiresiam advocabo et consulam quid faciendum censeat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:5:1:76" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 5, 1, 76</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">contionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 80</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem ad obsignandum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:12:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 12, 18</bibl></cit>;
