so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 39</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">viros primarios in consilium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:7:section=18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 7, § 18</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego vos, quo pauca monerem, advocavi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eo (i. e. in aedem Concordiae) senatum advocat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:ib. 47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(Deus) advocabit caelum desursum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,027:49:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Psa. 49, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">advocari gaudiis,</quote> <trans><tr>to be invited</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:11:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 11, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aegro,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> R. Am. 110</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">causis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:11:1:38" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 11, 1, 38</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1105.3" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">animum ad se ipsum advocamus,</quote> <trans><tr>we turn the mind upon itself</tr>, <tr>call the thoughts home</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:31" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non desiderat fortitudo advocatam iracundiam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 23</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:38" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 5, 38</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n1105.4" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n1105.5" n="A" level="2"> In judicial lang., t. t., <hi rend="ital">to avail one's self of</hi> some one in a cause, <hi rend="ital">as aid</hi>, <hi rend="ital">assistant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">witness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">counsellor</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">to call in</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:3:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 3, 3, 6</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:3:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 2, 3, 28</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:7:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 4, 7, 59</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquot mihi Amicos advocabo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:2:1:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 2, 1, 83</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">viros bonos complures advocat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in his, quos tibi advocasti,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2</bibl></cit> al.—Also used of the friend of the plaintiff or defendant, who calls in his friends to aid in the suit: <cit><quote lang="la">Oppianicus in judicio Scamandri aderat, frequens advocabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 19</bibl></cit>.—Hence, transf. to other things, <hi rend="ital">to call to one's aid</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to call to for help</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to summon</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">desuper Alcides telis premit omniaque arma Advocat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:249" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 249</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">secretas artes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:138" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 138</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad conamina noctem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:9:82" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 9, 82</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Troad. 613" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Troad. 613</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid in tutelam securitatis suae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:108" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 108</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vires suas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 6:2" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 6, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1105.6" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To get a respite</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to delay</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:5:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 5, 8</bibl>; v. advocatio, II. C. —</sense><sense id="n1105.7" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To give consolation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to console</hi> (in imitation of the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">parakalei=n</foreign>), <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 14</bibl>.!*? In the phrase ADVOCAPIT CONCTOS, in the song of the Fratres Arvales, Grotef. (Gr. II. 290) explains advocapit as an old <hi rend="ital">imperat.</hi>, instead of advocabite.Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">advŏcātus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> </sense><sense id="n1105.8" n="A" level="2"> In the class. per., in judicial lang., <hi rend="ital">one who is called by one of the parties in a suit to aid as a witness</hi> or <hi rend="ital">counsel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a legal assistant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">counsellor</hi> (diff. from patronus or orator, who spoke for a client engaged in a suit; from cognitor, who appeared in the name of such parties as had themselves been at first in court; <cit><quote lang="la">and from procurator, who appeared for such as were absent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0803,001:ad Cic. Div. in Caecil. 4" default="NO"><author>Ascon.</author> ad Cic. Div. in Caecil. 4</bibl></cit>; Ruhnk. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:3:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 2, 3, 48</bibl>; Heind. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:5:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 5, 38</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">v. Smith's Dict. Antiq.): quaeso, ut advocatus mihi adsis neve abeas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:4:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 4, 3, 3</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:2:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 5, 2, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:5:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 5, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:3:1:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 3, 1, 23</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">6, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:5:2:37 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 5, 2, 37 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">adversusne illum causam dicerem, cui veneram advocatus?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:5:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 5, 43</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:2:3:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 2, 3, 49</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 6, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 4, 5, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quis eum umquam non modo in patroni, sed in laudatoris aut advocati loco viderat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 40</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 1, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">venire advocatum alicui in rem praesentem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 10</bibl></cit>, etc.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:33:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 33, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1105.9" n="B" level="2"> In the post-Aug. per., for patronus, orator, etc., who conducted a process for any one, <hi rend="ital">an advocate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attorney</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:1:13" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 1, 13</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:1:25" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 12, 1, 25</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:6" default="NO">5, 6</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; 9, 3, 22; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:7:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 7, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 5, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:15" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 15</bibl> and 33.—</sense><sense id="n1105.10" n="C" level="2"> Esp., in eccl. Lat., of Christ as our <hi rend="ital">intercessor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">advocate</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">advocatum habemus apud Patrem, Jesum Christum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,023:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Joan. 2, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1105.11" n="D" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, in gen., <hi rend="ital">an assistant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">helper</hi>, <hi rend="ital">friend</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">se in fugam conferunt unā amici advocatique ejus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:8:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 8, 22</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
advolatus: <entryFree id="n1106" type="hapax" key="advo^la_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advŏlātus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>advolo</etym>, <sense id="n1106.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a flying to</hi>: tristi advolatu, Poët. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:10:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 10, 24</bibl>, as a transl. from the Gr. of Aeschyl. Prometh. Solut.</sense></entryFree>
advolitans: <entryFree id="n1107" type="main" key="advo^li^tans"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advŏlĭtans</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> [ad-volito], <sense id="n1107.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">flying often to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fluttering about</hi>: papilio luminibus advolitans, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 19, 21, § 65</bibl>: advolitans noctua, * <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> adv. Symm. 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
advolo: <entryFree id="n1108" type="main" key="advo^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-vŏlo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n1108.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to fly to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">toward;</hi> constr. with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in</hi>, <case>dat.</case>, or <case>acc.</case>, Rudd. II. p. 136. </sense><sense id="n1108.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, of birds: <cit><quote lang="la">avis advolans ad eas avīs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:49" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in agrum Volaterranum palumbium vise mari advolat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:78 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 29, 41, § 78 al.</bibl></cit>: papilio luminibus<cb n="AEAC" />  lucernarum advolans, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:162" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 28, 10, 45, § 162</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1108.2" n="II" level="1"> Metaph., of other things, <hi rend="ital">to fly to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">run to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">come to</hi> (class.): <cit><quote lang="la">vox mihi advolavit ad aurīs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 69</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rud. 2, 3, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:5:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 5, 2, 23</bibl>: imago ad nos, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:316" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 316</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad urbem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:chapter=4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 4 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in Formianum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 2, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Larino Romam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 6</bibl></cit>: ejus (Britanniae) <foreign lang="greek">ei)/dwlon</foreign> mihi advolabit ad pectus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:15:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 15, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hostes ex omnibus partibus ad pabulatores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">classem advolaturam esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> B. C. 2, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in auxilium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:20" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fama advolat Aeneae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:511" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 511</bibl></cit>; Manil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 760</bibl> P.—With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">rostra Cato advolat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 14 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:4:300" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 4, 300</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
advolvo: <entryFree id="n1109" type="main" key="advolvo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ad-volvo</orth>, <itype>vi, vŏlūtum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n1109.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to roll to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">toward.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1109.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">robora focis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:377" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 377</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:182" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 6, 182</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">advolvi (for advolvere se) ad ignem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:185" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 37, 70, § 185</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">advolvit saxum magnum ad ostium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:27:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 27, 60</bibl></cit>; Marc. 15, 46.—</sense><sense id="n1109.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp., of suppliants, <hi rend="ital">to throw one's self at</hi> the feet of any one, <hi rend="ital">to fall at. fall prostrate before</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">genibus ejus advolutus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:80" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 80</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnium genibus se advolvens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 37 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">advolvi genibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 28, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tuis advolvimur aris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:16:1" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 16, 1</bibl></cit>.—With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: genua patrum advolvuntur, Sall. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 1, 311</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Tiberii genua advolveretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 13</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 49</bibl>; 15, 71.—<usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: magnusque advolvitur astris clamor, <hi rend="ital">rolls</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">rises</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ascends</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:5:143" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 5, 143</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
advorsum: <entryFree id="n1110" type="main" key="advorsum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advorsum, advorsus</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">advorto</orth>, etc., v. adversum, adversus, etc.</entryFree>
advosem: <entryFree id="n1111" type="gloss" key="advosem"><orth extent="full" lang="la">advosem</orth>: “adversarium, hostem, dixere veteres,” <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=25" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 25</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
adynamon: <entryFree id="n1112" type="greek" key="a^dy^na^mon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădynămon</orth> vīnum = <foreign lang="greek">a)du/natos oi)=nos</foreign>, <sense id="n1112.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">weakened wine</hi> (half wine and half water): <cit><quote lang="la">ex ipso vino quod vocant adynamon,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 16, 19, § 100</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
adytum: <entryFree id="n1113" type="greek" key="a^dy^tum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ădytum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/duton</foreign> (not to be entered), <sense id="n1113.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the innermost part of a temple</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the sanctuary</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which none but priests could enter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and from which oracles were delivered.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1113.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: in occultis ac remotis templi, quae Graeci <foreign lang="greek">a)/duta</foreign> appellant, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 105</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aeternumque adytis effert penetralibus ignem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:297" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 297</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">isque adytis haec tristia dicta reportat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 115</bibl></cit>; 6, 98; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:16:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 16, 5</bibl>.—In gen., <hi rend="ital">a secret place</hi>, <hi rend="ital">chamber;</hi> of the dead, <hi rend="ital">a grave</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tomb</hi>, in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 84</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:13:205" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 13, 205</bibl>: descriptionem cubiculorum in adytis, <hi rend="ital">chambers in secret places</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">inner chambers</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,015:28:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Par. 28, 11</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1113.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig.: ex adyto tamquam cordis responsa dedere, <hi rend="ital">the inmost recesses</hi>, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:737" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 737</bibl>.!*? In Attius also <hi rend="ital">masc.</hi> adytus, ūs: adytus augura, in <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 488, 4</bibl> (Trag. Rel. p. 217 Rib.).</sense></entryFree>
adzelor: <entryFree id="n1114" type="hapax" key="adze_lor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">adzēlor</orth>, <itype>āri</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos>, <sense id="n1114.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to be zealous against one</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be angry with</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> 4</bibl> Esdr. 16, 49.</sense></entryFree>
ae: <entryFree id="n1115" type="main" key="ae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ae</orth>, see the letter A.</entryFree>
aea: <entryFree id="n1116" type="main" key="Aea"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aea</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)=a</foreign> (land). In the fable of the Argonauts, <sense id="n1116.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a peninsula in Colchis</hi>, <hi rend="ital">round which the Phasis flowed</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:742" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 1, 742</bibl>, and 5, 426.</sense></entryFree>
aeacideius: <entryFree id="n1117" type="main" key="Aea^ci^de_i^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeăcĭdēĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1117.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to the Æacidœ</hi> (the posterity of Æacus): <cit><quote lang="la">regna,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Ægina</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:472" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 472</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aeacides: <entryFree id="n1118" type="main" key="Aea^ci^de_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeăcĭdēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)aki/dhs</foreign>, <sense id="n1118.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">patr. m.</hi> (<case>voc.</case> Aeacidā, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:56" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:3:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 3, 87</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">Aeacidē,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:8:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 7</bibl></cit>; <hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> Aeacidūm, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:15:392" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 15, 392</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">a male descendant of Æacus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an Æacide.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1118.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: stolidum genus Aeacidarum, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:56" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:15:292" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 15, 292</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:12:15" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 12, 15</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1118.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp., <hi rend="ital">his son Phocus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:668" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 668</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">His sons Telamon and Peleus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 4</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">His son Peleus alone</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:365" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 365</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">His grandson Achilles</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 99</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12:82" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12, 82</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">96</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">365</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">His great-grandson Pyrrhus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">son of Achilles</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:296" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 296</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">His later descendants</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Pyrrhus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Epirus</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:56" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 56</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aeacidarum genus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:12" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 12</bibl></cit>; and <hi rend="ital">Perseus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Macedon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">conquered by Æmilius Paulus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:839" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 839</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:1:627" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 1, 627</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeacidinus: <entryFree id="n1119" type="main" key="Aea^ci^di_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeăcĭdīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1119.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to the Æacide</hi> (<hi rend="ital">Achilles</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">Aeacidinis minis animisque expletus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:2:3:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 2, 3, 25</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aeacius: <entryFree id="n1120" type="main" key="Aea^ci^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeăcĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1120.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Æacian</hi>: flos, <hi rend="ital">the hyacinth</hi> (as springing from the blood of Ajax, grandson of <hi rend="ital">Æacus</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:10:175" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 10, 175</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeacus: <entryFree id="n1121" type="main" key="Aea^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeăcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)ako/s</foreign> (Gr. <case>acc.</case> Aeacon,<cb n="AEDE" />  <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:434" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 434</bibl>), acc. to the fable, <sense id="n1121.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">son of Jupiter by Europa</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Ægina</hi>, <hi rend="ital">father of Peleus and Telamon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">grandfather of Achilles and Ajax; on account of his just government made judge in the lower regions</hi>, <hi rend="ital">with Minos and Rhadamanthus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quam pæne judicantem vidimus Aeacum!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:13:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 13, 22</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 25</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeaea: <entryFree id="n1122" type="main" key="Aeaea"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeaea</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)ai/h</foreign>, acc. to fable, <sense id="n1122.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the island in the Tyrrhene Sea where the Circe of Homer had her abode</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and where</hi>, acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9, § 58</bibl>, <hi rend="ital">the later Circeii was situated</hi>, now called <hi rend="ital">Monte Circello.</hi> Acc. to Mela, 2, 7 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi>, it was the abode of Calypso.</sense></entryFree>
aeaeus: <entryFree id="n1123" type="main" key="Aeaeus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeaeus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)ai=os</foreign>. <sense id="n1123.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Belonging to Æa</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in Colchis</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Colchian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Circe, since Circe is said to have been earlier in Colchis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:386" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 386</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:205" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 205</bibl>.— Hence, </sense><sense id="n1123.1" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">belonging to Circe</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">artes,</quote> <trans><tr>magic arts</tr>, <tr>such as Circe practised</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:2:15:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 2, 15, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">carmina,</quote> <trans><tr>magic words</tr>, <tr>charms</tr>, <tr>spells</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:1:8:5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 8, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1123.2" n="II" level="1"> Aeaea puella, <hi rend="ital">Calypso</hi>, because she had her residence in Aeaea, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:11:31" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 11, 31</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeas: <entryFree id="n1124" type="main" key="Aeas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeas</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1124.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river of Epirus</hi>, Mela, 2, 3, 13; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:145" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 23, 26, § 145</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:580" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 580</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:6:361" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 6, 361</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aebura: <entryFree id="n1125" type="main" key="Aebu_ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aebūra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1125.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city of Hispania Tarraconensis</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Cuerva</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:30:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 30, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aebutius: <entryFree id="n1126" type="main" key="Aebu_ti^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aebūtĭus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, <sense id="n1126.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">name of a Roman gens</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 16, 2, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:chapter=1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Caecin. 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fl. 37, 93 al.</bibl>—Hence: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aebūtĭa lex</orth>, <itype>so called from its author</itype>, the tribune Aebutius; <cit><quote lang="la">enacted A.U.C. 520,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 8</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:16:10:8" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 16, 10, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aecae: <entryFree id="n1127" type="main" key="Aecae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aecae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n1127.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city of Apulia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">southeast of Luceria</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Troja</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:20:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 20, 5</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aecani</orth>, <itype>orum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Æcae</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 11, 16, § 105</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeculanum: <entryFree id="n1128" type="main" key="Aecu^la_num"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aecŭlānum</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeclānum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n1128.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a city of the Hirpini in Samnium</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Le Grotte</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 3, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 16, 2, 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 5019</bibl>.—Hence: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aecŭlāni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Æc.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 11, 16, § 105</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 444, 5</bibl>; and: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aecŭlā-nenses</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeclānenses</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, the same as <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aecŭlāni</orth>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 838, 862</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3108 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
aedepol: <entryFree id="n1129" type="main" key="aedepol"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedepol</orth>, = edepol, v. Pollux.</entryFree>
aedes: <entryFree id="n1130" type="main" key="aede_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedēs</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">aedis</orth> (the form <sense id="n1130.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">aedes</hi> is found in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:21:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 21, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:8:14" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 8, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:9:43 al" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 9, 43 al.</bibl>, and now and then in other writers, but <hi rend="ital">aedis</hi> is more common, as in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:55:section=121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 4, 55, § 121</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:4:2:31" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Par. 4, 2, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:4:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 4, 7, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:5:32:156 al" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> 5, 32, 156 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:33:9 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 33, 9 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 6, 8, § 50</bibl>), <itype>is</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a building for habitation.</hi> [Aedis domicilium in edito positum simplex atque unius aditus. Sive ideo aedis dicitur, quod in ea aevum degatur, quod Graece <foreign lang="greek">ai)w/n</foreign> vocatur, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=13" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 13</bibl> Müll. Curtius refers this word to <foreign lang="greek">ai)/qw</foreign>, aestus, as meaning originally, <hi rend="ital">fire-place</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hearth;</hi> others, with probability, compare <foreign lang="greek">e(/dos, e(/dra</foreign>, and sēdes.] </sense><sense id="n1130.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Sing.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a dwelling of the gods</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a sanctuary</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a temple</hi> (prop., a simple edifice, without division into smaller apartments, while templum is a large and splendid structure, consecrated by the augurs, and belonging to one or more deities; cf. Manut. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 7</bibl>; but after the Aug. period aedes was used for templum; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:78" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 78</bibl> with <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 84</bibl>): haec aedis, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 494, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">senatum in aedem Jovis Statoris vocavi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 6</bibl></cit>: aedis Martis, Nep. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 792</bibl> P.: <cit><quote lang="la">aedes Mercurii dedicata est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic aedem ex marmore molitus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:11:5" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 11, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inter altare et aedem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:11:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Luc. 11, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aedem Concordiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 1, 6, § 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aedes Veneris genitricis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:78" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 78</bibl></cit>; v. above; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aedem Baal,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,014:10:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 4 Reg. 10, 27</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:19:24 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Act. 19, 24 al.</bibl>: haec ego ludo, quae nec in aede sonent, i. e. <hi rend="ital">in the temple of the Muses</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">of the Palatine Apollo</hi>, <hi rend="ital">where poems were publicly recited</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:10:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 10, 38</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quanto molimine circumspectemus vacuam Romanis vatibus aedem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 94</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi> in this sense generally in connection with sacrae, divinae, deorum, and only when several temples are spoken of: <cit><quote lang="la">aedes sacrae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:chapter=49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Dom. 49</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:30:100" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 30, 100</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Capitolii fastigium et ceterarum aedium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 46</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 41</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Deorum aedes,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Cat. 21</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:38" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ner. 38</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:21 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Claud. 21 al.</bibl>— </sense><sense id="n1130.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A dwelling for men</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a house</hi>, <hi rend="ital">habitation</hi>, <pb n="52" /> <cb n="AEDI" /> <hi rend="ital">obode</hi> (syn. domus; usu. only in the plur., as a collection of several apartments; but in the earliest period the sing. also may have had this signif., though but few certain examples of it have been preserved in the written language; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:3:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 1, 3, 67</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hic noster quaestus aucupii simillimust ... aedis nobis areast, auceps sum ego): aedes probae et pulchre aedificatae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:5:2:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 5, 2, 60</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 1, 2, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ultimae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:5:1:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 5, 1, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">apud istum in aedibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:19:section=50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 19, § 50</bibl></cit>, and soon after: in mediis aedibus; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:512" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 512</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">liberae,</quote> <trans><tr>a house that is rent-free</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:30:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 30, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">privatae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:44 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 44 al.</bibl></cit>—Hence sometimes used for a part of the domus, <hi rend="ital">a room</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an apartment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">chamber</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">insectatur omnes domi per aedīs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:3:5:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 3, 5, 31</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:462" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 462</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:487" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 2, 487</bibl> (v. also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:4:14" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 4, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:8:6" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 8, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:30:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 30, 4</bibl>).—In Plaut., by comic license, aedes for familia: credo hercle has sustollat aedīs totas atque hunc in crucem, Mil. 2, 3, 39: ut ego suffringam his talos totis aedibus, <hi rend="ital">to break the legs of this whole house</hi> (i. e. family), Truc. 2, 8, 7: ab aedibus, denoting office (cf. ab), <hi rend="ital">a castellan</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">CVM AB AEDIBVS ESSEM,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 697, 1</bibl></cit>.— * </sense><sense id="n1130.3" n="B" level="2"> Met., <hi rend="ital">the cells</hi> (or hive) <hi rend="ital">of bees</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">clausis cunctantur in aedibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:258" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 258</bibl></cit>.— * </sense><sense id="n1130.4" n="C" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">fac, sis, vacivas aedīs aurium, mea ut migrare dicta possint,</quote> <trans><tr>the chambers of your ears</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:5:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 5, 54</bibl></cit>.— * </sense><sense id="n1130.5" n="D" level="2"> Aedes aurata, <hi rend="ital">a gilded funeral structure</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on which the dead body of Cœsar was laid</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a catafalque</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:84" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 84</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aedicula: <entryFree id="n1131" type="main" key="aedi^cu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭcŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>aedes</etym>, <sense id="n1131.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small building intended for a dwelling.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1131.1" n="I" level="1"> For gods, <hi rend="ital">a chapel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a small temple</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum aram et aediculam et pulvinar dedicāsset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:chapter=53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Dom. 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Victoriae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:41" default="NO" valid="yes">35, 41</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aediculam in ea (domo) deo separavit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Judic. 17, 5</bibl></cit>; also <hi rend="ital">a niche</hi> or <hi rend="ital">shrine for the image of a god</hi>: in aedicula erant Lares argentei positi, Petr Sat. 29 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aediculam aeream fecit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 1, 6, § 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:87" default="NO" valid="yes">36, 13, 19, § 87</bibl>.—Hence on tombstones, <hi rend="ital">the recess in which the urn was placed</hi>, Inscr. Fabrett. c. 1, 68.—</sense><sense id="n1131.2" n="II" level="1"> For men, <hi rend="ital">a small house</hi> or <hi rend="ital">habitation</hi> (mostly in <number>plur.</number>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">aedes, II.),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:4:3:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 4, 3, 58</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,047:6:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Par. 6, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,014:23:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 4 Reg. 23, 7</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sing.</hi> in Plaut., <hi rend="ital">a small room</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a closet</hi>: in aediculam seorsum concludi volo, Ep<bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 3, 3, 19 sq.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
aedifacio: <entryFree id="n1132" type="main" key="aedi^faci^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭfacĭo</orth>, <itype>ere, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, = aedifico: <sense id="n1132.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">Labeo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:19:260" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 19, 260</bibl></cit> Torrentinus, where others read <hi rend="ital">aedificare.</hi></sense></entryFree>
aedifex: <entryFree id="n1133" type="hapax" key="aedi^fex"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭfex</orth>, <itype>fĭcis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = aedificator, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Idol. 12</bibl>.</entryFree>
aedificatio: <entryFree id="n1134" type="main" key="aedi^fi^ca_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭfĭcātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aedifico</etym>. <sense id="n1134.0" n="I" level="1"> Abstr., <hi rend="ital">the act of building</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a building</hi> or <hi rend="ital">constructing.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1134.1" n="(a)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">si ad horum luxuriam dirigas aedificationem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:13" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">immensa et intolerabilis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 21</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> 2</bibl> Para. 16, 6.—</sense><sense id="n1134.2" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbium,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Judith, 5, 10</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n1134.3" n="II" level="1"> Concr., <hi rend="ital">a building</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a structure</hi>, <hi rend="ital">edifice</hi>, Cato ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:13:23" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 13, 23</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">domum tuam et aedificationem omnem perspexi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aedificationes templi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:24:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Matt. 24, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1134.4" n="III" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">building up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">instructing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">edification.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1134.5" n="(a)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">loquitur ad aedificationem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,007:14:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Cor. 14, 3</bibl></cit>; 14, 26.—</sense><sense id="n1134.6" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad aedificationem Ecclesiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,007:14:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Cor. 14, 12</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,010:4:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Eph. 4, 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aedificatiuncula: <entryFree id="n1135" type="hapax" key="aedi^fi^ca_ti^uncu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭfĭcātĭuncŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>aedificatio</etym>, <sense id="n1135.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a little building</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ecquid de illa aedificatiuncula mandavisses,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:1:2:section=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 1, 2, § 5</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aedificator: <entryFree id="n1136" type="main" key="aedi^fi^ca_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭfĭcātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>aedifico</etym>. <sense id="n1136.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A builder</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vocaberis aedificator saepium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,048:58:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Isa. 58, 12</bibl></cit>; in the class. period only trop., = <foreign lang="greek">dhmiourgo/s</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">mundi,</quote> <trans><tr>the maker</tr>, <tr>architect</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=2" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Univ. 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aedificatores mundi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:9" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1136.1" n="II" level="1"> From the Aug. period <pos>adj.</pos> (cf. Br. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Ages. 4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Ages. 4, 2</bibl>) with the access. idea of inclination or passion, <hi rend="ital">that is fond of building</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nemo illo minus fuit emax, minus aedificator,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:14:86" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 14, 86</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1:4:8" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 1, 4, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1:8:4" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 1, 8, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aedificatorius: <entryFree id="n1137" type="main" key="aedi^fi^ca_to_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭfĭcātōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1137.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to building.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1137.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">aedificatoria somnia,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Anim. 47</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭfĭcātōrĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = architectura, Boëth. Aristot. Top. 3, 1, p. 680.—</sense><sense id="n1137.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig.: <cit><quote lang="la">verbum aedificatorium mortis,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>that was the cause of death</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Carn. Christ. 17</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aedificialis: <entryFree id="n1138" type="hapax" key="aedi^fi^ci^a_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭfĭcĭālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1138.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to</hi> <cb n="AEDI" /> <hi rend="ital">a building</hi> [aedes]: Priamus ad aram Jovis aedificialis confugit (so called because he was worshipped in the building; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Fest. s. v. Herceus, p. 101 Müll.),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Dict. Cret.</author> 5, 12</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aedificium: <entryFree id="n1139" type="main" key="aedi^fi^ci^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭfĭcĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>aedifico</etym>, <sense id="n1139.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a building of any kind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an edifice</hi>, <hi rend="ital">structure</hi>, even though not suitable for a dwelling (while aedes designates only a structure for habitation).—Hence: <cit><quote lang="la">aedes aedificiaque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:38:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 38, 38</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 9 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">exstruere aedificium in alieno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnibus vicis aedificiisque incensis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 29</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:13:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 13, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 41</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aedificiorum prolapsiones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:30" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 30</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Oth. 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">regis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,013:9:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 3 Reg. 9, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">paries aedificii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,053:41:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Ezech. 41, 12</bibl></cit>.—In late Lat., = aedificatio: <cit><quote lang="la">aedificium domūs Domini,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,013:9:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 3 Reg. 9, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">murorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,023:16:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Macc. 16, 23</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aedifico: <entryFree id="n1140" type="main" key="aedi^fi^co"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭfĭco</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>aedesfacio</etym>, lit. <sense id="n1140.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to erect a building</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to build;</hi> and in gen., <hi rend="ital">to build</hi>, <hi rend="ital">raise</hi>, <hi rend="ital">erect</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">establish any thing.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1140.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: aedificare cum sit proprie aedem facere, ponitur tamen <foreign lang="greek">kataxrhstikw=s</foreign> in omni genere constructionis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=13" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 13</bibl> Müll.; hence in the first signif. for the most part </sense><sense id="n1140.2" n="(a)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">aedificare diu cogitare oportet,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 3, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ecce aedificat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:2:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 2, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad quem (usum) accommodanda est aedificandi descriptio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:39:138" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 39, 138</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 23, 83</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tribus locis aedifico, reliqua reconcinno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lautius, id Leg. 2, 1, 3: belle,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:13 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 9, 13 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accuratius ad frigora atque aestus vitandos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">diruit, aedificat, mutat quadrata rotundis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 1, 100</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:308" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> S. 2, 3, 308</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1140.3" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">object</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">domum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 4</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:1:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 1, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">casas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:247" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 247</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1140.4" n="II" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to build</hi>, <hi rend="ital">construct</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">navim,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Plaut.</author> Mer. prol. 87</bibl></cit> piscinas, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:17:5" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 17, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">navem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 4, 53</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 1, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">oppida,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2</bibl></cit> Para. 26, 6: <cit><quote lang="la">turrim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,001:21:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Matt. 21, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">murum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2</bibl></cit> Para. 33, 14: <cit><quote lang="la">porticum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,020:chapter=43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Dom. 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hortos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 9, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">equum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mundum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:25" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tot adhuc compagibus altum aedificat caput,</quote> <trans>i.e. <tr>makes it</tr>, <tr>by bands and hair ornaments</tr>, <tr>a high tower</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:6:501" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 6, 501</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1140.5" n="III" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">to build up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">establish</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">rem publicam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 2</bibl></cit>.—And (eccl.) in a religious sense, <hi rend="ital">to build up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">instruct</hi>, <hi rend="ital">edify.</hi> </sense><sense id="n1140.6" n="(a)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">caritas aedificat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,007:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Cor. 8, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non omnia aedificant,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 16, 23</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n1140.7" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">object</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">semetipsum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,007:14:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Cor. 14, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">alterutrum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,013:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Thess. 5, 11</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aedilatus: <entryFree id="n1141" type="gloss" key="aedi_la_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedīlātus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = aedilitas [aedilis], <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=13" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 13</bibl> Müll.</entryFree>
aedilicius: <entryFree id="n1142" type="main" key="aedi_li_ci^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedīlīcĭus</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">aedīlīt-</orth>), <itype>a um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1142.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to an œdile</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">munus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:16" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">repulsa, i. e. in aedilitate petenda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:chapter=21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Planc. 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">scriba,</quote> <trans><tr>of an œdile</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">largitio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:25:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 25, 2</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:16" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vectigal aediliciorum, sc. munerum,</quote> <trans><tr>paid to the œdiles to defray the expense of public exhibitions</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 1, 9</bibl></cit>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">aedīlīcĭus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (sc. vir), <hi rend="ital">one who had been an œdile</hi> (as consularis, who had been consul), <hi rend="ital">an exœdile</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:7:10" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 7, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aedilicius est mortuus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=28" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 28</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,023:chapter=7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Vatin. 7</bibl>: edictum, <hi rend="ital">an ordinance of the œdile on entering upon his office</hi> (v. edictum), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:21:1" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 21, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aediliciae edictiones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:4:2:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 4, 2, 43</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aedilis: <entryFree id="n1143" type="main" key="aedi_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedīlis</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (<case>abl.</case> aedili, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 12, 64</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 7, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:18:6:13" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 18, 6, 13</bibl>; <sense id="n1143.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">but aedile is more usual,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 96</bibl></cit> P.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:1:22" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> 1, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:44:95" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 44, 95</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:158" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 48, 49, § 158</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 3787, 8</bibl>; cf. Schne<bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Gr. II. p. 221</bibl>; Koffm. s. v.) [aedes], <hi rend="ital">an œdile</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a magistrate in Rome who had the superintendence of public buildings and works</hi>, <hi rend="ital">such as temples</hi>, <hi rend="ital">theatres</hi>, <hi rend="ital">baths</hi>, <hi rend="ital">aqueducts</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sewers</hi>, <hi rend="ital">highways</hi>, <hi rend="ital">etc.;</hi> also <hi rend="ital">of private buildings</hi>, <hi rend="ital">of markets</hi>, <hi rend="ital">provisions</hi>, <hi rend="ital">taverns</hi>, <hi rend="ital">of weights and measures</hi> (to see that they were legal), <hi rend="ital">of the expense of funerals</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and other similar functions of police.</hi> The class. passages applying here are: <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:2:3:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 2, 3, 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=81" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 81</bibl> Müll.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:3:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 3, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:9:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 9, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 85</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:162" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 162</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:101" default="NO">10, 101</bibl>; Fest. s. h. v. p. 12; cf. Manut. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:8:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 8, 3</bibl> and 6.—Further, the aediles, esp. the curule ædiles (two in number), were expected to exhibit public spectacles; and they often lavished the most exorbitant expenses upon them, <cb n="AEDU" /> in order to prepare their way toward higher offices, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:16" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:6" default="NO" valid="yes">27, 6</bibl>. They inspected the plays before exhibition in the theatres, and rewarded or punished the actors according to their deserts, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:4:2:148" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 4, 2, 148</bibl>; id. Cist. ep. 3; <cit><quote lang="la">for this purpose they were required by oath to decide impartially,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:prol. 72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. prol. 72</bibl></cit>.—It was the special duty of the aediles plebeii (of whom also there were two) to preserve the decrees of the Senate and people in the temple of Ceres, and in a later age in the public treasury, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 55</bibl>. The office of the aediles curules (so called from the <hi rend="ital">sella curulis</hi>, the seat on which they sat for judgment (v. curulis), while the aediles plebeii sat only on benches, subsellia) was created A.U.C. 387, for the purpose of holding public exhibitions, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 6, 42</bibl>, first from the patricians, but as early as the following year from the plebeians also, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 1</bibl>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Julius Cæsar created also the office of the two aediles Cereales, who had the superintendence of the public granaries and other provisions,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:41" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 41</bibl></cit>.—The free towns also had ædiles, who were often their only magistrates, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 13, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:179" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 179</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:10:102" default="NO">10, 102</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:1:130" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 1, 130</bibl>; v. further in Smith's Dict. Antiq. and Niebuhr's Rom. Hist. 1, 689 and 690.!*? Plaut. uses the word once adject.: aediles ludi, <hi rend="ital">œdilic sports</hi>, Poen. 5, 2, 52.</sense></entryFree>
aedilitas: <entryFree id="n1144" type="main" key="aedi_li^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedīlĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aedilis</etym>, <sense id="n1144.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the office of an œdile</hi>, <hi rend="ital">œdileship</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aedilitatem gerere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:2:2:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 2, 2, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">petere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Quint. 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aedilitate fungi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:16" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">munus aedilitatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:12:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 3, 12, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">praetermissio aedilitatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:17" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 2, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">curulis aedilitas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,021:13:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Har. Resp. 13, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:9" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Vesp. 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:38 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Claud. 38 al.</bibl>—<hi rend="ital">Plur.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">splendor aedilitatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:16:57" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 16, 57</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aedilitius: <entryFree id="n1145" type="main" key="aedi_li_ti^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedīlītĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. aedilicius.</entryFree>
aedis: <entryFree id="n1146" type="main" key="aedis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedis</orth>, v. aedes.</entryFree>
aeditimor: <entryFree id="n1147" type="hapax" key="aedi^ti^mor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭtĭmor</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭtŭmor</orth> <etym>an earlier form for aedituor</etym>, <itype>āri</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos>, <sense id="n1147.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to keep</hi> or <hi rend="ital">take care of a temple</hi>: aeditumor in templo tuo, Pompon. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:12:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 12, 10</bibl>. Nonius quotes the same passage, 75, 15, but reads <hi rend="ital">aedituor.</hi></sense></entryFree>
aeditimus: <entryFree id="n1148" type="main" key="aedi^ti^mus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭtĭmus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">aedĭtŭ-</orth>) (an earlier form for aedituus, and first used in the time of Varro; v. the first quotation), <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1148.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who keeps</hi> or <hi rend="ital">takes care of a temple</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the keeper</hi> or <hi rend="ital">overseer of a temple</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">i(erofu/lac</foreign>: <cit><quote lang="la">in aedem Telluris veneram, rogatus ab aeditumo, ut dicere didicimus a patribus nostris, ut corrigimur a recentibus urbanis: ab aedituo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:2" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 2</bibl></cit>: Aeditimus ... Pro eo a plerisque nunc <hi rend="ital">aedituus</hi> dicitur, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:12:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 12, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:69" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 69</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:2" default="NO"><author>id.</author> L. L. 6, 2</bibl>: <hi rend="ital">liminium</hi> productionem esse verbi (Servius) volt, ut in finitumo, legitumo, aeditumo, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:8:36" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 8, 36</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aeditua: <entryFree id="n1149" type="hapax" key="aedi^tu^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭtŭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>aedituus</etym>, <sense id="n1149.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a female overseer of a temple</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 2444</bibl>.— <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum omnes templum simus Dei, ejus templi aeditua et antistes pudicitia est,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Cult. Fem. 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aeditualis: <entryFree id="n1150" type="hapax" key="aedi^tu^a_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭtŭālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n1150.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to a temple-keeper</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Pudic. 16</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aedituens: <entryFree id="n1151" type="hapax" key="aedi^tu^ens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭtŭens</orth>, <itype>entis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = aedituus, <sense id="n1151.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a keeper of a temple</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1275" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1275</bibl>, referred to by <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:12:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 12, 10 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
aedituus: <entryFree id="n1152" type="main" key="aedi^tu^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">aedĭtŭus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>aedes-tueor; quasi a <hi rend="ital">tuendis aedibus</hi> appellatus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:12:10" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 12, 10</bibl></etym>, <sense id="n1152.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a keeper of a temple</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a sacristan</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">i(erofu/lac</foreign> (first used in polite language in the time of Varro for aeditumus; v. the word and the passage cited from Varr.). </sense><sense id="n1152.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:1:3:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 1, 3, 48</bibl>: aeditui custodesque mature sentiunt, etc., * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 44</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:1 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Dom. 1 al.</bibl> It belonged also to the office of the aeditui to conduct strangers through the temple, and point out its curiosities, hence Horace says: quales aedituos habeat virtus, <hi rend="ital">what panegyrists</hi>, Ep. 2, 1, 230.—</sense><sense id="n1152.2" n="II" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">priests</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ministers</hi> (eccl.): <cit><quote lang="la">erunt in sanctuario meo aeditui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,053:44:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Ezech. 44, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Ose. 10, 5</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aedon: <entryFree id="n1153" type="greek" key="a^e_don"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăēdon</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">trisyl.</orth>), <itype>ŏnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)hdw/n</foreign>, <sense id="n1153.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the nightingale</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tristis aëdon,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Agam. 670" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Agam. 670</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> Sat. 131</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0830,001:6:8" default="NO"><author>Calp.</author> Ecl. 6, 8</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aedonius: <entryFree id="n1154" type="main" key="a^e_do^ni^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăēdŏnĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> (pentasyl.) [aëdon], <sense id="n1154.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to the nightingale</hi>: vox, Auct. Pan. ad Pison. 257; <bibl default="NO"><author>Lact.</author> Phoenic. 47</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aedui: <entryFree id="n1155" type="main" key="Aedu^i"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aedŭi</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Haed-</orth>), <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n1155.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a tribe in Gallia Celtica friendly to the Romans</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Departements de la Cōte d'Or</hi>, <hi rend="ital">de la Nievre</hi>, <pb n="53" /> <cb n="AEGE" /> <hi rend="ital">de Saōne et Loire</hi>, <hi rend="ital">et du Rhōne</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:10:11:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 10, 11, 23</bibl>, etc.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 19</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:3:2:4" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 3, 2, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:107 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 18, 32, § 107 al.</bibl>—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aedŭĭ-cus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Haed-</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the Ædui</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">stemma,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Aus.</author> Par. 4, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
aeetaeus: <entryFree id="n1156" type="main" key="Aee_taeus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeētaeus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n1156.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">belonging to Æetes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Colchis</hi>: fines, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Colchis</hi>, Catull. 64, 3; from</sense></entryFree>
aeetes: <entryFree id="n1157" type="main" key="Aee_tes"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeētes</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">Aeētas</orth>, or <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeēta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)h/ths</foreign>, <sense id="n1157.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">king of Colchis</hi>, acc. to the fable, <hi rend="ital">son of Sol and Persa</hi>, <hi rend="ital">daughter of Oceanus; father of Medea</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by whose aid the Argonauts took from him the golden fleece</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:21" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:12:29:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 12, 29, 51</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0533,001:3:22" default="NO"><author>Hyg.</author> 3, 22</bibl> and 23; <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. G. 2, 140</bibl> and 141.— Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeētĭăs</orth>, <itype>iădis</itype>, <hi rend="ital">patr. f.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">daughter of Æetes</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">Medea</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 9</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">326</bibl>.— <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeētīnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, the same as preced. (from Aeetes, as Nerine from Nereus), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:6:103" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 6, 103</bibl>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeētis</orth>, <itype>ĭdos</itype>, <hi rend="ital">patr. f.</hi>, = Aeetias, <hi rend="ital">daughter of Æetes</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:8:233" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 8, 233</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0800,001:2:110" default="NO"><author>Albin.</author> 2, 110</bibl>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Aeētĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Æetes</hi>, = Aeetaeus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:8:379" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 8, 379</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegae: <entryFree id="n1158" type="main" key="Aegae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <number>plur.</number>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)gai/</foreign>. <sense id="n1158.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A city of Cilicia</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Ayas</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:3:227" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 3, 227</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1158.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A small town on the western coast of Eubœa</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Limni</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:7:371" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 7, 371</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aegaeon: <entryFree id="n1159" type="main" key="Aegaeon"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aegaeon</orth>, <itype>ō^nis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*ai)gai/wn</foreign>. <sense id="n1159.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A giant-monster</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the other name of Briareus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:565" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 565</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,003:1:209" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Ach. 1, 209</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1159.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A sea-god</hi>, acc. to the fable, <hi rend="ital">the son of Pontus and Terra</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n1159.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg> for <hi rend="ital">the Ægean Sea</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:5:288" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 5, 288</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
